**The Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity**

**Scripture Title:** *The Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity*
**Author:** Xiao Yingsou, a Daoist of the Southern Song Dynasty
**Volume:** Five
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongzhen* Section, *Jade Instructions* Category

---

**Memorial on the Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity**

Your subject, Yingsou, respectfully states: Having examined *The Wondrous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure for the Salvation of Humanity*, I have compiled its esoteric meaning into this work, carved onto wood for transmission.

The *Primordial Kalpa* is called the *Prior Heaven*; the *Root Chapter of the Numinous Treasure* is thus named the *Supreme Scripture*. Its transformative power may be likened to the solitary return of the elixir, yet who but the Great Brahmā could encompass its vastness?

Now that its publication is complete, how dare I neglect to make this solemn declaration? With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head in prostration.

I humbly reflect: The vast and undifferentiated One Reality forms the shared body of Heaven and Earth; the myriad transformations, though diverse, share the same root in life and death. Though sentient beings differ in awareness, they all fundamentally accord with the wondrous emptiness of the formless.

Yet why do fame and profit stir the will, while emotions and desires delude the mind? Though the source is one, its streams diverge; though natures are near, habits grow distant. All this arises from clinging to illusion—how can one know the Eternal? The five colors dazzle the eyes—who will turn their gaze inward? The ten thousand changes bloom in profusion—who can reverse their course?

One may fortify the valley’s boat or store treasures in the abyss, yet how can one halt the sun’s chariot from departing? Rather than lamenting early death while clinging to life, it is better to cultivate the True and honor destiny.

Thus, our August Sovereign of the Void, the Sagely Lord, expounded the wondrous Dao before the empty kalpas; the Most High Jade Clarity, the Supreme Honored One, received the true transmission within the millet-like pearl. The salvation of beings is boundless, and the blessings bestowed are inexhaustible.

Yet the Great Dao is nothing but the true mean, and later generations, through repetition and distortion, have turned the contemplation of the wondrous into golden shackles, while their confusion of the source resembles fish trapped in a basin. Discoursing on emptiness and purity, they drown in suffering and void; debating cinnabar, mercury, lead, and silver, they cling to what is fixed and substantial. Without understanding the transformative power of the *Ancestral Qi*, how can one fathom the subtle mysteries of the Great Brahmā?

Taking the true scripture as its foundation, this work elucidates the profound mechanism without divulging its essence. In former times, crows were mistaken for horses, leading to endless confusion; today, the butcher’s eye sees no whole ox, yet his touch knows restraint. Turning the wheel of delusion to point back toward the southern homeland, damming the raging waves to follow the downward flow—may all the people below ascend to benevolence and longevity.

With utmost reverence, I contemplate the Most High August Heavenly Honored One, the Jade Emperor, Your August Jade Majesty: majestic beyond measure, vast beyond naming, impartial and selfless, penetrating even the most hidden, ever benefiting beings with goodness, ever saving beings without abandoning a single one. Thus, You have permitted even one of such modest talent as I to dare compose this humble work. If it may contribute even a ten-thousandth part, I pray You deign to regard my earnest devotion.

If it offers not even the slightest benefit, I can but hope for pardon of my presumption.

This inner teaching, comprising one work in two scrolls, has been carved onto printing blocks and compiled. Humbly submitted to the Department of State Affairs, I beseech that it be presented for imperial consideration. With trepidation, I offer this memorial for Your August Majesty’s perusal, dreading the offense to Your celestial majesty.

I, Your servant, am awestruck and trembling, bowing my head to the ground in reverence.

Respectfully submitted.

On the seventh day of the seventh month, the first day of which was *jiayin*, in the second year of the *Baoqing* reign, cyclical year *bingxu* (17th August, 1226), Your servant Xiao Yingsou, Master of the Three Radiant Realms of the Great Cavern of Supreme Purity and the Mysterious Capital, respectfully presents this memorial.

---

**Essential Meaning of the Scripture**

The Most High is the Supreme of the Boundless, the inception of the Primordial Beginning. Prior to the existence of one’s father and mother, a single spark of true yang essence—when the two *qi* interact—gives rise to the two kidneys. Once the kidneys are formed, the two eyes emerge. Then, the five viscera gather and coalesce, shaping the countenance, and only then does the body exist. This is called *the Cavern*.

*The Cavern* refers to the fully formed physical frame, the descent into birth as a human being—here, one merely perceives the body. *The Mysterious* denotes the essence of the Mysterious Unity. Once the body exists, the essence is preserved at the *Guanyuan* (Gate of Origin). When essence is preserved at *Guanyuan*, *qi* circulates throughout; when *qi* circulates, spirit is whole. With spirit whole, the hundred apertures open, and the myriad things respond.

The eyes, permeated with light, can see all things; the nose, opened to its pores, can detect fragrances; the ears, unsealed, can hear sounds; the mouth, connected to the heart, can savor all flavors. When these four are fully developed, one becomes numinous. This is what is meant by "among the ten thousand things, humans are the most numinous."

Yet humans, though numinous, fail to awaken. The reason one may attain longevity and agelessness lies in preserving the singular numinosity, preventing its dissipation outward. Let the eyes not gaze upon forms, so that the *hun*-soul guards the liver, consolidating the wood-*qi* without leakage. Let the nose not perceive fragrances, so that the *po*-soul guards the lungs, consolidating the metal-*qi* without leakage. Let the ears not heed sounds, so that essence guards the kidneys, consolidating the water-*qi* without leakage. Let the mouth not speak, so that spirit guards the heart, consolidating the fire-*qi* without leakage. Let the entire body sit upright, the four great elements unmoving, so that intent guards the spleen, consolidating the earth-*qi* without leakage.

When the five directions are firmly rooted, spirit, *qi*, and essence merge into one, returning to the origin and reverting to the root to fulfill destiny. Then, the myriad spirits gather, transforming into an infant. Abandoning the illusory husk, one moves freely without entanglement with creation, merging with the Dao in truth—this is the treasure.

One who attains this treasure within the body moves with unrestrained freedom, drifting carefree, ever-springing and ageless, sharing the same eternal rest as Heaven. By emitting true *qi*, one can transmute earth and stone into treasures; by emitting true *qi*, one can revive withered bones into living beings; by emitting true *qi*, one can cure the ten thousand ailments, and all maladies heal of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can repel malevolent spirits, and they vanish of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can stir wind and thunder, and they resound of themselves. By emitting true *qi*, one can sustain the ten thousand things, and they flourish of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can deliver lost souls, and they are freed of themselves—this is the boundless salvation of beings.

The highest grade is the Great Vehicle’s method. *The Wondrous* is the swift path to the profound and obscure. *The Scripture* is the road to cultivating truth. If one can recite its words and inwardly grasp its mysteries, then with every thought, there will be a mysterious response. As for cultivating truth and learning the Dao, saving the living and delivering the dead—all is contained herein. Practice it in secrecy, and one may attain the Dao.

The meaning of the *Scripture of Wondrous Treasure* is vast and its principles profound; without delving deeply, seeking the hidden, and plumbing the mysterious to its subtleties, it is not easily fathomed. Yet I say otherwise. Thus, the Scripture states: "If one attains the One, all things are complete." Would the Heavenly Worthy create arduous matters to confuse people? In all daily actions and ordinary conduct, this Scripture is present.

Those who thoroughly investigate it are like the wealthy observing drinking vessels: though goblets, cups, and chalices lie scattered before them, they know them to be gold. What difficulty is there? Those who do not observe well are led astray by the vessels—how could they not be confused?

This Scripture is simply the Dao. Its wondrous discourse on profound principles, its subtle elucidation of grand names—all are but the branching of the *fan-qi* (Brahma-*qi*) and the revelation of true emptiness. When people engage with circumstances, they scatter and find it hard to enter. To clarify this Scripture, one should measure oneself against creation: that is as it is, and I am as it is. Observe carefully and contemplate deeply, and one will surely find resonance.

Not only is this true of this Scripture; the entire canon of teachings is thus. As the elder Su of Laoquan said: "That which Heaven bestows upon me—can it be by chance? What it bestows must have a use for me. If I know it but do not practice it, nor share it with others, though Heaven intends to use it, I cast it aside—this is called abandoning Heaven. To humble oneself in seeking fortune through its words, to belittle oneself in seeking to employ its Dao—how does Heaven bestow upon me, and how do I respond thus? This is called profaning Heaven."

Abandoning Heaven is my sin; profaning Heaven is also my sin. I have always taken this as a warning. Reflecting on Heaven’s grace, the polishing of teachers and friends, and my glimpse of the essence of the *Wondrous Treasure*—this, too, is Heaven bestowing upon me. Having received it, I strive to practice it, not daring to abandon Heaven. Explaining it in detail and guarding it carefully, I dare not profane Heaven. Neither abandoning nor profaning, I wander in it, rest in it, cultivate in it, and preserve it in it—this is my aspiration.

If like-minded individuals know of it and wish to share it with others, I fear profaning Heaven and decline. They then say: "Have you not heard of Li Guangxuan’s story? Long ago, Guangxuan diligently sought the Dao for many years. One day, on Shaoshi Mountain, he encountered an extraordinary person who asked him: 'In your quest for the Dao, should you not also uplift the people of the world?'"

"Should you only perfect yourself? If it is solely for one’s own person, even immortals would not accept it. Have you not heard of the foolish man of Song? Long ago, a foolish man of Song obtained a swallow stone and treasured it as a precious jewel. A visitor from Zhou heard of it and came to see it, chuckling and saying: 'This is merely a swallow stone—no different from a common tile.' The foolish man grew furious and guarded it all the more stubbornly. If your words are correct, then you are of the same class as Li Guangxuan; if your reasoning is flawed, then you tread the path of the foolish man of Song. If you share it with others, those of great wisdom may correct your errors, open your obstructions, and enlighten your understanding—not only benefiting others, but also bringing profound gain to you from Heaven. Though I am dull of wit, I respectfully heed these words. Thus, I have selected the commentaries of Yan, Xue, Cheng, and Li, extracting their clearest explanations, and appended the teachings of my teachers and friends beneath each line—these are the small characters in the main scroll, to clarify the meaning of the scripture. As for the principle being revealed through the image and the image being illuminated by the principle, the essence of the scripture and the cinnabar Dao being one and without distinction, I have appended the explanations of the images and recorded them afterward. Though my gaze is but a pipe’s view of the sky and my measure a gourd’s dip of the sea, and I have not plumbed even the tiniest fraction, this is the extent of my capacity. Alas!"

Confucius said: "Those who understand me do so through the *Spring and Autumn Annals*; those who condemn me do so through the *Spring and Autumn Annals*."

In the second year of the Baoqing reign, cyclical year *bingxu*, on the first day of the seventh month, the *jiayin* day, recorded by Xiaoying the Daoist of Guanfu.

**Chart of the Wondrous Transformations of the Supreme Ultimate and the Numinous Chaos of the Vermilion Writ of Hun Dun**

The Vermilion Writ of *Hun Dun*—the Non-Ultimate’s Supreme Perfection—is what is called "the Non-Ultimate and yet the Supreme Ultimate." At the primordial beginning of the ancestral kalpa, it gave birth to the myriad heavens, unfolding the Three Luminaries, thus becoming the root of Heaven. With no ancestor beyond itself, its body is the Dao alone—this is what is meant by "the Supreme Ultimate moves and generates yang." When movement reaches its limit, it becomes still; stillness generates yin; when stillness reaches its limit, it moves again. One movement, one stillness, each the root of the other. Yin and yang divide, and the Two Modes are established.

The Five Scripts unfold and expand—this is what is meant by "yang transforms, yin conjoins, and water, fire, wood, metal, and earth are born." The five *qi* flow in sequence, and the four seasons proceed. The Five Phases are one yin-yang; yin-yang is one Supreme Ultimate. The Supreme Ultimate is fundamentally the Non-Ultimate. The generation of the Five Phases, each with its own nature.

Universally planting the numinous, without script there is no illumination, no clarity, no establishment, no completion, no deliverance, no generation. This is what is meant by "the true of the Non-Ultimate, the essence of the Two and Five, wondrously conjoined and congealed." The Way of Qian forms the male; the Way of Kun forms the female. The two *qi* interact and transform, giving birth to the myriad things. The myriad things, endlessly generating and transforming, are inexhaustible.

The scholar must investigate its words and seek its meaning, then the Way of Prior Heaven will unconsciously align, and the wondrous workings of creation may be glimpsed. Thus, the Confucian, knowing the causes of the hidden and the manifest, encompasses the myriad things, traces beginnings to return to endings, exhausts principle and fulfills nature, and attains the wondrous mystery beyond life and death. Laozi, however, says: "Deeply root, firmly stem, for long life and enduring vision." Each has its own tradition.

If this is so, how then is it to be achieved?

The Scripture states: "Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine, and return to the state of the infant. Know the white, yet guard the black, and return to the boundless." This is the Way of the Golden Elixir and Returning Cinnabar, by which one may deeply root and firmly stem, attaining long life and enduring vision.

**Diagram of the Body’s Symbolism of Yin-Yang Ascending and Descending**
*Analogy:*
This body is the furnace and stove of Heaven and Earth; the Central Palace is the crucible, while the space beyond the body is the Great Void. The Qian Palace is the Sea of Marrow; the Kun Palace is the Chamber of Essence; the Chamber of Spirit and the Cinnabar Crucible are called the Three Palaces. Qian and Kun are the warp and woof of Heaven and Earth. Yin and yang circulate within them. Heaven and Earth are the great forge; yin and yang are the mechanism of transformation; the single *qi* is the medicinal substance.

In refining the elixir, one relies on the *qi* of Qian and Kun, the male and female, nurturing them through the cyclical stars to form the crucible. The Golden Mother resides within, employing the wondrous generative *qi* to interact and stimulate, a process called cultivation and refinement. When yang essence blazes daily and the true spirit transforms and generates, it is called the Sacred Embryo. When yin is shed and yang is pure, it is called the Infant. This is what is meant by the Great One containing the true, harmonizing with the void, and returning to the boundless.

The locus of the Spirit Chamber and the mechanism of nurturing must not be lightly disclosed, for oaths and pacts govern their transmission. The teacher must clearly instruct to avoid misleading the aspirant into the depths of delusion.

**The Eight Rings of the Diagram:**
1. The first ring, with the Eight Trigrams, represents Earth. The Eight Trigrams form images and interact.
2. The second ring, with the twenty-eight constellations, represents Heaven. It clarifies the great reckoning of the celestial cycles, beginning with the Celestial Origin.
3. The third ring, with thirty waxings and wanings, represents the fire phases of a month, corresponding to the sixty hexagrams and their interactions.
4. The fourth ring, with one hundred white and black dots, represents the yin tally and yang fire of the water clock, corresponding to the celestial tally’s movement and stillness.
5. The fifth ring, with twelve hexagrams, represents the advancing and retreating of the lines, the rising and falling of the Dragon and Tiger.
6. The sixth ring, with the twelve earthly branches, represents the fire phases’ ascent and descent, gathering the celestial tally.
7. The seventh ring reveals the great reckoning of the celestial cycle, resonating with the four seasons and five phases, corresponding to the inner symbolism.
8. The eighth ring arranges the myriad images of yin, yang, and the five phases into the crucible, assisting the Gold Fire and Dragon Tiger, the Li Woman and Kan Man, the yin and yang spouses. Through their union, true cinnabar and true mercury are generated, forming the divine elixir.

The above is the *Diagram of Fire Phases in the Great Return’s Heart-Mirror* by Zhenyizi Peng Xiao, adopted to elucidate the use of the Great Brahma’s esoteric language.

**Recitation of Scriptures and Precepts**
There are the Five Precepts and the Ten Useless Matters. The method of reciting scriptures must be understood: purify oneself with fasting and bathing, cast aside worldly concerns, and align inner and outer to do good.

I have witnessed the method of scripture recitation by the Supreme Pole’s Immortal Ge, which includes the Five Precepts and the Ten Useless Matters. The noble seeker of goodness who adheres to these words will gain boundless benefits—far beyond merely ascending and transcending oneself, for blessings will flow to descendants as well.

**The Five Precepts:**
1. Do not recite with the mouth while the heart resists.
2. Do not treat the words and principles with disdain.
3. Do not conceive of oneself as a living person.
4. Be humble and defer to the teacher’s guidance.
5. Practice compassion and guidance, mutually enlightening one another.

**The Ten Useless Matters:**
1. Disloyalty to the sovereign.
2. Lack of filial piety toward parents.
3. Lack of kindness toward all beings.
4. Clinging to ignorance and comparing self and others.
5. Envying the worthy and resenting those superior to oneself.
6. Slandering the good and humiliating the orphaned and poor.
7. Engaging in malicious speech and double-tongued gossip.
8. Deceiving the heart and harming beings.
9. Indulging in wine and meat, and favoring depravity.
10. Giving rise to greed, anger, hatred, and attachment.

If one can adhere to these, what disaster will not be averted, what sin will not be dissolved? The names will be recorded in the heavens, and demon kings will vouch for one. Otherwise, even a lifetime of recitation will not bring the desired blessings and wisdom.

The noble and enlightened should take heed and be cautious.

**Method of Recitation (for Daoists and laypersons, men and women alike):**
Purify the fast within, free from distracting thoughts, and abstain from rich foods and meat externally. Enter the *jing*—a purified chamber. Don the ritual attire (a robe or jacket will suffice, as long as it is clean).

Tap the teeth to align the central incisors, sounding the Dharma Drum to gather the body’s spirits. Burn incense—abundant and fragrant—to convey sincerity.

Bow to the four directions (east, south, west, north), then to the four corners (northeast, southeast, southwest, northwest), and finally to the above and below, one bow each. After bowing, sit facing east. The bowing to the ten directions relates to the scripture’s content. A bow of the heart surpasses a bow of the body. Facing east follows the order of ascending to heaven, from east to west. Sit upright—whether cross-legged or with feet hanging, there is no strict rule.

Next, tap the teeth, recite the *Heart-Mouth Purification Mantra* and the *Body Purification Mantra* to adorn the body’s spirits. Then tap the teeth and recite the *Heaven-Earth Purification Mantra* and the *Scripture’s Mysterious Essence Mantra*. After reciting these mantras, open the scroll and begin the scripture recitation. The remaining precepts and details are fully annotated below.

**The Inner Meaning of the Supreme Scripture of Limitless Salvation, First Scroll**
*Observations by Guanfuzi Xiao Yingsou:*
According to the *Numinous Treasure Great Method*, the *Scripture of Salvation* encompasses seven matters, broadly outlined as follows:
- The Primordial *Qi* of the Origin, before formlessness—how can it be compared?
- Descending to form *qi*, transforming and generating the myriad treasures—what is its present manifestation?
- Refining this *qi* into treasure and ingesting it to ascend as a perfected being.

I observe that the former perfected and supreme sages revealed this single principle as the supreme mechanism of life and death, the great essential of nature and destiny. Without the Way of the Golden Elixir and Returning Cinnabar, how could the mystery of the Primordial *Qi* of the Origin be illuminated? Exhaustively probing the subtle and profound, pursuing the abstruse and wondrous, dredging forth divine grace to irrigate the field of immortality—such is the intent.

**The Supreme Scripture of Limitless Salvation from the Numinous Treasure of the Supreme Mystery**
This scripture is revered by the myriad sages and venerated by all perfected beings. It is supreme beyond all, mysterious beyond the mysterious.

Moreover, *Dongxuan Lingbao* ("Cavern Mystery Numinous Treasure") is the general designation of its ranks and grades, while *Wu Liang Du Ren* ("Limitless Salvation of Humankind") is the title of this particular scroll. Revered as the source of all scriptures, it is thus called the "Supreme Grade"; through it the Dao is illuminated, hence it is termed the "Wondrous Scripture."

Our dynasty’s True Sovereign, Emperor Zhenzong, composed a preface stating: *The Great Change* imparts its teachings, originating in the utmost numinous; *Hunyuan* ("Primal Origin") sets forth its writings, rooted in the wondrous Dao. It accords with the unfathomable of yin and yang, and marks the indescribable of profound silence. For it expounds the action of non-action, manifests the form of the formless, encompasses the hidden and assists the subtle, concealing its function while revealing its benevolence. Vast and obscure, it transforms the people and nurtures all things. Though its systems differ across past and present, its instruction and guidance converge as one.

As for the sacred texts stored in the hidden chambers, the secret records on the luminous terrace, the jade-bound scrolls in profusion, the cinnabar-sealed cases in abundance—these were transmitted down from the loftiest perfected beings through the walled cities of the turtle-gate, flowing through the kalpas of Red Brightness and Dragon Han in accord with the cycles of fate. Such truths transcend what sight and hearing can perceive, existing beyond the realm of names and words. They assist in perfecting the utmost governance and gradually permeate all beings.

First emerging among the nine schools, standing firm through the ages, even amid the tumult of war and strife, who would find time to employ them? Yet in times when "the insects and fish are all at peace," who would deem them dispensable?

The *Scripture of Salvation* is the wondrous utterance of the Primordial Beginning, the precious proclamation of the Jade Dawn. In the Floating Black Realm, it records the initial transmission; in the Purple Tenuity Upper Palace, it reveals the traces of its concealed treasures. It is the hidden rhyme of all heavens, the immortal hymn of the Great Brahmā. Its eight-cornered radiance descends from divine brushstrokes; its thousand *qi*-guardians array in defense, universally delivering the numinous essence of humankind.

Those who nurture their essence in roundness and squareness, who receive harmony between heaven and earth, who diminish selfishness and desire, who turn from falsity to return to truth, who purify their thoughts through solemn fasting and cleanse their hearts through recitation—when their focus accumulates externally and purity fills them internally, they may obscure themselves to become luminous, illuminating all that is hidden. Like a vacant chamber generating brightness, like a warm spring dispelling evil, they ascend the springtime terrace in joy, mounting the realm of longevity in solemnity. Where utmost sincerity reaches, what bound is there to the blessings bestowed?

How magnificent! As for the *Lingbao* ("Numinous Treasure"), some say *ling* ("numinous") is the transformation of the sagely, and *bao* ("treasure") is what is cherished and esteemed. Others say *ling* is the general term for all sages, and *bao* is what all sages treasure. Still others say *ling* denotes boundless transformation, while *bao* denotes reverence and precious love. Some say *ling* is in heaven, and *bao* is on earth. Others say the divine descends as *ling*, and *qi* gathers as *bao*.

As it is said: "The benevolent see it and call it spirit; the wise see it and call it wisdom. The common people use it daily yet do not know it." Thus, we forcibly give it form to respond to transformation, establish teachings, govern things, and benefit life.

*Qi* refined to utmost subtlety becomes formless; vastness reaches the point of being unencompassable. Taking examples from afar or near—from things or from the self—it is great as heaven and earth, minute yet not departing from the tiniest detail. Manifest, it is the sun and moon; hidden, it is yin and yang. In Confucianism, it is benevolence and righteousness; in Buddhism, it is wisdom and knowledge. In humans, it is spirit and *qi*; in the elixir, it is mercury and lead. It lodges in the nature and emotions of the myriad things, unites the primordial *qi* as creation—yet in truth, it is all the Dao.

Only those who comprehend can unify it. Yet those who cling to illusion and lose sight of reality, who follow their emotions and chase after things, cause the numinous source to rupture and the wondrous root to scatter. They cannot return to youth and recover from decay.

Thus, the *Chapter on Generating Spirit* states: "When a person attains rebirth in the human realm, bathing their form in the Great Yang, it shakes heaven and earth—such honor is hard to surpass. Heavenly perfected and earthly spirits, the three realms all attend, for it is not lightly bestowed. At the time of birth, one is not deemed base. Yet people, having received life, fail to honor their *qi*, treasure their form, cherish their life, or love their spirit. They bring about their own decay and death, departing from their original truth."

The *Scripture of Western Ascension* says: "Life births me in emptiness, places me in nothingness. What gives me life is spirit; what kills me is the heart. Accumulated *qi* and gathered blood form my body. The body is the chariot of spirit, the abode of spirit, the master of spirit. When tranquil, spirit resides within; when restless, spirit departs."

The *Scripture of the Yellow Court* says: "For long life, be most cautious in the chamber of intimacy—why invite death and make the spirit weep? The inch-field and foot-dwelling can cultivate life; if you breach the sea, the hundred streams will pour out. Leaves fall, the tree withers, losing its verdancy; *qi* perishes, fluids leak—this is no longer one’s true form."

*Zhuangzi* said: "Our life has limits, but knowledge has none. To pursue the limitless with the limited is perilous." He also said: "Human life is the gathering of *qi*. When it gathers, there is life; when it scatters, there is death. If the form labors without rest, it wears out; if essence is used without cease, it exhausts. Exhaustion leads to depletion."

The Grand Historian said: "What gives life to humans is spirit; what it relies upon is form. If spirit is overused, it depletes; if form is overworked, it wears out. When form and spirit separate, death comes. The dead cannot be revived; the departed cannot return. Thus, the sage values them highly."

Carefully observing these words, all point to returning to the root and restoring the source. Therefore, the natural *Lingbao* Dao and the principle of the Great Return of Golden Fluid have been admired by those who comprehend, and such people have never been lacking through the ages.

The Supreme Lord revealed the method of guidance and proclaimed to humankind: "Constantly abide in desirelessness to observe its mystery; constantly abide in desire to observe its subtlety." The Buddhist tradition also says: "People are turned by things; if one can turn things, one is the same as the Tathāgata."

Thus, the Daoist and Buddhist teachings each possess principles for transcending life and death. Buddhism takes nature as its foundation, hence it cultivates meditation and stillness. Daoism takes spirit as its master, hence it refines the golden elixir. The utmost of meditation and stillness is quiescence in yin; the utmost of the golden elixir is return to yang. These two emerge from the same source but differ in application. Both achieve true perfection from the root of what gives life, not through reliance on external things or artificial creation.

The spirit and nature may be grasped intuitively but cannot be dissected by reason. To dissect them is to invite confusion and dispute, creating divisions between self and other; to grasp them intuitively is to harmonize differences, erasing distinctions between this and that. This is the wondrous Dao of the supreme and perfect truth—thus, the myriad methods and thousand gates are none other than the numinous treasure.

The *True Record of the Primordial Unity* states: Since the Dragon Han era, Lord Lao has divided his body to teach and transform, revealing true scriptures in the Central Heaven Great Blessing Hall Kingdom, the Southern Culmen Vermilion Brightness Kingdom, the Eastern Culmen Floating Black Kingdom, the Western Culmen Western Na Kingdom, and the Northern Culmen Yü-tan Kingdom—within these five, all received the teachings of the Numinous Treasure. Moreover, during the Xia dynasty, he bestowed upon Yu the Five Talismans of the Numinous Treasure and the True Scriptures of the Numinous Treasure. He also transformed to address the Hu king, saying: "In the Central Lands, I constantly employ the Daoist methods to enlighten the people of the world." The king asked: "What are the Daoist methods?" Lord Lao replied: "The Daoist methods are none other than the Supreme Numinous Treasure, born before heaven and earth, vast enough to embrace all, subtle enough to contain all. Without it, heaven could not shine; without it, earth could not manifest form."

Without this, spirits cannot enter the hidden; without this, humans cannot be born or completed—thus the teeming ten thousand things take the Dao as their root. The serpent that attains it becomes a dragon; the bird that attains it becomes a phoenix; the beast that attains it becomes a qilin; the ordinary person who attains it becomes an immortal. Those who cultivate it roam the Great Void, transform their five viscera, alter their form and appearance, command ghosts and spirits, and appear or vanish at will—this is the Way of the Upper Immortals.

The king said: "What you speak of as the Numinous Treasure is indeed rare. From this, it seems that what is called ‘attaining’ and ‘cultivating’ it—what is it, in the end?" Thereupon it was known that the Numinous Treasure and the Golden Elixir emerge from the same source but bear different names.

The *Scriptures of the Numinous Treasure* were bestowed by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign upon the Yellow Emperor at Mount Emei. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign also transmitted them to Emperor Ku at the Terrace of Pastoral Virtue. Xia Yu received them in full at Mount Zhong, while Helü of Wu secretly glimpsed them at Mount Gouqu. Later, figures such as Ge Xiaoxian and Zheng Siyuan, master and disciple, passed them down in an unbroken lineage—this is how the scriptural teachings emerged.

The Dao says: The words of the Supreme Jade Dawn Dao Lord are the words of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy. Formerly, he received the scriptures from the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Void Sovereign, compiled them into volumes, and concealed them in the Purple Tenuity Palace of the Mysterious Capital. The Dao Lord transmitted them to the Perfected of the Mysterious Unity, whence they spread.

In the past, within the Primordial Azure Heaven—
The Eastern Nine Qi form the Azure Heaven.
"Primordial" is the name of the inception of the Five Directions;
"Azure" is the color of the East.
The Azure Empyrean resounds with celestial song in the Great Floating Li Land—
This heaven’s qi is azure and emerald, its radiance vast and boundless, hence called the Azure Empyrean.
The numinous wind and jade trees strike celestial melodies in the void, hence called "celestial song."
The Great Floating Li Land is the kingdom of the Eastern Culmen’s Great Floating Li.
There, the Dao Lord received the *Primordial Beginning’s Scripture on the Salvation of Innumerable Beings of the Supreme Grade*.

The Dao Lord said: "In that heaven and that land, I formerly received the wondrous scriptures of the Void Sovereign Heavenly Worthy, widely delivering humans and gods. The merit is beyond reckoning—this is the true essence of the Supreme Grade."

The *Inner Meaning* states: Of heaven and earth’s vastness and the tiniest of creatures, all things bound by form and subject to number are born and completed by embodying the workings of creation. The Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy’s opening of the scriptures—"In the Primordial Azure Heaven, the Azure Empyrean resounds with celestial song in the Great Floating Li Land"—reveals the inception of creation.

Things are born from earth and return to earth, thus the *Scripture of the Hidden Correspondences* says: "Fire is born from wood; when calamity erupts, it must be subdued." Those who know this and refine it are called sages.

Within wood lies fire; if unleashed without restraint, it reduces all to flying ash and vanishing smoke, leaving no trace of its original nature. Those who restrain it, though fire scorches wood to cinders, gather it into earth—once it becomes earth, its original nature is preserved.

The Primordial Azure Heaven is the sprouting of grain;
The Azure Empyrean’s celestial song is the symbol of fire.
The Eastern Culmen’s Great Floating Li Land is all of azure jade, ever generating azure radiance. There are also the verdant forests, whose trees, stirred by wind, produce sounds like cavernous hymns, resplendent and luminous throughout the Great Void.

The Floating Li Kingdom belongs to the Jade Prosperity Heaven of the Northeast. The Northeast is the *yin* position, the land where fire is born. The wind-stirred verdant forests—verdant is the color of wood, and "forest" is two trees. Guan Yin said: "When two woods rub, fire is born." Trees are also wood. Wood and wind are *xun*. The Daoist in Hemp Robes said: "Earth two generates fire," for the qi of *li* is conceived within *xun* wood. The resplendence and luminosity throughout the Great Void are the symbol of fire’s brilliance. The azure radiance’s vastness and boundlessness resemble the void’s sound in their emptiness and clarity—hence "Azure Empyrean celestial song." The Great Floating Li Land is the root of earth. Earth is the foundation of the Returned Elixir. The Returned Elixir is the Way of returning to the origin.

The scripture says: "Attain utmost emptiness, guard deep stillness; as the ten thousand things arise together, I observe their return." The teeming things each return to their root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called the restoration of life—this is the principle of returning. The *Book of Changes*’ *Fu* hexagram embodies this. *Fu* is the Way of yin and yang’s return. Thus it is said: "*Fu* reveals the heart of heaven and earth." Heaven and earth are the body of yin and yang; "heart" clarifies their function. Heaven moves and earth is still; yang moves and yin is still. When heaven’s movement reaches its limit, yin is born; when earth’s stillness reaches its limit, yang is born. This is the stripping away above and the returning below—movement and stillness wax and wane, thus revealing their heart. Humans are the same.

In the *Fu* hexagram, one yang lies beneath five yins, its body *zhen* below and *kun* above. *Zhen* is wood—the Primordial Azure Heaven. Wood generates fire—the Azure Empyrean’s celestial song. Fire generates earth—thus *kun* earth is the Great Floating Li Land.

The Azure Empyrean’s celestial song, in terms of the scriptures, is qi and sound, emerging from nonbeing into being. In terms of the Elixir, *zhen* wood and *kun* earth each have their solid substance, yet within their emptiness appears the symbol of fire. From this, one may clearly understand the scriptural purport and the natural alignment of the Elixir Way with the workings of creation.

Earth is the root of creation, thus earth generates metal, called "void qi." The Metal Embryo is truly the primordial ancestral qi, hence it is said: "Received the *Primordial Beginning’s Scripture on the Salvation of Innumerable Beings of the Supreme Grade*." "Primordial Beginning" is the ancestral qi—the indestructible primordial spirit from past kalpas, called True Lead, which serves as the mother of the Elixir.

The *Scripture of the Dragon and Tiger* says: "Metal and fire are True Lead." In the art of the Elixir, nothing is more essential than metal and fire. The Perfected Zhang Ziyang’s *Awakening to Reality* states:
"Fire is born from wood, wood conceals its edge;
Without skill in drilling and grinding, do not force it.
Calamity erupts only because it harms oneself—
One must seek to subdue it and find the Metal Duke."

It also says:
"If *li* and *kan* lack *wu* and *ji*,
Though they contain the Four Images, no Elixir is formed."

All this arises from the mutual embrace of True Earth between them, thus enabling the Golden Elixir to return and revert. From this, the Dao of the Elixir may be clearly discerned, and its fruition truly witnessed.

The Chan master of Zhaozhou said:
"A golden Buddha cannot pass through the furnace,
A wooden Buddha cannot pass through fire,
A clay Buddha cannot pass through water—
How then may *I* be delivered?
If you would deliver *me*,
None but *I* can deliver *me*."

Thus this Dao is the return of my spirit, the restoration of my nature, and the deliverance of my body. Each delivers oneself—none remains undelivered. Without limit or number, this is the Supreme Vehicle. Hence it is called *the Supreme Grade Scripture on the Salvation of Innumerable Beings*.

The *Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning*—this is the responsive title of the *Vacuous Sovereign*, arising from the True and manifesting in the phenomenal, termed *realization through cultivation*. The subtle contemplation of the profound source is the unique possession of one’s own nature. The *Scripture of Cavernous Spirit* states: "The wondrous image is formless; responsive resonance takes bodily form."

When this scripture is expounded—
*Scripture* means *path*: it is by this that one may proceed to attain the Dao.

The *Inner Meaning* says: "The *Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning* is the ancestral qi of the Dharmakāya—the so-called *original face*, the indestructible primordial spirit, termed *True Lead*." When this scripture is expounded, it clarifies that ancestral qi is the essence of the Elixir.

Lord Lao told Master Yin: "If you can know the One, all things are complete. Seal off passions and desires, enter the inner chamber, refine metal and ingest qi—this is foremost. If you can know this, guard it and do not lose it."

He also said:
"Red Lead and Black Tin are the great heads of the Elixir;
Entering the Black from the Red is true cultivation.
Extract essence from the Black, marrow from the Red—
If you can resolve the Red and Black, the medicine is peerless.
Using the Red to enter the Black ensures longevity;
Using the Black to enter the Red ascends to celestial immortality."

He further said:
"One is Lead, and Lead is the sovereign;
Two is Mercury, and Mercury is the minister.
If Lead is not true, Mercury will not draw near;
If Lead is true, the household minister is not lost.
The Green-Waisted Envoy, the Red-Blooded General—
Harmonizing the two clans, distinct yet united in fellowship.
White Mercury becomes the brain, Yellow Sprout the root.
Transform Lead into powder, refine Mercury into dust.
Yin resides in the position of Yang, Yang’s number and Yin’s are balanced.
The moon waxes as the sun wanes; cold and heat are distinct.
The symbolic configurations are established, resplendent in pattern.
Only this Dao of mine endures with Heaven and Earth."

The principle of expounding this scripture is thus made manifest.

Someone may ask: "In this scripture, only cultivation, recitation, salvation of the living, and deliverance of the dead are mentioned—where are the principles of Dragon and Tiger, Kan and Li, cinnabar, mercury, lead, and silver?"

The answer: "The Great Dao is without fixed form; it lodges in things to reveal its principles. Consider the *Book of Changes*: it begins with the primordial qi, divides into Yin and Yang, whose interplay of hardness and softness generates endless transformations. Fu Xi drew its hexagrams to illuminate the Dao; Shen Nong modeled tools upon it. Yao used it to face south as sovereign; Shun practiced it facing north as minister. King Wen unfolded it to exhaust the wonders of creation; Confucius expanded it to plumb the depths of Heaven and Earth. Laozi borrowed it to expound the aims of the Elixir; Master Mayi employed it to speak of the mechanisms of transformation. Chen Tuan distinguished its images and numbers; Lü Dongbin discoursed on nature and destiny; Shao Yong investigated the Prior Heaven; Zhou Dunyi and Zhang Zai established the Supreme Ultimate. Some explored the principles of things, others deduced divination—its round mechanism encompasses ten thousand transformations, never confined to one aspect. How is the Dao of this scripture different?"

As the saying goes: "One who knows ritual but not the spirit is no adept of long life." Transcending principle to enter the spirit, merging with qi, acting without acting yet accomplishing all—this is the true teaching of my tradition.

Thus Master Yin said: "Those who are skilled in my Dao, within a single thing, know Heaven and exhaust the spirit, attaining the mysterious and reaching the ultimate destiny. Those who lose it chase after differences, splitting names while the reality remains the same; those who attain it harmonize in sameness, though intentions and names may differ."

Circulating ten times to summon the ten directions—
The *Inner Meaning* says: "Expounding the scripture ten times in a cycle summons the true sages and lofty worthies of Heaven and Earth. Refining the Elixir for ten months to completion is the work of circulating the essence and quintessence of Yin and Yang."

Thus circulating ten times comprises the generating number five and the completing number five. Heaven One is Water, Earth Two is Fire, Heaven Three is Wood, Earth Four is Metal, Heaven Five is Earth. Earth Six is Lead, Heaven Seven is Mercury, Earth Eight is Cinnabar, Heaven Nine is Silver, Earth Ten is the Elixir. Summoning the ten directions comprises the odd numbers—One, Three, Five, Seven, Nine—Yang; and the even numbers—Two, Four, Six, Eight, Ten—Yin. This is the wondrous function of the Returned Elixir; as for the subtle workings of creation, they are detailed below.

At the commencement of the assembly,
The *Vacuous Sovereign Celestial Worthy* ascends to the seat.
The celestial perfected, supreme sages, and lofty worthies,
The wondrously practicing immortals, and the innumerable hosts—
These are the five hundred million heavens,
The eight spherical worlds,
The Three Origins and Nine Saints,
The Nine Perfected and Nine Immortals,
The sun, moon, and stars,
The celestial and terrestrial spirits—
Arrive riding the void,
Flying upon cinnabar clouds in the rosy dawn,
Amidst the clouds of the Three Primes and the crimson mists.
Green carriages and jade wheels,
Feathered canopies casting shade.
When the Queen Mother of the West transmitted the scripture to Emperor Wu of Han, all the vessels, texts, and regalia followed Han dynasty conventions. Observing the present, one knows the past—thus no further details are given.
Radiant jade light streams forth,
Five colors billowing in profusion,
Illuminating the vastness of the Great Void.

The streaming essence is the radiance of the sun, moon, and stars; the jade light is the perfect image of the immortals and perfected beings. The five colors interweave, illuminating the Great Void.

*The Inner Meaning* states: When one first approaches the seat, it is the Metal Mother entering the chamber. When the Metal Mother is in the chamber, she summons the Two Non-Beings to the Yellow Path and gathers the Three Natures in the Primordial Palace. The Five Phases cluster together, the Four Symbols harmonize—this is called the arrival of the Heavenly Perfected Great Spirits, the Lofty and Exalted Sages, the Wondrous-Practicing Perfected Ones, and the innumerable hosts, riding the void.

With spirit directing qi, with qi refining spirit, lead and mercury merge, yin and yang rush forth in harmony. The Metal Mother radiates her splendor in the spirit-chamber, the silver essence emits its brilliance in the cinnabar chamber. The empty chamber generates whiteness, the spirit-abode attains great tranquility—thus the flying cinnabar clouds, the green carriages and jade wheels, the feathered canopies casting shade, the streaming essence and jade light, the five colors billowing in profusion, illuminating the vastness of the Great Void.

For seven days and seven nights, the sun, moon, and stars of all heavens, the jade pivot and jade balance, halt their wheels at once. The divine wind falls silent, mountains and seas conceal their clouds. The heavens are free of drifting veils; the four qi shine clearly. Throughout the land, mountains, rivers, forests, and trees stretch level as one, no longer distinguished by high or low.

When speaking of "all heavens," it refers to the thirty-two heavens. Within each heaven, there are sun and moon. Their essence and light, originally transformed, all take root in this realm. The "jade pivot and jade balance" are the seven stars of the Northern Dipper. The "four qi shining clearly" are the qi of heaven, earth, sun, and moon.

For the true transmit the true, the sages instruct the sages; thus the Three Luminaries cease their turning, mountains and seas gather qi, the Wind Earl dares not rustle the branches, the Cloud Marshal buries all shadows. Heaven and earth open in clarity, sun and moon shine purely, mountains and rivers lie level, all distinctions dissolved. Since it is said their wheels halt, how could there be night? Measured by ordinary time, this is the span of seven days and seven nights.

The Mystic Master says: This is the Great Stillness, where the divine light is profoundly serene, revealing the Jade Clarity Realm.

*The Inner Meaning* states: *The Great Commentary on the Book of Changes* says: "Hard and soft are the images of day and night." Some explain that day is yang-hard, night is yin-soft. Master Yichuan says: "Hard and soft are the coming and going of one qi." In humans, the coming and going of qi is breath. One exhalation and one inhalation make a single breath; within each breath, yin and yang divide. Exhaling and brightening is yang and day; inhaling and darkening is yin and night. The seven orifices’ exhalation is the seven days; their inhalation is the seven nights. Through the Metal Mother’s merit and practice, the celestial mechanism does not move; spirit congeals, eyes fix, pulses cease, the heart stills—thus it is said that for seven days and seven nights, the sun, moon, and stars of all heavens, the jade pivot and jade balance, halt their wheels at once. The "divine wind falling silent" means breath does not enter or exit. The "mountains and seas concealing their clouds" means qi does not rise or fall. The "heavens free of drifting veils" means delusive thoughts and false conditions do not arise. The "four qi shining clearly" means movement and stillness, being and non-being are all transcended. To the point of forgetting form and cutting off thought, the myriad existences all empty, with no self and no other, profoundly embodying one’s nature—thus it is said that throughout the land, mountains, rivers, forests, and trees stretch level as one, no longer distinguished by high or low. The earth all turns to azure jade, without any other color. The former were celestial omens; these are terrestrial responses.

*The Inner Meaning* states: "Earth" is the purity of nature. When nature is empty and transforms, it generates spirit; stored within the chamber, it is called "wu-earth." When qi is stirred and moved to feeling, gathered within the cauldron, it is called "ji-earth." When spirit is joyful and qi is still, nature returns to the darkness of feeling—like color’s azure without flaw, like jade’s purity without admixture—thus it is said the land all turns to azure jade, without any other color.

The assembled perfected ones attend the seat.

*The Inner Meaning* states: When intention is undivided, it congeals in spirit. The Primordial Heavenly Worthy’s mysterious seat floats in emptiness above five-colored lions—this is the Dao-form of the Heavenly Worthy.

*The Inner Meaning* states: The "Primordial Heavenly Worthy" is the primordial spirit. The "mysterious seat" is the spirit-chamber. "Floating in emptiness" is the Dharma-body. The "five colors" are the qi of wondrous transformation. The "lions" are the knowing heart. When the primordial spirit is in the chamber, directing the heart to gather qi, the Dharma-body is empty and still, the knowing heart is luminous and wondrous—spirit commands qi, the heart takes form as a lion. Is this not the Dao-form of the Heavenly Worthy?

After expounding the scripture once, all the heavenly great sages simultaneously praise its excellence. At that time, the deaf and ailing men and women of the land all regain their hearing.

*The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture once" is Heaven One generating water, the qi of Kan nurtured within Qian-metal. The "heavenly great sages simultaneously praising its excellence" is the myriad spirits all rejoicing at once. The "men and women of the land" are the yin and yang qi of the Dharma-body. "Deafness and ailment" belong to Kan, which governs the ears. When human spirit and qi nourish each other, if spirit is dull, qi stagnates; if qi is chaotic, spirit is turbid—dim and obscure, like deafness. When practice flows smoothly, qi is still and spirit is clear, awakening what was unawakened—thus it is called "regaining hearing." This is the initial step in entering the Dao. As for bodily illnesses, when one encounters scripture and method and is cured, it need not be explained.

After expounding the scripture a second time, the blind regain their sight.

*The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a second time" is Earth Two generating fire, the qi of Li nurtured within Xun-wood. Li governs the eyes, which correspond to the heart. When the heart is deluded by things, it darkens as if blind. Following the Dao, the heart opens and intention awakens—nothing can obscure it. Right and wrong become clear, like eyes seeing the path ahead.

After expounding the scripture a third time, the mute can speak.

*The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a third time" is Heaven Three generating wood, the qi of Zhen nurtured within Gen-water.

Gen corresponds to the mountain, where the peaks are high and the earth deep, and springs emerge from within. This is the doctrine of hemp and ashes. Speech is sound, which pertains to the nature of metal. Heaven Three generates wood, and after expounding the scripture a third time, why is it said that the mute can speak? This reveals the image of metal within wood. Wood is severed at *shen* and conceived at *you*; though metal overcomes wood, wood paradoxically lodges its embryo in the realm of metal. For metal generates water, and water generates wood—thus metal is the ancestor of wood. Heaven Three generates wood, and the third transmission of metal gives rise to wood, as in *jiazi* and *yichou* (Sea Middle Metal). Metal resides in the sea, and water generates *zi* and *chou*; water generates wood, which is *jia* and *yi*. Yang arises at *zi*, and the three yangs ascend from earth. Thus *Zhuangzi* states: "Brilliant brilliance emerges from earth." Rising from below, the upper trigram *zhen* transforms into *dui*, illuminating the presence of metal within wood.

After expounding the scripture a fourth time, those afflicted with lameness, chronic ailments, or hereditary infirmities can all rise and walk. "Hereditary infirmities" refer to illnesses passed down through generations. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a fourth time" is Earth Four generating metal, the qi of *dui* nurtured within *kun*-earth. "Rising and walking" describes the act of standing upright, which pertains to the nature of wood. Earth Four generates metal, and after expounding the scripture a fourth time, why is it said that those with lameness, chronic ailments, or hereditary infirmities can all rise and walk? This reveals the image of wood within metal. Metal is severed at *yin* and conceived at *mao*; metal is the ghost of wood, yet it lodges its embryo in the realm of wood. For wood generates fire, fire generates earth, and earth generates metal—thus wood is the origin of metal. Earth Four generates metal, and the fourth transmission of wood gives rise to metal, as in *jiawu* and *yiwei* (Sand Middle Metal). *Jia* and *yi* are wood, generating fire; *wu* and *wei* are fire, generating earth; sand and stone are earth, generating metal. Yin arises at *wu*, and the three yins descend from heaven. Thus *Zhuangzi* states: "Solemn solemnity emerges from heaven." Descending from above, the trigram *dui* transforms into *zhen*, illuminating the presence of wood within metal. From this, the principle of alternation between metal and wood becomes evident. Yet the workings of creation are subtle and profound, far beyond what can be fully grasped through mere study on paper.

After expounding the scripture a fifth time, long-standing chronic illnesses are restored to wholeness in an instant. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a fifth time" is Heaven Five generating earth, the qi of *li* lodging in *wu*, with earth-qi nurtured within *li*. All things arise from earth and return to earth, as above—this is the generative number of the Five Phases. Regarding "long-standing chronic illnesses," the *Daoist Canon* states: "Humans are the most spiritually endowed of beings. Their natural lifespan is over forty-three thousand two hundred days, and their spirit consists of thirty-six thousand primordial yang qi. Their original weight is three hundred eighty-four *zhu*, corresponding internally to *qian*. If one does not know how to preserve it and instead dissipates it, one will meet an untimely end midway. *Qian* embodies six yangs yet remains inactive and undispersed; those who understand this and cultivate it become immortals. From fifteen to twenty-five years of age, if one indulges in dissipation without cease, the primordial qi is depleted by forty-eight *zhu*, leaving a correspondence to *gou*. If desires grow more intense, and this continues for another decade, another forty-eight *zhu* is lost, leaving a correspondence to *dun*. If one still does not nurture it and adds another decade, another forty-eight *zhu* is lost, leaving a correspondence to *pi*. At this point, one reaches the midpoint of heaven and earth’s qi. If one still does not nurture it and adds another decade, seventy-two *zhu* are lost, leaving a correspondence to *guan*. If one still does not nurture it and adds another five years, ninety-six *zhu* are lost, leaving a correspondence to *bo*. If one still does not nurture it, by the sixty-four hexagrams, the primordial qi is exhausted, leaving a correspondence to *kun*. *Kun* is pure yin; one lives only by the grace of grain qi, hence the term 'borrowed lifespan.' At this stage, death is near, and one can no longer refine the elixir. Those who have severely damaged themselves may not even reach this point before perishing. The depletion of primordial qi—is this not what we call long-standing chronic illness? 'Restored to wholeness in an instant' means that through cultivating this Way, the true spirit grows daily stronger, the primordial qi flourishes, one returns to life and restores the root, attaining peace and longevity—this is the meaning.

After expounding the scripture a sixth time, white hair turns black again, and fallen teeth regrow. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a sixth time" is Heaven One generating water, Earth Six completing it. Dwelling in the north, the accumulated yin of *kan* is the true qi of lead, where *qian* and *kan* unite to form water from metal. Lead is the mother of metal; lead is black and metal is white—this refers to white hair returning to its original root. "Fallen teeth regrowing" means that which was withered revives.

After expounding the scripture a seventh time, the old regain their youth, and the young grow stronger. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a seventh time" is Earth Two generating fire, Heaven Seven completing it. Returning south to the palace of *li* is mercury, where *xun* and *li* unite to form fire from wood. Mercury is drawn from cinnabar. The south is fire, and mercury is also fire—the image of blazing flames without cease. The scripture states: "When things reach their peak, they age—this is called 'not the Way.' What is not the Way perishes early." If one does not know the Way of return, fire blazes and smoke scatters, leaving nothing of the original state—how can one remain strong without aging? Once one grasps the principle of return, mastering the workings of cyclical reversal, returning to restore the root and reverting to the origin, the old become youthful and the young grow strong.

After expounding the scripture an eighth time, pregnant women, birds, and beasts carrying young—whether already born or not yet born—all attain full development. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture an eighth time" is Heaven Three generating wood, Earth Eight completing it. Returning east to the abode of *zhen* is cinnabar, where *gen* and *zhen* unite to form wood from water.

Cinnabar forms when mercury responds to lead-qi and congeals. Cinnabar contains the essence of mercury, resembling a womb carrying a fetus. Just as mercury solidifies upon encountering lead, qi blends with spirit and merges as one. This qi is not the postnatal yin-qi of the body but the wondrously transformed, life-generating primordial qi. Scholars must not fail to discern this. Once congealed, this qi grows ever more robust, while the arising spirit-qi repeatedly fuses and solidifies, no longer subject to material decay. It nurtures the sacred embryo, hence it is said that "whether already born or not yet born, all attain full development."

Expounding the scripture a ninth time, Earth’s treasury releases its store, and gold and jade reveal their forms. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a ninth time" is Earth Four generating metal, with Heaven Nine completing it. Returning west to the *dui* direction yields gold, where *kun* and *dui* unite to form metal from earth. For mercury returns to the earthen crucible and becomes treasure. *The Kinship of the Three* says: "When metal comes to return to its nature, it is called the Reverted Elixir"—this is what is meant by "qi returning to the origin." The Heavenly One’s water first arises from the empty qi of the metal embryo before the metal’s substance appears. Earth Four generates metal, still a transformative mechanism; at this stage, it returns to the origin and restores its nature, residing in the Central Palace—this is the elixir’s body, bearing a mysterious image. The Central Palace is earth. Earth is the realm, and the Metal Mother dwells within it, hence it is said that "Earth’s treasury releases its store, and gold and jade reveal their forms."

Expounding the scripture a tenth time, withered bones revive, and all rise as complete beings. *The Inner Meaning* states: "Expounding the scripture a tenth time" is Heaven Five generating earth, with Earth Ten completing it. This is *li* separating from *ji* so that earth forms from fire, residing at the center as the root of all creation and the foundation of the elixir’s body. The *Daoist Scripture* says: "The harmonious arises from the void." The harmony within qi is what enables the generation of the myriad things. Heaven Five’s earth is yang earth; Earth Ten’s earth is yin earth. When the two earths overlap, metal resides within them, hence the Reverted Elixir is called the "knife-point." The marvel of the Reverted Elixir lies in reverting old age to youth and transcending the mundane to attain sagehood. The world’s people, bound to mortality, are but walking corpses in the eyes of those who behold them. Yet once this Way is attained and cultivated, one achieves longevity and does not become a ghost of the yellow springs—is this not "withered bones reviving and all rising as complete beings"? This is the completion of the Five Phases’ numbers.

The Han Celestial Master’s preface to *The Scripture of Divine Golden Fluid* states: "The path of divine immortals, the subtlest of words, the supreme principle beyond principles, the great truth beyond what is so—all are fully contained in the profound tradition, not to be conveyed by even the slightest trace." The Most High likewise expounded this wondrous Way of emptiness and subtlety. At that time, every man and woman in the land turned their hearts toward it, all received protection and deliverance, and all attained longevity. Those who clearly grasped this Way achieved immortality and did not die. In that era, whether man or woman, old or young, all in the land received the sagely grace and were universally saved and delivered. The living did not die, and the dead revived.

*The Inner Meaning* says: "A land is like a single body; men and women are like yin and yang. Turning the heart is akin to mutual affinity. Protection and deliverance mean receiving nourishment. When yin and yang are in harmony, spirit and qi are nourished, the body is at peace, and the Way flourishes—this is the principle of longevity."

*End of The Inner Meaning of the Supreme Mystery of the Infinite Salvation Scripture, Scroll One*
*Beginning of The Inner Meaning of the Supreme Mystery of the Infinite Salvation Scripture, Scroll Two*

Disciple Guanfu, Xiao Yingsou, studying the Dao, said: At that time, the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning expounded the scripture once, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the eastern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a second time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the southern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a third time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the western realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a fourth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the northern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a fifth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the northeastern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a sixth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the southeastern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a seventh time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the southwestern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture an eighth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the northwestern realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a ninth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the upper realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void. He expounded the scripture a tenth time, and the boundless, innumerable hosts of perfected great spirits from the lower realm of the Infinite arrived, floating through the void.

*The Inner Meaning* says: In terms of the scripture, when the Celestial Worthy expounded the scripture ten times, the great spirits of the ten directions arrived—these were the Three Origins and Nine Sages, the Nine Perfected and Nine Immortals, the lofty perfected and exalted sages, the celestial spirits and earthly deities, all assembling in the Azure Beginning Heaven’s Floating Black Realm to listen to the Dharma.

In terms of the elixir, when the Primordial Beginning expounded the scripture, true lead became the ancestor of the medicine, and mysterious essence formed the foundation of the cinnabar. The ten recitations correspond to the numbers of heaven and earth’s generation. The ten directions correspond to the numbers of the Five Phases’ combinations. One, three, five, seven, nine—twenty-five in total—are the celestial numbers, the essence of yang. Two, four, six, eight, ten—thirty in total—are the terrestrial numbers, the splendor of yin. One, two, three, four, five correspond to the four cardinal directions and the upper direction; six, seven, eight, nine, ten correspond to the four corners and the lower direction. The generative numbers of yang are five, the root of the Five Phases. The consummate numbers of yin are ten, the root of the myriad transformations. One and nine, four and six, each combine to make ten—metal and water share the same origin. Two and eight, three and seven, each combine to make ten—wood and fire share the same body. In sum, fifty-five, distributed among the five directions. One and six reside in the north; two and seven in the south; three and eight in the east; four and nine in the west; five and ten in the center. Applying the method of division, the five directions subtract one, two, three, four, five—these are the origins of water, fire, wood, metal, and earth. Subtracting again, one, two, three, four, five—these are the roots of the Five Phases. After subtraction, each of the five directions retains five numbers, totaling twenty-five, the root of the Five Phases, the true yang body of the central earth. Further removing the root numbers of the five directions—one from the north, two from the south, three from the east, four from the west, five from the center—reveals four remaining numbers in the north, symbolizing metal. Metal fundamentally generates water, yet metal itself is born from water, as lead arises from the qi of silver, and silver is born within lead—this is the child producing the mother. Metal is the tiger. Metal within water is the tiger born within water. Three remaining numbers in the south symbolize wood. Wood fundamentally generates fire, yet wood itself arises from fire, as mercury responds to the qi of lead to form cinnabar, and cinnabar is born from mercury—this is the child producing the mother. Wood is the dragon, the dragon emerging from within fire. Two remaining numbers in the east symbolize fire. Fire is born from wood, mercury drawn from cinnabar—this is the sevenfold return of cinnabar to its origin. One remaining number in the west symbolizes water. Water is born from metal, the one qi returning to its origin—this is the ninefold return of golden liquid to the true. The center, emptiness, combines the four images to form ten, revealing the wondrous function of true yin earth.

Thus, Master Zhang Ziyang said:
*The dragon of thunder mercury emerges from the land of fire,*
*The tiger of marsh lead is born in the region of water.*
*These two things arise from the child producing the mother,*
*The Five Phases must all enter the center.*

He also said:
*The red dragon and black tiger each dwell west and east,*
*The four images interact within the central earth.*
*From this reversal and union, transformation is set in motion—*
*Who could say the golden elixir would not succeed?*

The Perfected of the Great One said: "The art of inverting the Five Phases—
*The dragon emerges from within fire,*
*The Five Phases do not proceed in order,*
*The tiger is born within water—*
This is the meaning."

The arrival of the boundless great spirits takes the hidden movements of the pure and true Qian and Kun as its model, dividing the three hundred eighty-four lines, circulating within the fire, revolving the five stars and twenty-eight constellations, arrayed within the crucible, condensing the three thousand six hundred primordial qi, traversing the seventy-two seasonal nodes, driving the sixty-four hexagrams’ yin tally, stirring the twenty-four qi’s yang fire. Subtle and detailed, revealed in the hidden language of the heart’s mirror. Thus, heaven and earth cannot conceal the mechanism of creation, yin and yang cannot hide the root of nurturance. Thereby, spiritual transformations are boundless, and pure generation is achieved, all gathered within grasp, merged within the empty and cavernous.

Someone asked Cheng Yi: "The sage does not learn from the immortal; their arts differ. Could the sage perform such things?" He replied: "This is a thief within heaven and earth. If one does not steal the mechanism of creation, how could one prolong life?" Thus, the *Scripture of Unconscious Unison* says: "Humans are the thieves of the myriad things." To steal creation and plunder the myriad things is to make all within heaven and earth one’s own—taking without prohibition, using without exhaustion.

When the ten recitations were complete, the boundless perfected great spirits of the ten directions arrived simultaneously. The men and women of the land turned their hearts in reverence, coming like fine rain and dense mist.

The innumerable multitude pressed upon the land, occupying half its breadth, and the earth sank unevenly—none could prevent it. When the Heavenly Venerable opened the realm, the ten thousand sages assembled, their majesty and virtue so weighty that the earth could not bear it, hence the uneven sinking. For extraordinary events, there are extraordinary responses. When Chan Master Farong of Niutou Mountain expounded the *Mahāprajñāpāramitā Sūtra* and reached the "Accomplishment of Stillness" chapter, the earth trembled—how much more so when the August Emperor of Emptiness enacts transformation!

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the ten recitations were complete and the perfected great spirits of the ten directions arrived simultaneously, this was the settling of the spirit in quiescence, the return of qi to the chamber. When the men and women of the land turned their hearts in reverence, this was the blending and refinement of the yin and yang qi within the body. The gathering of spirit and qi exuded a dense, fragrant vapor. The *Cantong Qi* says: "When gold and cinnabar enter the five viscera, their mist scatters like wind and rain." Gold is the purest essence of heaven and earth—it is spirit. Cinnabar is the pure quintessence of yin and yang—it is qi. Thus it is said: "They came like fine rain and dense mist." The innumerable multitude, reaching the golden essence behind the elbow and the true qi beyond the Yang Pass, was the mutual stirring of nature and emotion, the silent operation of heaven’s mechanism, the mutual excitation of yin and yang, and the transformation of the true spirit. Though it is said that the body moves naturally, it still resides within the realm of effort, unable to avoid the alternations of restlessness overcoming cold and stillness overcoming heat. This is because, when held and filled, nature and emotion are not yet merged. Nature and emotion belong to earth, hence it is said that half the land was pressed upon, the earth sank unevenly, and none could prevent it.

The Primordial Beginning suspended a precious pearl, as large as a grain of millet, within the empty mystery, five measures above the earth. The pearl symbolizes the Dao; suspended in the empty mystery, it shares the meaning of the "mysterious pearl." Within it, the transmission of scriptures reveals treasure within treasure, mystery within mystery, the true within the true, the Dao within the Dao. "Five measures above the earth" signifies that one departs from the Five Turbidities of the world and sheds the use of the Five Phases. When the Five Turbidities all emerge, afflictions naturally vanish; when the Five Phases are no longer used, mutual conquest ceases forever. Thus, when the Five Phases do not conquer one another, all things may be preserved, and one naturally attains long life and enduring vision, achieving the Dao and becoming a perfected being.

The Mysterious Master said: This is the precious pearl of Jade Purity, the Dao of the womb-transformation of divine immortals. The *Inner Meaning* states: The Primordial Beginning’s suspension of the pearl is the union of spirit and Dao. Previously, the lion upon which the scriptures were expounded was the spirit congealed within the chamber, proceeding from non-being to being. Now, this pearl suspended in the empty mystery transcends spirit and things, moving from being into non-being. The Heavenly Venerable, fearing that later students of the degenerate age would not grasp this principle and merely cling to dull emptiness, manifested wondrous transformations to clarify that within the utmost non-being, the utmost true and utmost pure abide. The scripture says: "Vast and obscure, within it there is essence; its essence is most true, within it there is sincerity." In terms of principle, this is the return of spirit to the obscurity of nature, standing alone in perfect clarity, suddenly without obstruction, emptily without foundation. Radiant and joyful, dark and silent—it is not bound by the reckoning of the Five Phases nor sullied by the realm of the Five Turbidities. Master Chuan said: "Forms and seeking are both delusion; formlessness and invisibility fall into barrenness. How could the resplendent and dense ever be separate? A single beam of cold light shines through the great void."

The Primordial Beginning ascended and led the great spirits of the perfected heavens, the lofty sages and venerable ones, the perfected of wondrous conduct, the perfected great spirits of the ten directions and the boundless realms—all the innumerable multitude—into the precious pearl. The heavenly beings gazed upward and saw them bustling as they entered the pearl’s mouth; once inside, their whereabouts were unknown. The Heavenly Venerable enacted wondrous and profound transformations, suspending the pearl within the empty mystery, its suspending thread unfathomable. He ascended and led the Three Origins and Nine Saints, the Nine Perfected and Nine Immortals, all into its midst. All the heavenly beings, not being the perfected of the heavens, the lofty sages, or the true persons, could not follow the transformative mechanism of non-action nor enter the wondrousness of the empty mystery; they could only gaze upward. They saw them bustling as they entered the pearl’s mouth; once inside, their whereabouts were unknown.

Moreover, even lesser immortals of lower rank possess the wondrous ability to contain Mount Sumeru within a mustard seed and suspend heaven and earth within a gourd—how much more so the great sagely Heavenly Venerable, who unfolds and proclaims great transformations, manifesting divine marvels! The precious pearl, though said to be as large as a grain of millet, is already subtle and wondrous; to be five measures distant and still see the pearl within the empty mystery is beyond the capacity of heavenly beings, let alone perceiving its mouth. Furthermore, to witness the Heavenly Venerable leading the perfected sages into the realm of wondrous being and empty non-being—when the heavenly beings gazed upward as they followed the Heavenly Venerable into the pearl, they saw them enter its midst but could not perceive the wondrous transformations within.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the true spirit is already obscure, qi also follows into stillness, uniting with emptiness and merging with the non-being, ascending into the mysterious and entering the wondrous. This is called gathering the ten thousand beings into a single breath and dispersing a single breath into the ten thousand beings. In welcoming it, one does not see its beginning; in following it, one does not see its end. Its coming has no source; its going has no place. When the people of the land dispersed and moved, the earth returned to level stillness, no longer uneven or sunken.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Movement and stillness both forgotten, being and non-being both relinquished. The Primordial Beginning then completed the recitation of the scriptures within the precious pearl. The *Inner Meaning* states: The Primordial Beginning is the spirit and the precious pearl—it is nature. "Reciting the scriptures" signifies illuminating the primordial qi as the body of the elixir. "Completed" means that spirit and nature are perfectly clear, utterly devoid of any thing. The assembled perfected monitored and transmitted it to me. The *Inner Meaning* states: The "assembled perfected" are the qi of wondrous transformation and arising. "I" is the Dao Lord.
