The Nine Heavenly Emperors were established as the mysterious ford of the Three Treasures, the Twenty-Seven Heavens as the cultivated grades of the realms, and the Thirty-Six Divisions as the mysterious roots of the Three Radiant Heavens, below which lie the domains of the Thirty-Six Heavens. Next, the Thirty-Two Heavens and Thirty-Two Emperors subtly set transformation in motion, dividing below into the Three Realms. Flanking the celestial pivot, the Twenty-Eight Constellations and Five Planets trace their courses to illuminate the Five Directions. Pure qi ascended, heavy turbidity congealed below, giving rise to the Nine Earths. At the center, the Nine Humans were born. Heaven, Earth, and all beings were thus complete.

Thus, the harmonious and upright qi of yang transformed into lofty sages and perfected immortals; the gentle, tranquil, and serene qi transformed into primordial lords, sacred consorts, immortal maidens, and jade women; the fierce, valiant, and heroic qi transformed into heavenly soldiers, divine warriors, and martial officials; the qi of yin and yang and the Five Phases transformed into men and women; and the chaotic and errant qi transformed into birds and beasts. All receive the same qi yet manifest in myriad forms, each following its own generation and transformation.

Since the Great Void lies within the enveloping and embracing Dao qi, this body, too, resides within it. Like the norms of the myriad things, the sun, moon, stars, constellations, peoples, and all categories of beings, it is akin to the qi’s ascent and descent responding to yin and yang, or the cyclical revolutions of cold and heat manifesting as cinnabar, mercury, lead, and silver. This is the transformation from non-being into being, forcibly named and modeled. To cling to it as real is to miss the wondrous Dao; returning to merge with the primordial is to achieve the Elixir.

The Primordial Net flows through the Thirty-Two Heavens, wheeling through the formless and circling the Ten Directions. Revolving the Dipper and traversing the Winnowing Basket, it cycles through the Five Constants. The Thirty-Five Divisions gather the qi of the Upper Origin. The Eight Radiant Realms merge in darkness, and qi enters the Mysterious of the Mysterious.

The Five Constants are the Five Phases. The Thirty-Five Divisions are the sun, moon, Five Planets, and Twenty-Eight Constellations. The *Inner Meaning* states: The Primordial Beginning’s ancestral qi, like a net’s guiding cords, is a unified whole. The Three Officials ascend and descend, circulating endlessly. This is what is meant by the Primordial Net flowing through the Thirty-Two Heavens, wheeling through the formless and circling the Ten Directions.

"Revolving the Dipper and traversing the Winnowing Basket, cycling through the Five Constants" clarifies how the great Brahman ancestral qi begins its revolution at the Dipper and concludes at the Winnowing Basket, circling through the celestial degrees to complete the Five Phases. The Dipper and Winnowing Basket belong to the northeast, the position of Gen and Yin. Measuring celestial degrees through the human body, this corresponds to the region above the lower cinnabar field. The primordial qi first stirs, surging through the obscure and hidden. At the Yin hour, above the lower cinnabar field, it begins to unfold and expand.

At this moment, with lead drawing mercury and yin summoning yang, it resembles the great potter’s wheel shaping all things—nothing fails to arise. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "In the primal chaos of the vast expanse, the female and male follow one another, their nourishing fluids moistening and enriching, their transformative influence flowing and circulating." Beginning in the northeast realm of the Dipper and Winnowing Basket, it revolves and turns rightward, spewing forth the wheel of sprouts, revealing hidden depths in the abyss, and scattering radiant essence.

Thereafter, yang qi ascends, and at its extreme, yin is born; yin qi descends, returning to the root and reverting to the source, encircling the entire body and revolving the Five Phases. Thus, Master Yixuan said:
*"The returning elixir extends life,
Reversing and cycling yin and yang qi.
Father and son, ruler and minister,
Circulate and return to one position."*

Spring’s benevolence warms wood,
Summer’s fire abides in ritual.
Autumn’s justice belongs to metal,
Winter’s wisdom is water.
The Yellow Lord alone upholds trust,
Earth’s tally is wu and ji.
These are the true Five Phases,
The Five Phases fundamentally of one kind.
Virtue and power are most distinct,
The ancestral masters focus solely on this.

Within a single day, within a year’s seasonal qi, heaven, earth, and the myriad things are all complete within me. The primordial qi stirs and yin-yang divides; yin-yang divides and the four seasons form; the four seasons form and the qi nodes cycle; the qi nodes cycle and the Five Phases are complete; the Five Phases are complete and creation is achieved.

Yin and yang qi are the sun and moon.
The four seasons are the four images.
The twenty-four qi nodes are the fire times.
The Five Phases are the medicinal substances.
Yin-yang and the Five Phases correspond to the Dipper’s four seasons.
The twenty-four qi correspond to the twenty-eight lunar lodges.
This is called the thirty-five divisions.
Creation’s achievement arises entirely from the one qi’s guiding net, the Eight Trigrams’ transformations, the subtle workings of the mysterious mechanism, and the hidden accord with the profound principle. Thus, it is said: the thirty-five divisions, the upper origin of all qi, and the eight luminous scenes merge in darkness. It cannot be exhaustively questioned, so it is blended into one, endlessly beyond naming, reverting to nothingness—hence, "qi enters the profound mystery." Within the profound is the Supreme August, the Highest Perfected, the Celestial Thearch.

Whenever "August" is invoked, it is the title of the Heavenly Worthy, equal in rank to the Primordial Beginning. As the *Inner Meaning* states: "Within the profound is the immortal among immortals, the perfected among the perfected, the sage among sages, the Dao among the Dao." The Supreme August is the Primordial Beginning; the Celestial Thearch is the Lord of the Dao; the Highest Perfected is the Venerable Lord. The annals say: The Primordial Beginning is a being of the Great Canopy Heaven; the Lord of the Dao is a being of the Western Na country; the Venerable Lord is the utmost essence of primordial generation, the utmost spirit of incipient form. Though their titles differ, their Dao is one.

Inwardly speaking, the Primordial Beginning as a being of the Great Canopy Heaven is the ancestral qi; the Lord of the Dao as a being of the Western Na country is the Metal Mother; the Venerable Lord as the utmost essence of primordial generation and the utmost spirit of incipient form is the cinnabar body. All are my true nature, originally no different from any other thing. As the Daoist scriptures say: "The formless form, the imageless image." This is what the Buddhists call the three bodies inherent in one’s own nature. The Sixth Patriarch said: "The pure Dharma-body is your nature; the perfect Reward-body is your wisdom; the hundred thousand million Transformation-bodies are your conduct." The Confucian texts say the same. The *Doctrine of the Mean* states: "What Heaven imparts is called nature"—this is the Primordial Beginning. "Following nature is called the Dao"—this is the Lord of the Dao. "Cultivating the Dao is called teaching"—this is the Venerable Lord. Though one thread runs through them all, they are the Dao.

The Confucians use it to govern the world, to order ruler and minister, to rectify high and low, their merit extending to things, and they too can transcend the world. Thus, the *Records of the Primordial Beginning’s Ascended Immortals* states: "From ancient times, those of utmost loyalty, utmost filial piety, utmost integrity, and utmost incorruptibility—unlike the common crowd—have all been promoted to immortal offices." The Buddhists use it to transcend the world, hence they say: "All conditioned things are impermanent, a dharma of arising and ceasing; when arising and ceasing cease, quiescence is bliss." The Daoist gate employs both presence and absence, interpenetrating the empty and the real, gathering to form shape and dispersing to form qi. Thus, it is said: "The jade tally preserves the spirit, the golden liquid refines the form; when form and spirit are both wondrous, they unite with the Dao in truth."

Floating upon the great aurora, chanting the cavernous chapters.
"Floating" means drifting; "scene" means body. It speaks of the Heavenly Worthy drifting upon the auroral clouds and intoning the cavernous chapters. As the *Inner Meaning* states: "Floating scene" refers to the principle in the scriptures that "the great Dao drifts—it can go left or right." "Great aurora" is the qi of constant yang, for the Dao is omnipresent. Wherever it drifts, it is not beyond the realm of constant yang, and intoning the cavernous chapters is the principle of ease and contentment. If one’s true nature is immersed in the primordial harmony, it is joyful and at peace. As *Zhuangzi* says: "Wandering the mind in blandness, uniting qi in the vastness."

The golden perfection shines resplendently, its flowing resonance in the cloudy encampment.
The jade sound gathers qi, the numinous wind assembles mist.
The Purple Void flourishes luxuriantly, aiding and sheltering the ten thousand immortals.

"Golden perfection" is the chapter of natural radiance, its flowing resonance in the palace of auspicious clouds. "Jade sound" is the chapter of jade light; with a single dawn roar, the numinous wind gathers mist. As the *Inner Meaning* states: "Golden perfection shines resplendently" means the true spirit is luminous and abundant. "Flowing resonance in the cloudy encampment" means qi returns to the spirit chamber. "Jade sound gathers qi" means lead qi attracts mercury. "Numinous wind assembles mist" means true mercury coagulates cinnabar. "The Purple Void flourishes luxuriantly, aiding and sheltering the ten thousand immortals" means the yang spirit is concealed and radiant, surrounded by the ten thousand qi, dwelling within the spirit chamber. This is called the body of the golden elixir.

Thus, Master Wen Shi’s *Eulogy on the Purple Void’s Yang Light Record* says:
*"The Void Origin’s peerless Purple Void Secret Record,
Root of the Three Caverns’ mystery,
True ancestor of heaven and earth,
Utmost high, utmost supreme,
Utmost wondrous, utmost numinous.
Cultivating it, one attains long life;
Practicing it as an immortal, one returns to simplicity and reverts to the uncarved block."*

Carefully observing these words, the Dao of the Purple Void is no different from the golden elixir.

A thousand harmonies, ten thousand unions—naturally they form the true.

The *Inner Meaning* states: "A thousand spirits harmonize into one spirit; ten thousand qi unite into one qi." By the principle of spontaneity, they coalesce into truth. Within truth dwells the spirit, the Great Lord of Longevity.

The *Inner Meaning* says: "This is the true spirit within nature, the fundamental Dao of undying life." As the scripture declares: *"Its essence is most true, within it lies constancy. From ancient times to now, its name has never faded."* This is called the golden liquid returned elixir.

The Noble Youth of Non-Flourishing, the Venerable White Prime, the Great One Who Oversees Destiny, Peach Prosperity and Union Longevity—
The Noble Youth of Non-Flourishing is the spirit of the liver; the White Prime is the spirit of the lungs; the Great One is the lord of all spirits; the Overseer of Destiny is the true one of the southern summit; Peach Prosperity and Union Longevity are the spirits of the left and right kidneys.

The *Inner Meaning* states: "The *Method of Uniting the Imperial One* says: 'White Prime, Non-Flourishing, Peach Lord, Overseer of Destiny, and the Great One—unite the five spirits, bearing the register and standing in attendance.'" Each of the five spirits governs its domain; through nine transformations they merge, and the Three and Five penetrate and transform. Thus the Three Palaces are secured in truth, and the hundred joints receive numinosity. The Imperial Lord’s precious register ensures that one’s predestined life remains unshaken.

Revolving through the misty void, they open the passage to mysterious essence. The twenty-four perfected ones suddenly manifest, ascending to open the Upper Prime, descending to open the Eight Dark Realms. To the left they summon the Six Jia, to the right they dispatch the Six Ding. The Jade Splendor draws the sun, and the Great One merges with form. A thousand chariots, ten thousand riders—with the whole body they ascend at dawn.

Cultivating the true Dao of the Imperial One, when merit is complete and the hundred spirits unite, the principle of the golden elixir is likewise fulfilled. Holding the talisman and grasping the register, one preserves life and roots existence.

The *Inner Meaning* says: "Talismans and registers: in terms of form, they are written characters; in terms of the formless, they are numinous qi. The adept of the elixir grasps yin and yang, wields heaven and earth, clarifies the marvelous workings of creation, and moves the subtle mysteries of lead and mercury. When spirit is whole and qi complete, one unites with the Dao in truth. The true spirit guards one’s nature and life; the numinous qi protects the root of one’s existence."

Above they roam the Upper Clarity, entering and exiting the Flowery Chambers. Within the Eight Dark Realms, amid the finest subtleties, below they guard the human body—Mud Pill Palace and Crimson Palace. In the center they govern the five qi and unite the hundred spirits. Ten revolutions return the numinous; ten thousand qi ascend as immortals together.

The Flowery Chambers are the Three Flowery Chambers of Jade Clarity. The Eight Dark Realms are the Eight Poles. The finest subtleties are the tips of hairs. Mud Pill Palace is the palace of the brain; Crimson Palace is the heart. These true spirits, with the Great One as their lord, roam the Three Clarities, enter and exit the Flowery Chambers, circulate within the Eight Poles, and pervade the finest subtleties. Below, they guard the human body: the Great One resides in the brain, governing all spirits; the Overseer of Destiny dwells in the heart, receiving the primordial of life; Non-Flourishing is in the liver, controlling the three hun souls; White Prime is in the lungs, restraining the seven po souls; Peach Lord is in the navel, preserving the root of essence; Union Longevity is in the kidneys, guarding the Gate of Life. In the center, within the hollow emptiness, they regulate the qi and harmonize the hundred spirits. As the *Book of Changes* says: *"The spirit’s origin is boundless—this is what is meant by the unfathomability of yin and yang."*

Thus the spirit is present everywhere; wherever it is, there is nothing it does not penetrate. Wisdom and knowledge cannot be defined by existence or non-existence.

The *Inner Meaning* states: "The principles of inner and outer are identical and without distinction. The Flowery Chambers of Upper Clarity, the Eight Dark Realms, and the finest subtleties—these are outer manifestations, transformed by a single qi. Mud Pill Palace, Crimson Palace, the five qi, and the hundred spirits—these are inner manifestations, likewise transformed by a single qi. Now, the non-existent: vast, it encompasses all; minute, it enters all. As for the spirit—it is not swift, yet it is fast; it does not move, yet it arrives." Mencius said: *"The vast qi fills the space between heaven and earth."* Zhuangzi said: *"The spirit reaches in all four directions, flowing without limit, ascending to heaven above, coiling upon the earth below."*

If one nurtures it in accord with nature, then the Three Divisions and Eight Effulgences, the Three Passes and Five Viscera, the Six Bowels, the Nine Palaces and Golden Towers and Jade Chambers, the Twelve Heavy Gates and Purple Doors and Jade Enclosures, the thirty-six thousand joints—all these, from root to origin, when spirit is whole and qi sufficient, are called the pure and unadorned Dao. Thus it is said: *"One who embodies purity and simplicity"* is called a true person. They roam and ascend to Upper Clarity, enter and exit the Flowery Chambers, vast enough to embrace the Eight Dark Realms, subtle enough to enter the tips of hairs. When gathered, they form a body; when dispersed, they become qi. The Heavenly Pass revolves ten times; the perfected ones transmit the numinous. The ten thousand qi return to the origin, and all attain the immortal Dao.

The immortal Dao values life and delivers beings without limit. Above, the Eight Gates open, and the Wheel of the Flying Celestial Law turns. Transgressions and blessings, prohibitions and precepts, predestined causes and conditions—all receive deliverance, and the souls of the dead are reborn in bodies. Once the body attains rebirth, it ascends to be heard by the various heavens. Above the various heavens, each has its Gate of Life. Within the heavens are countless great sages who constantly review the records of life and death for those who study immortality, delivering the souls of the Nine Dark Realms to ascend through the Eight Gates of the Dharma Wheel.

The above is the main text, spoken by the Most High Lord of the Primordial Beginning.

The *Inner Meaning* states: What the immortal Dao values above all is longevity. Without limit in its boundlessness, it delivers beings as they become ripe for deliverance. The *Treatise on Stimulus and Response* says: Those who seek longevity must advance through the Dao and retreat from what is not the Dao; they must accumulate virtue and merit, cherish compassion toward all things, be loyal and filial, friendly and fraternal, rectify themselves and transform others. Such are called good people—all people respect them, the heavenly Dao protects them, blessings and prosperity follow them, all evil departs from them, divine spirits guard them, their undertakings surely succeed, and immortality may be hoped for. Those who seek to become Celestial Immortals must establish one thousand three hundred good deeds; those who seek to become Earthly Immortals must establish three hundred good deeds. Refrain from all evil and practice all good. Thus, the fortunate person speaks good, sees good, and does good—three good deeds in a single day. After three years, Heaven will surely bestow blessings upon them. The ill-fated person speaks evil, sees evil, and does evil—three evil deeds in a single day. After three years, Heaven will surely bring down calamity upon them. The good and evil of people are all created by the heart. The heart, in its issuing and entering, takes form as an image; its gate moves in accord with the image. Its wheel of mental mechanism is perfected within, and the heavenly mechanism responds without. Thus, there are the Eight Gates of the Dharma Wheel, within which lies the arena of transgressions and blessings, the traces of prohibitions and precepts, and the origins of causes and conditions—all recorded in the *Dharma Wheel Sutra*. Though it is said that the transformation of great compassion universally opens deliverance, blessings vary in depth, and karmic retribution differs in degree. This is called: "All predestined lives are heard, and the heavens above bestow according to one’s meritorious deeds." In receiving life, the souls of the dead enter the gate corresponding to their karmic fruit, while the reborn body attains ranks of immortality, high or low.

Within these are the chapters of the *Empty Cavern Songs*, the *Numinous Writ of the Demon Kings*, and verses that rival those of the loftiest perfected beings. The *Inner Meaning* states: The preceding text speaks of the Gate of Life above each of the various heavens. The Dao Lord continues, saying: "Within these are the chapters of the *Empty Cavern Songs*." Some say "Empty Cavern" is the general name for the Three Realms; others say it refers to the principle of the *Cavern Chapters*. Taken together, the Three Realms encompass all the heavens, and within these heavens are the *Empty Cavern Songs*—the scriptures and records of the Three Caverns, the writings of the celestial perfected, hymns of praise, and the wondrous principles of the mysterious texts that awaken later learners. The flying songs of the Demon Kings, composed in midair, serve as warnings and admonitions, their principles in harmony with the celestial perfected. The Dao Lord has recorded them here, though they are not part of the original *Numinous Treasure* chapters and thus do not belong to the inner symbolic order; only their meaning is explained.

The above is the main text, recorded by the Jade Dawn Dao Lord.

The first is the *Flying Song of the Desire Realm*:

The *Inner Meaning* states: The Demon King of the Desire Realm composed this song. When the karmic deeds of speech in a person are entirely purified, and they possess the ten virtues, they ascend to be reborn in the Six Heavens of the Desire Realm. The human realm is fleeting and frivolous; the immortal Dao is vast and difficult to fathom.

The Ghostly Way delights in the gate of human life,
Yet perverse paths rush toward death.
The Heavenly Way treasures life,
Desiring humanity’s long existence.
The Ghostly Way treasures endings,
Desiring humanity’s final death.
The Immortal Way is ever auspicious,
For it knows the constant, understands the luminous—thus is it auspicious.
The Ghostly Way is ever inauspicious,
For it acts in delusion—thus is it inauspicious.
The lofty and pure numinous spirits,
Sing mournful songs resounding through the vast sky.
They only wish the Immortal Way to succeed,
And do not desire the human way to come to ruin.

The *Inner Meaning* states: In clarity, they are the lofty perfected and exalted sages; in obscurity, they are the pure and numinous spirits. Moved by compassion for the world’s people, they proclaim the principles of all things, awakening those of utmost learning and illuminating the space between Heaven and Earth. They only wish the Immortal Way to succeed, and do not desire the human way to come to ruin.

An ancient virtuous one said: In the secluded forest, birds call; in the emerald stream, fish leap. Clouds drift and unfold; waterfalls murmur in sorrow. Such scenes reveal the path for humanity to enter. From this perspective, the myriad transformations, though vast and chaotic, are nothing but mournful songs.

Master Dongshan said: If you rely on the ear to listen, you will never grasp it; only when the eye hears the sound will you come to know.

*Zhuangzi* said: Do not listen with the ear, but listen with the heart.

Like rushing waters in a swift river, like a white colt passing through a gap—sun-bird and moon-hare reveal the foundation of cinnabar. The snake’s sloughing and cicada’s molting manifest the principle of liberation. The spirit turtle imbibes qi; the dung beetle rolls its ball. The fish by the Hao River’s banks in Qiyuan, the grass before Lianxi’s window—all can be inwardly apprehended, the Way perceived in the very act of seeing. This is the teaching without words, the hearing without sound.

In the winding springs of the Northern Capital’s subterranean府,
A myriad ghosts gather in throngs.
They only seek to cut short human destiny,
Severing the gate of human life.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The offices of Mount Fengdu govern punishment and retribution, recording transgressions and diminishing lifespans. Once the lifespan is exhausted, the limit of life is extinguished.

As the scripture notes: The lifespan a person receives at birth is called their "allotment," recorded among the heavens. By decree of the Most High, the heavens and earth, sun and moon, stars and constellations, celestial perfected and exalted sages, generals and messengers, great spirits and divine youths, flying immortals of Heaven and Earth, the four bureaus of the Three Realms, and the officials of mountains and rivers—all hold registers and ledgers, patrolling and examining. Every three days, a report is made; every ten days, a memorial is submitted; every hundred days, a reckoning is settled. At the Three Primes, Eight Nodes, Five La Festivals, and Three Assemblies, merits and faults are assessed without cease. If one cultivates goodness, their years are extended; if one commits evil, their allotment is reduced, and they are sent to Fengdu with not a fraction lost.

Ah, the people sing the cavernous chapters,
To restrain the northern Luo and Deng.
Binding and delivering demonic spirits,
Severing the blades of the Six Ghosts.
The qi of the myriad heavens surges boundlessly,
My Way flourishes day by day.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When external deviance is eliminated, the qi of the myriad heavens surges boundlessly; when inner conduct is established, my Way flourishes day by day.

The second is the *Song of the Form Realm’s Demon King*:

The *Inner Meaning* states: The Demon King of the Form Realm composed this song. When the karmic deeds of the body in a person are entirely purified, and they possess three hundred virtues, they ascend to be reborn in the Eighteen Heavens of the Form Realm. Lofty and expansive—this is Heaven. Radiant qi shines in four directions—this is qi. The Brahma-conduct heavens encircle the ten directions; Brahma-qi envelops all. Immeasurable great spirits all arise from my body. All those who attain the Way are recommended for perfection by the Demon King. This demonstrates to practitioners the principle of promotion and demotion, so they may know what to take warning from.

I possess cavernous chapters,
Ten thousand repetitions make an immortal.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The cavernous chapters are the *Flying Mystery Purple Writ of Mount Gui’s Cinnabar and Yellow*. When the Perfected Lord Yin attained the Way, the Elder Lord granted him the Western Tower of Hao Terrace. Entering the Seven Treasures Garden, he beheld its scripture. Practicing it according to the method, as fully recorded in the *Numinous Treasure Scriptures and Methods*, one achieves the rank of Numinous Treasure Perfected—this is not the Demon King’s song. "Ten thousand repetitions make an immortal"—ten thousand is the accumulation of one; it cannot be accomplished in a single morning or evening. Thus, it is achieved through accumulated practice.

Formerly, the Perfected Lord of Fixed Records said to Lord Xu of Leiping: "Studying the Way is like digging a well: the deeper the well, the harder it is to remove the soil. If one does not steadfastly cultivate correct conduct, how can they reach the spring’s source?" This is the principle of accumulated practice.

The Immortal Way values deliverance,
While the Ghostly Way clings to connection.
What the Immortal Way values is long life and deliverance from the world; otherwise, when the body perishes and qi scatters, the hun and po souls are examined, and ancestors are implicated—how can one not be cautious?

Heaven and Earth are vast and boundless,
Foul qi swirls in abundance.
The joys of the Three Realms—
Pass beyond them to abide forever.
Crossing into my realm,
The body enters spontaneity.
At this time, joy—
Is but a trifling grace from me.

The *Inner Meaning* states: In the vastness of physical forms, none surpass Heaven and Earth, yet foul and turbid qi also fill their midst. The Great Void is vast and empty, unobstructed by the myriad encounters.

A master of great wisdom said: In the vastness of empty space, is there anything that obstructs it? Though it is not obstructed by things, it does not hinder things from coming and going. If a person’s nature is as vast and empty as Heaven, unobstructed by things, emulating the all-embracing nature of the Great Void, they transcend the six senses and six dusts, surpassing the Desire Realm, Form Realm, and Formless Realm. Habitual tendencies are entirely forgotten, and they no longer sink into the cycle of rebirth. Flesh and bones ascend together, entering the formless, attaining this state—true joy abides forever. Though this comes from cultivation, merit fulfilled and virtue perfected, it is also through the Demon King’s recommendation. This is one who attains the Way through the power of scriptural practice. If the work of the cinnabar path is accomplished, one ascends without passing through the ranks, immediately attaining the highest grade of immortality.

The Dragon Han era stretches boundlessly—
How can one distinguish the true?

The Dragon Han is the name of the first kalpa. At that time, the Great Way was pure and simple, its transformations effortless and unadulterated; human nature was likewise. The *Inner Meaning* states: At the inception of receiving one’s nature, like an infant before it can smile, how could there be distinctions of refinement and coarseness? The originally inherent nature is serene and pure; it is only through the delusions of emotions and consciousness that defilement and attachment arise.

The Most High said: "My greatest affliction is that I have a body."

"And when I have no body, what affliction could I have?
To have a body is to have consciousness and emotion.
To be without a body is to be without consciousness and emotion.
All consciousness and emotion arise from delusion by false illusions;
If one can recognize false illusions, consciousness and emotion naturally dissolve.
The *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* states: *Knowing illusion is to depart from it; departing from illusion is awakening.*
Nor is there need for forced rejection—
Then one’s nature returns to the darkness of the mind, merging wholly with the inception of the Dragon Han.
The scriptures say: *Focus the qi to attain suppleness, and one can be like an infant.*
Thus, what is real, and what is not?
My realm is difficult to transcend, so I compose this *Dongwen*.
My realm is the realm of form.
*Dongwen* is this song.
For the demon kings wish to encourage people toward the Dao and thus compose songs to exhort them.
They transform and fly through the void to test your resolve.

The *Inner Meaning* states: *Master Guan Yin said: ‘Things come without end, but my mind has its limits.’*
Thus, my good heart is constrained by emotion;
My original emotion is constrained by things.
The world’s entanglements, myriad and chaotic, are like obstacles to the Dao.
Respond to circumstances as they arise, but do not cling to them in the mind.
Thus it is said: *Things are not my things, yet I cannot but respond;
I am not my self, yet I cannot but nurture it.*
Though one responds to things, there are no things;
Though one nurtures the self, there is no self.
What cannot be avoided are clothing and food.
Yet clothing and food are but the boat and oars for crossing the world’s river.
Once the other shore is reached, they are no longer needed.
When all matters are settled, the floating life busies itself in vain.
Success and fame come as they will—
Chariots and crowns may arrive by chance,
So do not strive for them through force or cunning; follow the conditions of the world.
But if one is deluded by sounds and sights, recklessly squandering spirit,
Severing the bonds of nature and life, creating the karma of birth and death—
Then the mind chases after things, and the spirit drifts and scatters.
In the midst of utter nothingness, one clings to existence;
In the midst of ceaseless change, one clings to constancy.

The scriptures say:
*Ears and eyes, sounds and sights—these are the faults that detain you;
Nose and mouth, fragrances and flavors—these are your foes.
The body is the root of affliction—pain, itching, cold, and heat;
The mind is the burden of form—sorrow, poison, worry, and vexation.
If you do not swiftly cast them aside, your lifespan will not be prolonged.*
The noble person acts upon seeing the subtle signs, not waiting until the day’s end—
Why await the test?
How many among the transcenders falter in success or failure?
I laugh at your failure to transcend, so I sing this song.

The *Inner Meaning* states: *Success and failure, slackening and retreat—within these four words, one benefit and three harms.*
If one does not take the cycles of rebirth and death to heart,
Then faith in the Dao is not sincere, and one advances an inch only to retreat a foot—this is certain.
Thus the scriptures say: *People in their endeavors often fail when nearly accomplished.*
If one remains as vigilant at the end as at the beginning, there will be no failure—
This refers to the rarity of those who persevere to the end.

The Third Song of the Formless Realm Demon King states:

The *Inner Meaning* says: *The Formless Realm Demon King composes this song. When the karmic deeds of the human mind are entirely purified, and six hundred meritorious acts are accumulated, one is born in the four heavens of the Formless Realm.*
Above the Three Realms, the vast and distant Great Luo.
Above the Three Realms are the Seed People’s Four Heavens.
Above the Seed People is the Great Luo Heaven.
Without form or root, cloud layers rise towering.
Above the Great Luo Heaven is the Jade Capital Mountain, born without roots, suspended in the void.
Upon the mountain stand nine-tiered cloud towers, lofty and majestic.
Only the Primordial Beginning dwells there, the home of kalpas vast.
He governs my realm, presiding over the Mysterious Capital.
The Primordial Heavenly Worthy has resided there since the Empty Kalpa, ruling over the Three Realms.
Those who transcend my realm enter the Jade Void.
The *Inner Meaning* says: *My realm is the Formless Realm; the Jade Void is the Void Jade Capital.*
The practitioner who transcends the Formless Realm ascends above the four heavens of the Seed People to the Dao realm of the Jade Capital’s void—only then is there no risk of falling.
Those who have not yet transcended remain bound in the cycle of rebirth;
For the root of birth and death is not severed, and the qi of yin and yang still lingers.
Still subject to fate, they rise or fall without end, ceaselessly turning—
Only attaining the Dao brings it to an end.
I reign as the supreme king, governing the multitude of demons.
Ten thousand transformations in the void, impure qi blooms in profusion.
Few preserve the true; many are deluded."

The *Inner Meaning* states: Those who preserve the true remain steadfast and unchanging; those who are deluded dwell in illusion and are easily swayed. What is fragrant as orchid and musk, the enlightened call foul and wanton qi; the arena of right and wrong, the enlightened call the turmoil of sin and fortune; the allure of powdered faces, the enlightened call the poisonous blossoms of the turtledove. The world delights in these, hence the deluded are many.

The Dao of immortals is hard to uphold; the path of ghosts is easily corrupted. The Dao of immortals is tranquil and non-action—though precepts are set, few firmly abide. Worldly affairs indulge the heart’s desires; without instruction or temptation, one naturally follows dissipation. The human Dao lies in the heart—truly, it does not come from elsewhere.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The Three Teachings all arise from the ground of the heart. The Confucians speak of preserving the heart, the Daoists of cultivating the heart, and the Buddhists of illuminating the heart. Some say rectifying the heart, washing the heart; some say emptying the heart, quieting the heart; some say stilling the heart, subduing the heart—all aim to refine it and restore its goodness. Thus, the Confucian cultivates the self, orders the family, governs the state, and brings peace to the world, all proceeding from the rectification of the heart. Extending this to others, one finds ample room—how could it be external to the heart?

The *Book of Documents* says: *The human heart is perilous; the Dao-heart is subtle. Only with precision and unity can one truly hold to the center.* As for extending knowledge and investigating things, these too are attained through rectifying the heart.

The Daoists say: *The void gives me life; non-being places me. That which gives me life is spirit; that which destroys me is the heart.* They also say: *All the evil karma of sentient beings arises from the heart’s deluded thoughts and inversions, failing to awaken to non-action. All roots of sin are created by the heart. The joys of heaven arise from the heart; the sinking into the Three Realms also begins in the heart.*

The Buddhists say: *If one wishes to fully know all buddhas of the three times, one should contemplate the nature of the dharma-realm—all is created by the heart.* They also say: *A hundred thousand dharma-gates all return to the square inch of the heart; the sands of the Ganges’ wondrous virtues all reside in the source of the heart. All gates of precepts, concentration, and wisdom, all spiritual transformations and miracles, are fully possessed within—none are apart from your heart.* As Mazu said: *The heart itself is buddha.* The *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* states: *All sentient beings are the ground of pure awakening.*

Pei Xiu said: *That which is truly pure, luminous, wondrous, and empty—penetrating and spiritually efficacious, standing solitary and unchanging—is the heart. Turning away from it makes one ordinary; following it makes one sagely. Delusion gives rise to the beginning of birth and death; awakening brings the end of rebirth.*

Yang Guishan said: *The entire *Mencius* is but an effort to rectify the human heart, teaching people to preserve the heart and nurture nature, to gather the scattered heart. Though a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, all arise from the heart. If one can rectify the heart, nothing else need be done.*

Shao Kangjie said: *Heaven divides creation from the One Center; humans initiate governance from the heart.* He also said: *The body is born after heaven and earth; the heart exists before heaven and earth. Heaven and earth emerge from me—what else need be said?*

From this, we see it is truly not from elsewhere. The essential lies in vigilance in solitude: do not look at what is contrary to propriety, do not listen to what is contrary to propriety, do not speak what is contrary to propriety, do not act in ways contrary to propriety. Do not see what may be desired, lest the heart be disturbed. Abide in stillness and quietude, anchoring the spirit—let no stray thoughts arise. Embrace the One and guard the true; spirit harmonizes and qi clarifies. Let the heart be like dead ashes, the form like withered wood. External scenes do not enter; inner scenes naturally close. Do not pursue, do not cling—ten thousand thoughts will settle of themselves. Concentrate qi to attain suppleness. Return to the nature of an infant.

Should one act contrary to this, one merely invites hardship. The Dao of immortals values substance: *See the plain and embrace the uncarved; returning to life is called constancy.* The human Dao values splendor: like feasting on grand sacrifices, like ascending spring terraces. If you do not delight in the Dao of immortals, how can you transcend the Three Realms? If you wish to turn through the Five Paths, what can I do for you?

The *Inner Meaning* states: Those who do not delight in the Dao of immortals value the splendor of the human realm. Enamored of worldly pleasures, they do not know the suffering of rebirth. According to the *Sutra of Origins*: *When thoughts cannot return and one turns away from the Dao, one enters the Five Paths without respite.* What are the Five Paths? The first path: the spirit ascends to heaven as a heavenly spirit. The second path: the spirit enters flesh and bone to become a human spirit. The third path: the spirit enters birds and beasts to become an animal. The fourth path: the spirit enters creeping vines to become a hungry ghost. The fifth path: the spirit enters the hells of mud and plough to be tormented.

Alas! The Great Sage, in boundless compassion, earnestly warns: if one awakens to the fact that worldly pleasures are not true pleasures and that transcending the Three Realms is true joy, one will surely not endure rebirth through the Five Paths.

The above is the main text as narrated by the Dao Lord.

Above the Three Realms, in the void of flight, the Demon King’s song resonates, its melody interwoven with cavernous hymns. Reciting it a hundred times is called *Passing the Southern Palace*. Reciting it a thousand times, the Demon King will protect and welcome you. After ten thousand recitations, the Dao is perfected, and you will ascend to the great void, transcend the Three Realms, and be enthroned as an immortal duke. Those who hear the numinous sound—the Demon King will show reverence. The numinous sound refers to the original hymns of the *Numinous Treasure*; the Dao Lord praised the Demon King’s song, saying that even reciting it can lead to perfection and entry into the Dao—how much more so the original hymns of the *Numinous Treasure*!

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the heart aligns with the scripture and conduct accords with it, uniting goodness as one and cutting off all conditions, recitation then truly embodies the scripture’s intent. It commands and restrains earthly deities, who escort and receive, delivering one from the Five Sufferings and Eight Difficulties of the earthly realm. Seven generations of ancestors ascend, forever departing the ghostly officials. The soul crosses the Vermilion Mound, undergoes refinement, and is reborn.

The above command and restraint were bestowed by the Celestial Venerable of Original Beginning; the Dao Lord recorded them.

The *Inner Meaning* states: *Command and restraint* refers to the decrees of the Celestial Venerable of Original Beginning—the primordial qi of the Original Beginning. Decrees are the workings of creation. *Earth* is soil; *only* is spirit, signifying that the primordial qi of creation, the true nature of soil, gives birth to spirit.

Those who *escort and guard* cultivate correctness, sustain fullness, preserve the feminine, and embrace the One. Those who *send off and receive* are the flow of *kan* into *wu*, the movement of *li* toward *ji*—this is the completion of merit and the perfection of the elixir. Thus the *Wuzhen Pian* says:

*Take the solid from the next position in the heart,
Refine the yin within the Palace of Li.*
From this, it transforms into the firmness of *qian*,
A hidden, soaring, and free heart.

When yang *qi* is pure and complete, and yin *qi* is entirely stripped away, one transcends the reckoning of the Five Phases and escapes the mechanism of the Eight Trigrams—hence it is said: *delivered from the earthly realm’s Five Sufferings and Eight Difficulties.* Yin *qi* is severed at the Gate of *kun*, thus *seven generations of ancestors ascend, forever departing the ghostly officials.* The yang spirit gathers in the Palace of *li*, thus *the soul crosses the Vermilion Mound, undergoes refinement, and is reborn.* This is the divine transformation of shedding the mortal coil—*the immortal of eternal life.*

Such is the boundless, universally liberating power. It holds the secret celestial script, revered by all heavens. To leak or profane it is to fall into hell, bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Vast as heaven and earth, minute as insects, this Dao is complete, lacking nothing. It is not bestowed because of nobility, nor withheld because of lowliness. Its secrecy exists only to prevent disrespect. If one can revere and practice it, blessings are infinite; if one is negligent, dark retribution remains.

The Dao says: These two chapters are the hidden sounds of the Heavenly Emperors and the Divine Kings of Spirits—utterances of the Great Brahma, not the common speech of the world. Their words lack ornate rhythm, their melodies lack florid beauty; thus they are called profound and obscure, difficult to fathom.

The *Inner Meaning* states: These two chapters are the *Hundun Chiwen* and the *Yuandong Yuli.* One reveals the Dao of the Primordial Heaven, the other the principles of the Posterior Heaven. Their hidden sounds, the words of the Great Brahma, the mysteries of the elixir—all follow the same principle. Not being the language of the world, they are hard to investigate. Without a master’s guidance, how could they be easily understood?

This treasure of heaven is kept secret in the Purple Tenuity Palace of the Mysterious Capital. According to the celestial statutes, it is transmitted once every forty thousand kalpas. If a perfected person offers gold and treasures with a sincere heart, following the old protocol and pledging allegiance to the Ten Heavens, only then is it bestowed. Ten thousand kalpas are like last night; a thousand springs are like this morning. Thus, a transmission once every forty thousand kalpas is not truly distant—this is the celestial standard, not the timeframe of mortal transmission.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This scripture and this Dao are heavenly treasures, with strict protocols for transmission. How could they be treated lightly?

The Dao says: The revolutions of heaven and earth also have their ends. *End* refers to the calamity of the *yang* nine and hundred-six. *Termination* refers to the dissolution of the Three Realms. The sun, moon, and five planets also wax and wane. Even the most sagely and divine beings experience cycles of flourishing and decline. Lesser students also face illness and injury. If heaven, earth, and sages have their times of decline, how could lesser students avoid affliction? If one encounters such, accept it without resentment.

When such disasters arise, all of shared *qi* must act together: with unified hearts, perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times. Blessings and virtue will descend immediately, dissolving all misfortune. The boundless scripture universally liberates without end.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Humans, heaven, earth, and the myriad things are of a single *qi.* Thus the Most High addressed the four assemblies: When any among them face disaster, all of shared *qi* should unite in purification rites, burning incense and reciting scriptures—this is to view all as one body. How could one who cultivates the Dao place self and others in the chamber of the mind?

Master Zeng said: The Master’s Dao is nothing but loyalty and reciprocity. *Loyalty* is exhausting oneself; *reciprocity* is extending oneself to others. If I desire peace, how could others not desire it as well? Thus, when I wish to stand, I help others stand; when I wish to succeed, I help others succeed. Then there is no killing or harming, no jealousy or envy, no licentiousness or theft, no greed or desire, no hatred or resentment. Words are free of embellishment, speech free of malice. With unified compassion and love, even those of different bones become kin. This is how it is achieved.

It is said: To become an earthly immortal, perform three hundred good deeds; to become a heavenly immortal, perform one thousand three hundred good deeds—this is not difficult. If one can follow this, why merely become an immortal? The Dao of Great Peace will be complete.

The Dao says: If a student’s cultivation is shallow and their immortal rank incomplete, when their destined time of passing arrives and their body enters the Great Yin, at the moment of transition, fellow students and perfected ones should burn incense and recite the scripture ten times to deliver the corpse according to the method. The soul will ascend directly to the Southern Palace, and according to their merit, after a set number of days, they will be reborn. Escaping the wheel of rebirth, they will attain immortality.

The *Inner Meaning* states: If one’s practice is insufficient, fate cannot be escaped. Though this form is shed and appears dead, the feet do not turn green, the skin does not wrinkle, the eyes do not dim, and the limbs remain pliable. Following the protocol for delivering the corpse, the spirit undergoes refinement in the Yin realm. According to the depth of their merit and the length of their practice, after the allotted time, the spirit returns to the body, and they are reborn. Though outwardly deceased, after years or even decades, it is but a moment in time. From then on, they attain immortality—this is also the Dao of corpse liberation.

The Dao says: When the revolutions of heaven and earth end, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their regularity, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. These three cannot escape the reckoning of fate, but human effort can assist them. Human effort cannot alter their outcome, yet the Dao grants it.

When the ruler of a state faces disaster and warfare erupts on all sides, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When plague and pestilence spread, causing the death of the people, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures.

When masters or friends face the end of their allotted span, one should likewise perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. In these three matters, Heaven cannot manifest its efficacy unaided; human effort brings them to fruition, yet human effort cannot exhaust their utmost sincerity—this, too, is granted by the Dao.

Now, purification rites and scripture recitation carry profound merit: above, they dissolve celestial calamities and safeguard the emperor; below, they dispel poisonous harms and deliver the multitudes. In life and death, all depend upon them, their blessings beyond measure. Thus it is said: boundless, they universally ferry across heaven and humanity.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Humans, bearing the form of Heaven, dwell between yin and yang, never departing the bounds of their mold—how could they escape hardship and adversity? The workings of creation move in secret; cold and heat shift imperceptibly. If one does not adjust in accord with the seasons, suddenly afflicted by pestilence, how could illness be avoided? Speaking inwardly, when "the movements of Heaven and Earth reach their end," this is the exhaustion of fate. When "the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their regularity," this is the turbidity and chaos of spirit and qi, the dizziness and palpitations of heart and eyes. When "the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony," this is the imbalance of dryness and dampness, cold and warmth, the discord of the two qi. As for "performing purification rites, burning incense, and reciting scriptures," this is to empty the heart and refine qi, to nurture the spirit and preserve the true. It can succor the world and revive the dying, avert misfortune and dispel illness.

If the ruler of a state faces disaster, warfare erupts on all sides, plague and pestilence spread, causing the death of the people, or masters and friends face the end of their span, one should rouse loyalty and sincerity, compassion and pity, dispel calamities and rescue the afflicted, employing arts of salvation to accumulate good karma and amass hidden merit. Thus it is said: purification rites and scripture recitation carry profound merit.

Now, purification is the purification of the heart. When Yanzi abstained from wine and meat, Confucius called it the purification for sacrifice, not the purification of the heart. The purification of the heart is to empty the heart. The *Daoist Canon’s Record of Calculations* states: "A ten-day purification fast adds a twelve-year cycle to one’s lifespan; a one-day purification fast adds a hundred days." This purification is none other than the purification of the heart.

As for precepts, Lord Laozi said: "Those who study the supreme Dao yet do not uphold the great precepts—reciting scriptures, chanting incantations, wearing talismans, praying to spirits, compounding elixirs, ingesting medicines, or retiring to the mountains to seek ascent as immortals—may hardly hope for success. If one can fully uphold the precepts inwardly while harmonizing one’s light outwardly, one may approach the threshold of the numinous. It is not cultivation that is difficult, but upholding the precepts. If you can fully uphold the precepts, extending your thoughts to the ten directions, the Most High will ensure your ascent as an immortal. If one upholds the precepts fully, recites the precious scriptures, wears the great talismans, and performs the rites, yet still does not ascend as an immortal, then there is no path to deathlessness under Heaven. What I lament about the world is the rarity of such people."

To have scriptures without precepts is like crossing the sea without a boat or oars, like having a mouth without a tongue—how could one ferry across the multitudes? The essence of the Dao lies in aligning one’s conduct with the true regulations and accumulating goodness within; only then may one enter the realm of the great Dao. Those who cannot do so labor in vain amidst the dust, gaining nothing for the length of their lives.

Thus, precepts have distinct texts, their outlines briefly set forth: the Five Precepts of Lord Laozi, the One Hundred Eighty Precepts conferred upon Master Yin, the Seventy-Two Precepts conferred upon the Perfected Master Gan, the Twenty-Four Precepts of the Great Clarity, the Twelve Precepts for Purification Rites and Daoist Practices, the Ten Precepts for Cultivating the True, the Nine Wondrous Precepts of the Nine Perfected, the Nine Precepts of the Numinous Treasure, the Five Precepts of the Orthodox Unity—others are fully recorded in the scriptures and repentance texts, too numerous to name. Without exception, they serve to examine the heart and restrain the self, to cease evil and prevent wrongdoing. In short: think no deviance, respect all things. What is most urgent is to place lust first. Thus it is said: lust is the foremost of the ten defeats, killing comes next. Other actions that hinder Daoist practice or obstruct principle should all be abandoned. The scriptures say: "Diminish and diminish again, until reaching non-action."

All who uphold the precepts must meticulously study and practice them. If there is anything not understood, omitted, violated, or mistakenly transgressed, all incur transgressions and sins, collectively called "breaking the precepts." One should then repent and confess. The Queen Mother of the West said: "Those who yearn for the Dao and aspire to immortality must concentrate their sincerity and will, purify themselves and reflect on transgressions, thereby eliminating a hundred faults. Restraining the self and returning to goodness, revering the true spirits, preserving the true and guarding the One—practicing this for a month eliminates a thousand faults. Thus, faults are transformed, the preserved becomes numinous, the world is succored, the state is blessed, and all under Heaven enjoy its great benefits. Yin and yang harmonize and settle, ghosts and spirits do not disturb, all beings fulfill their natures, and the myriad things remain unharmed. Outwardly, this is the response; inwardly, the result may be known. How could it not 'dissolve celestial calamities above, safeguard the emperor, dispel poisonous harms below, and deliver the multitudes'? How could its blessings not be 'beyond measure, universally ferrying across heaven and humanity'?"

Here ends *Volume Four of the Inner Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Boundless Salvation of Humanity*.

*Volume Five of the Inner Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Boundless Salvation of Humanity*

It is also said: "Purification rites and scripture recitation can dissolve celestial calamities, safeguard the emperor, dispel poisonous harms, and deliver the multitudes. May one’s good intentions be voiced, and the heavens above shall hear them—resounding like the crack of firecrackers—whereupon the Perfected Ones and all the sages above will surely uphold them, for their hearts are in accord. Within the heavens, the Great Brahma’s hidden language resounds with boundless tones. **The Middle Section of the Numinous Scripture of the Original Beginning**
*Composed by the Dao Lord*

The *Inner Meaning* says: The white characters marked in the *Numinous Scripture* correspond to the symbolic forms of the hexagrams’ qi, the seasonal nodes, and the times of day. The ancient Perfected Ones declared that this *Numinous Scripture* accords with the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Great Change*. This scripture existed before heaven and earth, before the hexagrams came into being. The Queen Mother of the West, over nine days, guided the *Qian* and *Kun* hexagrams to manifest the *Mu* and *Dong* trigrams, so that *Qian* and *Kun* began with these, followed by *Zhun* and *Meng*, and concluding with *Ji Ji*, forming the warp and woof of creation. The sixty *jiazi* cycles listed below clarify the beginning and end of the qi’s numerical circulation. The twelve hexagrams of the monthly nodes and seasons that follow illustrate the waxing and waning of yin and yang, the advance and retreat of cold and heat over the year. The separate notations for the waxing and waning of the new and full moons clarify a single month. The twelve two-hour periods further mark the fire phases and the advance and retreat of the water tally within a single day. Thus, the nodes of a year are compressed into a month, and two and a half days correspond to a month. The twelve hexagrams that follow, matching the twelve two-hour periods, further condense a month into a single day. One two-hour period corresponds to two and a half days. Therefore, the upper and lower hexagrams differ in their applications, and the *jiazi* cycles and seasonal nodes also vary in meaning. In sum, the upper hexagrams’ *jiazi* are the warp, while the lower hexagrams’ seasonal nodes and times of day are the weft. The cultivated person need only observe the movements and stillness, the rises and falls, the waxings and wanings, and naturally will grasp the meaning beyond words, for the subtlest principles are all contained herein. Following the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s annotations of the inner sounds, some passages have been abridged to retain essentials, while others have been expanded with additional characters to elucidate the text, all to ensure that people may understand its meaning.
