Having received the union of sun and moon, one meets upon the Jade Terrace. "Great chiliocosm" refers to the enumeration of worlds. Master Lù says: Counting a thousand to a thousand makes a small chiliocosm; counting a thousand small chiliocosms makes a medium chiliocosm; counting a thousand medium chiliocosms makes a great chiliocosm. Those who recite and chant the Cavernous Writ shall ride the feathered-wheel chariot, ascend to the Yellow Chamber, wander above the Jade Terrace, and behold the realm of the great chiliocosm.

The Nine Uglies are obscure and vast,
*Kuí* (睽), *Dīng-Yǒu* (丁酉).

The old commentary states: *Miǎo* (眇) means the jade script is veiled and not manifest, appearing faint and distant.

"Mǎng" (莽) signifies that its script shines again, vast and boundless.

When one encounters the true Dao, both men and women shall live for thirty-six thousand years. At the culmination of this cycle, after enduring one kalpa, the nine qi each give birth to a beast to harm the wicked. Once the kalpa unfolds, these nine beasts are called the Nine Uglies of ghosts. The Northern Emperor and the Perfected of the Upper Realm preside over the Register of Life and Death, thus establishing the Nine Uglies to assist the Three Officials. When the count reaches eighty-one myriad, at the convergence of heavenly qi, the Nine Uglies are fit to serve as aids, known as the Envoys of the Nine Capitals.

The *Sháo* hymns follow the *Yuán-Zhān* cycle.
*Saì* (赛), *Wù-Xū* — at the Great Heat solar term, corresponding to the *Dùn* hexagram, the day aligns with the *Wèi* hour.

The old commentary states: *Sháo* is the inner name of the Celestial Sovereign of the *Huáng-Jiā* Heaven. The Celestial Sovereign of *Shén-Xiāo* is the spirit of the Demon King, who constantly tests those who study the Dao to discern whether they are upright or not, composing songs to disturb the human mind. Those with steadfast hearts are protected and recommended by the Sovereign, ascending to the *Huáng-Jiā* Heaven. *Yuán-Zhān* is the inner taboo name of the Northern and Southern Dipper Lords. When one accumulates good deeds, they are recorded by the Southern Dipper, which then delivers them from the tribulations of the Three Realms and the sufferings of the Nine Darks, notifying the Demon King below to refrain from harming or corrupting them. If one commits evil, the Three Officials list their sins before the Northern Dipper, which then instructs the Demon King below to extinguish their souls and consign them to the depths of the Nine Darks, where they toil in eternal night for ten thousand kalpas without end.

Above the Nine Capitals, *Jiě* (解), *Jǐ-Hài*.
The old commentary states: "Above the Clouds" is the inner taboo name of the Flying Celestial Divine King. At the dawn of the *Lóng-Hàn* kalpa, the *Chì-Míng* cycle was inaugurated, the spontaneous scriptures were bestowed, and the roots of heaven and earth were established. The Nine Capitals refer to the nine-tiered terrace that arose after the Three Images were divided, situated upon the Jade Capital Mountain, resplendent above the Mysterious Void. Flying celestial beings constantly scatter the fragrance of a hundred lotuses and strew the blossoms of the five clouds to behold the Flying Perfected. Upon the terrace stands the Jade Lad of the Great Perfected, who thrice daily waves the Ten Absolute Banners. With each revolution of the banners, the Divine Emperors of all heavens thrice circumambulate the Mysterious Terrace, chanting the Cavernous Writ in procession.

The flying ones ascend of their own accord.
*Sun* (损), *Gēng-Zǐ*.

The *Old Commentary* states: "Flying Life" refers to the divine being of renewed existence in the southern heavens. Should a scholar recite the Cavernous Writ, Flying Life shall open the path of deathlessness, pour forth the qi of enduring life, and refine the five souls below—thus the Eight Radiant Ones are preserved. *Qiān* denotes the Forest of Ascension. Once the body is raised together to ascend the Mysterious Terrace and wander beneath the Forest of Ascension, bearing the Celestial Writ and reciting the Cavernous Writ for twenty-four years, one may ascend to pay homage at the Mysterious Capital.

*Na-Yu* is lush and fragrant.
*Benefit* (Yì), *Xīn-Chǒu*.
On the day of *Jiàn-Shēn* in the month of *Lì-Qiū*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Na* is the esoteric name of the Heavenly King’s attendant. It governs the qi of heaven’s four seasons and the net of emptiness and non-action to rectify and pacify the celestial divisions. *Yu* is the name of the Heavenly Gate’s hollow wheel. *Yù-Fù* is the name of the numinous youth within the Dipper, who constantly turns the Wheel of Yu to summon the Perfected. When the Heavenly Gate revolves ten times, the great sages of the ten directions ascend to pay homage to the Jade Emperor, and all spirits assemble—whereupon *Yù-Fù* intones the rites.
The *Móluó* Dharma-Wheel.
*Decisiveness* (Guài), *Rén-Yín*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Móluó* is the esoteric inner name of the Great Demon of Heaven. When *Yù-Fù* intones once, the Demon King binds his form. The adept who understands the arising of qi in the four seasons and the ten revolutions of the Gate enters the portal of the Dharma-Wheel, mounts the chariot to ascend to *Yù-Qīng*, and pays homage at the Terrace of the *Zǐ-Wēi*.

*Hòng* holds the *Wú-Jìng*.
*Gòu* (Yǐn), *Guǐ-Mǎo*.
At the *Chǔ-Shǔ* solar term, corresponding to the hexagram *Pǐ*, the day aligns with the *Shēn* hour. By the *Gēng* hour, it is called "half a catty of water," when yin returns to the yang chamber, mercury comes to join lead, its essence resembling the mother, and white silver is formed.

The ancient scripture says:
*The Primordial Lord first refined mercury,
The divine chamber held emptiness profound.
Mysterious white gave birth to Metal’s Duke—
Lofty, the first glimpse of the primal ground.*

This speaks of Metal returning to its original nature; only then may it be called the *Returned Elixir*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Hòng* is the inner name of the Celestial Capital’s supervisory spirit. *Holding* is the name of *Lóng-Yuān*. Within it coil the myriad dragons, bearing the golden infant to convey the blossom of the Eastern Well, ever irrigating the celestial perfected. *Wú-Jìng* is the radiance of the Flying Heavenly Divine King, issuing colorless light to govern the register of life and death, opening the path for those who cultivate the Dao.

*Lǎn-Zī* moves with grace.
*Cuì*, *Jiǎ-Chén*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Lǎn-Zī* is the name of the gate to the Three Realms. Should one know this title, the Divine King will open the palace of eternal night, rescue the souls from the nine depths of darkness, and guide them through the gate of the Three Realms.

*Yùn-Róng* is the name of the Mysterious Harmony Jade Maiden. Once *Lǎn-Zī* is attained, *Yùn-Róng* employs the vermilion spirit-qi to guide it into form, while the fluid of Great Harmony irrigates the spirit, ascending to the Hall of Fortune and Virtue. *Fù-Lǎng* shines resplendent, *Kuò-Yì* soars—ascending on *Yǐ-Sì*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Fù-Lǎng* is another name for the Jade Capital Terrace in the midst of heaven. The Western Numinous Perfected constantly recites the cavernous scriptures while wandering above it. *Kuò-Yì* is the inner name of the Heavenly Divine Lord. Born together with the Primordial Beginning, he serves as the model of the mysterious qi, instructing those who study immortality. Should one comprehend the sounds of the eight characters, the Divine Lord will open the gate of eternal darkness, allowing ascent through the Gate of Renewed Life to mount the Jade Capital Terrace.

The divine tassel returns to the palace—*Kùn* on *Bǐng-Wǔ*. Established in the *Yǒu* month, at the White Dew node.

The *Old Commentary* states: The *divine tassel* is the Purple Tenuity Numinous Youth, who presides over the dissolution of the corpse. Should one obtain the *divine tassel* and chant the boundless chapters, the form will return to the chamber of the Three Refinements, receive the qi of spontaneity, and rejoice in limitless longevity.

The above sixty-four characters constitute the true script of the Southern Eight Heavens.

*Dāo-Lì* Chan practices—*Jǐng* on *Dīng-Wèi*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Dāo-Lì* is the name of the Southern Limitless World. Chan is the kingdom of *Dāo-Lì*, also called *Chán-Lí*. Within this kingdom lies the Cavernous Yang Palace and the Flowing Fire Court. The numinous script originates from the Flowing Fire; once refinement is complete and enlightenment attained, *Dāo-Lì* transforms into the Hall of Fortune and Virtue. *Yóu* is the inner name of the Southern Lord of Compassionate Life. All suffering souls are delivered to enter the Cavernous Yang Palace.

*Pó-Ní-Gāu-Tōng*.

At *Gé*, *Wù-Shēn*—the Autumn Equinox—corresponds to the *Guān* hexagram, with the sun aligned at the *Yǒu* hour.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Pó-Ní* is the numinous youth of the Fire-Refinement Pool. When one attains deliverance to the Cavernous Yang Palace, they proceed to the Fire Pool to undergo refinement and be reborn in the kingdom of Fortune and Virtue. *Gāu-Tōng* is the demonic spirit of the *Dāo-Lì* world, ever obstructing the path of human life. Yet when one knows the name of the Lord of Compassionate Life and approaches the numinous youth for refinement, they are born into the kingdom of Fortune and Virtue, and the demonic spirit submits. If one recites the sound of these eight characters, the limitless numinous officials of *Dāo-Lì* will guard their body, escorting them directly to the Southern Palace, where immortals shall receive them. Within three years, they will surely ride the cinnabar wheels of the celestial void, ascending to the heavens of the Three Qi.

*Wǎn-Sǒu-Dí-Sè*, *Dǐng*, *Jǐ-Yǒu*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Wǎn-Sǒu* is the inner name of the Heavenly Emperor of the August Cliff. He presides over the opening of the scriptures of the Great Desert, illuminating the text of the eight characters. *Dí-Sè* is the flying immortal of the Form Realm, ever riding a chariot drawn by dragons, moving in and out of the Jade Purity, delivering the virtuous. The Hall of the Vast and Subtle, *Zhèn*, *Gēng-Xū*.

The *Zhèn* trigram is Wood, the Dragon, the transformative mechanism of Fire—its subtle principles of alternation and concealment were expounded earlier.

The *Old Commentary* states: The Hall of the Vast and Subtle is the Hall of Transformative Generation. The transformations of the hollow void condense into natural patterns, vast and boundless, unfolding the destinies of the ten thousand beings. When a practitioner masters the sound of the eight characters, flying immortals descend in cloud chariots to bear them upward into the Hall of Transformative Generation.

*Liú-Luó-Fàn-Méng*, *Gèn*, *Xīn-Hài*. Established in the tenth lunar month, at the Cold Dew node.

The *Gèn* trigram is Earth, the root of generation and completion, the foundation of creation and transformation—its profound meaning was elucidated earlier.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Liú* is the inner name of the Heavenly King, who dwells above the Purple Empyrean, roaming the Jade Capital Mountain. *Luó* is the taboo name of the Moon Maiden, who presides over the rites of the royal excursions and feasts. *Fàn* is the name of a flying immortal, who governs the turning of the Nine Heavens’ gates. *Méng* is the Primordial Celestial Divinity, the root of the Supreme Wind’s origin.

*Jǐng-Wèi-Xiāo-Yú*, *Jiàn*, *Rén-Zǐ*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Jǐng* is *Jǐnghuáng*, the Perfected One of the Four Poles above. *Wèi* is *Wèixiù*, the Immortal of Radiant Empyrean. Together, they govern the Jade Capital Terrace, ever traversing the long night to deliver the souls of good roots. *Xiāo* is *rèn*—the palace of the White Primordial Sovereign. *Yú* is the cove of *Xiāo-Rèn*, the place where guests are received. Those who constantly recite the cavernous scriptures may ride the nine-colored clouds to ascend the Terrace of *Jǐnghuáng*.

*Yì-Miǎo-Wú-Jì*, *Guīmèi*, *Guǐ-Chǒu*. At the Frost Descent node, corresponding to the *Bō* hexagram, the hour aligns with *xū*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Yì-Miǎo* is the title of the Heavenly King of Filial Radiance. *Wú-Jì* is the Court of Emptiness and Stillness. It speaks of the Heavenly King coming from the Dragon Han, emerging in the Crimson Clarity, and dwelling within the Court of Emptiness and Stillness.

*Wǎn-Shǒu-Shào-Dū*, *Fēng*, *Jiǎ-Yín*. The *Old Commentary* states: *Wǎn-Shǒu* is the inner name of the Supreme Dao Lord. The Dao Lord ever unfolds the profound mysteries of the Primordial Beginning, expounding the Great Dharma to deliver beings. *Shào-Dū* is the name of the Spirit Youth within the sun, who scatters solar essence to irrigate the true currents and scatters flying blossoms to brush away dust. Those who know the sound of these eight characters will have the Heavenly King descend in a chariot of radiant clouds, plow the Three Pristine Fields, deliver their person above the Three Realms, and enter the Court of Stillness.

*Ā-Lán-Yù-Zhú*, *Lǚ*, *Yǐ-Mǎo*. The *Old Commentary* states: *Ā-Lán* is the hidden name of the Heavenly King, who constantly rides the wheel of Radiant Empyrean, roams the nine-tiered terraces, dwells in the Jade Tower, and chants the cavernous scriptures to subdue demon kings. *Yù* is *Mò-Yù*, the hidden name of the Demon King of Heaven’s Center. *Zhú* means desire—the Demon King’s capital is ever in the realm of *Kǎn*, chanting songs of emptiness.

*Huá-Mò-Yán-Yóu*, *Xùn*, *Bǐng-Chén*. Established in the eleventh lunar month, at the Beginning of Winter node. *Xùn* is Wind. All things rely on its breath to grow, flourish, and bear fruit. Yin does not congeal without wind; Yang does not harmonize without wind. The *Book of Changes* says: "Following the wind, *Xùn*." The noble one issues commands and acts—this is the principle of Yin and Yang in application.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Huá* refers to the radiant splendor of the Form Realm. *Mò* refers to the vast and untraceable Desire Realm. *Yán* is the Court of Binding Demons; *Yóu* is the Chamber of Restraining Demons. When the Heavenly King ascends the Cloud Tower and chants the boundless scriptures, celestial demons respond by binding themselves, and all ghosts submit their forms at *Yóu*. Those who uphold this will see their nine ancestors prosper; those who cultivate it will have their ashen bones reborn.

*Jiǔ-Kāi-Zì-Biàn*, *Duì*, *Dīng-Sì*. *Duì* is the Metal Tiger. Metal is the transformative mechanism of Water—its subtle principles of separation and concealment were explained earlier.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Jiǔ-Kāi-Zì-Biàn* refers to the Great Expansion’s beginning, when Heaven and Earth were not yet sealed. The revolving Three *Qi* opened into nine divisions. Once the nine degrees were clarified, the nine positions were arrayed, and the ten thousand kinds of Yin and Yang could then arise, naturally discerning and distinguishing.

*Ā-Nà-Pǐn-Shǒu*, *Huàn*, *Wù-Wǔ*. At the Lesser Snow node, corresponding to the *Kūn* hexagram, the hour aligns with *hài*.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Ā* is the inner name of the Heavenly King of *Ā-Qiū*, who constantly drives a dragon chariot, ascends the peaks of Dragon Mountain, and roams within the Nine Mysteries. *Nà* is the hidden name of the Flying Immortal *Nà-Xié*, who traverses the Three Realms, reviews the long night, and skillfully delivers the souls of the good. Those who know the sound of these eight characters will have the Heavenly King grade and deliver their person, transform their withered bones, and restore the countenance of a youth.

*Wú-Liàng-Fú-Gài*, *Jié*, *Jǐ-Wèi*. The *Old Commentary* states: *Wú-Liàng* is the Primordial Spirit of the Boundless Great Sage, who governs all flying immortals, all of whom receive their grades and promotions from him. *Fú* is the inner name of the True Person of Regeneration, who ever reviews the records of the long night and examines the roots of good and evil. *Gài* is the title of the Blessed Hall within the Mysterious.

*Fú-Luó-Hé-Shén*, *Zhōng-Fú*, *Gēng-Shēn*. The *Old Commentary* states: *Fú* refers to the delivered souls of the deceased, received by the True Person. *Luó* is the Great Net—opening the realms of the Great Thousand, summoning the guests of regeneration, and proceeding to the Heaven of the Great Net to fix their registers and erase death. *Hé* is union with blessings; *Shén* is the Divine Duke, the prime minister of the Great Net. Those who know the sound of these eight characters will unite with the Divine Duke in blessings, be delivered as guests of regeneration—hence it is called *Hé-Shén*.

*Yù-Dàn-Cháng-Sāng*, *Xiǎo-Guò*, *Xīn-Yǒu*. Established in the twelfth lunar month, at the Great Snow node. The *Old Commentary* states: *Yù-Dàn* is the name of the Jade Capital in the Heaven of *Tán-Shì*. *Cháng-Sāng* is the Heavenly *Qiān* Grove, also called Mulberry Grove.

*Bǎi-Kōng-Dù-Xiān*, *Jì-Jì*, *Rén-Xū*.

When *Jì-Jì* is achieved, cinnabar is formed. Mercury responds to the qi of lead and congeals into cinnabar. *Kǎn* is lead; *Lí* is mercury. When water and fire achieve *Jì-Jì*, *Kǎn* and *Lí* unite to manifest the image of cinnabar. The *Old Commentary* states: The *Qiān* Grove shades the Eastern Florescence Palace, its leaves bearing the script of the Great Cavern—purple writings in jade characters, resplendent in the Upper Clarity. Below stands the Fusang Tree; above, the dense thickets of *Qiān* Wood. Azure fowl sing beneath its canopy, while verdant mists crown its peaks. Divine winds stir the fragrant grasses, and the Mulberry Grove sets forth the music of a hundred pipes. With a single gust of the divine wind, the cavern script becomes sound—hence it is called *Bǎi-Kōng-Dù-Xiān*. Flying celestial perfected ones examine those who study immortality, delivering the souls of the Nine Glooms. The preceding sixty-four characters constitute the true script of the Western Eighth Heaven.

*Jué-Wú-Zì-Yù*, *Wèi-Jì*, *Guǐ-Hài*—the last day of the lunar month. *Wèi-Jì* is mercury. Water and fire remain apart; mercury has not yet formed cinnabar. *Lí* and *Kǎn* return to their origin, and mercury regains its fundamental nature. The *Old Commentary* states: *Jué-Wú* was a flying celestial spirit of the *Lóng-Hàn* era. From the primal qi of the original beginning, within the formless expanse of the primordial chaos, *Jué-Wú* emerged borne by the turning of the cosmos, coagulating qi to take form. Once the *Xiāo* Heaven was established, it endured through the unending kalpas. *Yù* is the inner name of the Heavenly King of *Xiāo* Heaven. Nine suns guide *Qián*. *Qián*...

*Qián* is the beginning of the ten thousand things, the spontaneous void of nature. The pure essence of the true unity of qi is called *Empty Qi*. The golden embryo is likened to silver plating: when father and mother unite in essence, the responsive attachment forms the embryo, concealed within the kidneys—this is called the *Original Spirit*. As the unified qi transforms and returns to the Central Palace, it becomes the *Elixir Mother*; through the cyclical movement of metal and fire, it reverts to its origin—this is silver.

*Metal* is the spontaneous qi of prior heaven. *Metal* is the embryo. *Fire* is the yang qi of daily life and generation. Though they emerge as one with different names, forming substance and function, they are not originally two things.

The *Old Commentary* states: The nine refers to the Heavenly King of *Yù* riding the elephant-wheel chariot, roaming the Nine Dark Gates, turning the Nine Celestial Mechanisms, and responding to the kalpa’s appointed time. The *sun* refers to the Sun Lad within heaven, guiding and harmonizing qi. When the Sun Lad reaches the end of heaven’s movement, he halts his radiance to deliver the adept, bathing them in the essence of the *Water Mother*, guiding them with the qi of *Great Harmony*, refining the Five Spirits, and entering the Vermilion Palace. The *Mother of Kūn* covers the east—*Kūn*.

*Kūn* is the completion of the ten thousand transformations.

After the adept receives the embryo, the spirit conceals itself within the kidneys—this is called the *Kun* Palace. It is termed *nature*, and called *lead*; the mechanism of transformation returns to the Central Palace. This mechanism is the yang qi of daily arising and generation. As the foundation of the elixir and the ancestor of medicine, it is called *primordial essence*; gathering and refining cinnabar and mercury, it forms the substance of the elixir.

Now, in the workings of creation, existence arises from the primordial, and so *Kun* is established through *Qian*, while *Qian* is completed through *Kun*. *Qian* and *Kun* mutually generate and complete one another, with no before or after. As Yi Chuan said: "Creation has no beginning; yin and yang have no origin." It is like the principle by which lead arises from silver, and silver is completed by lead.

According to the *Daoist Scriptures*: "These two emerge as one with different names." Why then do the ancient perfected and supreme sages, in elucidating the principles of things and clarifying the workings of creation, forcibly employ lead, silver, cinnabar, and mercury as metaphors for the elixir’s mysteries? It is simply to make it easier for later generations to understand.

The *Old Commentary* states: The *Kun* Mother is the Great Yin’s capital, the Ninefold Spirit Mother. She governs the abyss of the Eastern Sea’s Fusang and Yang Valley, ever controlling the earth’s mechanism, turning the wheel of primordial qi, and corresponding above to the Celestial Pass. When the Celestial Pass turns and the earth’s mechanism moves, the heavens complete one revolution, and the waters surge forth in thirty-three hundred degrees. When the qi of heaven and earth intermingle, the nine seas merge into one, and the waters fill the sky.

The *east* refers to the Eastern Sea, the meeting point and controlling source of the river’s origin. *Covering* means the Water Spirit governs Kunlun Mountain, filling and securing the vast sea, blocking the Eastern Well—thus the earth’s mechanism does not leak, and the kalpa’s long preservation is ensured. Its form gathers the Upper Mystery.

*Tun* (屯)
*Jiazi* (甲子): The Winter Solstice node, corresponding to the *Fu* hexagram, the new moon, and the hour of *zi*. The yang qi’s wondrous workings arise from the *Kun* Palace as the first yang returns. The ancient scriptures say: "The yang qi’s black emanation arises from *Kun*; the sundial points to the southern pole, the five stars align in a string, and the sun and moon form a jade bi." It also says: "When the metal essence undergoes its first transformation, the Azure Dragon receives the talisman, and the yang line is the pool." True yang ascends like the image of the sun. Upon reaching the Central Palace, the Metal Mother gathers and refines it—this is called *cinnabar*. *Cinnabar* is wood; wood is the dragon. This is the Azure Dragon receiving the talisman.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Gathering form* refers to the time of calamitous conjunction, when the *Kun* Mother’s form emerges above the Eastern River, summoning the Bird Mother with a phoenix chariot to welcome the adept ascending to the wastes of Kunlun. The Bird Mother is the spirit overseeing water. *Above* means the *Kun* Mother ascends to the Celestial Lord to report the kalpa’s appointed time, delivering the adept and inscribing their name in the Dark Capital.

*Tuoluo Yumiao* (陀罗育邈)
*Yichou* (乙丑)
The *Old Commentary* states: *Tuo* is the inner name of the Celestial Emperor, born together with the Miao Cheng Heaven on the Cloud Ridge. *Luo* is the name of the moon at its first appearance. *Tuo* dwells above the Cloud Ridge, embracing the moon to illuminate it. *Yu* is the name of the Divine King, who governs the ten directions and the flying gods of heaven. *Miao* is the name of the celestial overseer of the Feathered Forest. The Divine King constantly commands the guardians of the Three Realms, reviewing the registers of human life and death, and ordering the demon kings to protect and deliver those who attain the Dao.

*Miao qi* merges with the clouds.

*Xu* (需)
*Bingyin* (丙寅): The month of *jianchou*, the Lesser Cold node.
The *Old Commentary* states: *Miao qi* refers to the adept, having been delivered and protected, ascending to the Feathered Forest overseer to receive the talisman and ascend to heaven, traveling the subtle qi of the clouds. *Merging* means merging with the luminous essence. Once entering the Feathered Forest, they weave cloud qi into garments and then ascend together with the heavens, merging with the luminous essence.

*The Great Ugly of Flying Heaven* (飞天大丑)
*Dingmao* (丁卯)
The *Old Commentary* states: *Flying Heaven* refers to the flying mystery of qi, forming the scripture of the Cavernous Void. The Flying Heaven Divine King constantly recites it to receive the adept. *Great* refers to the Three Realms’ comprehensive register, governing the charts of life and death. *Ugly* means elder. He is the great demon of the Three Realms, serving the Great Ugly. If the adept recognizes the sound of the eight characters, the demon kings protect their authenticity, and their body ascends to the Three Clarities.

*Overseeing the heavens above*.

*Shi* (师)
*Wuchen* (戊辰): The Greater Cold node, corresponding to the *Lin* hexagram, and the hour of *chou*.
The *Old Commentary* states: *Overseeing* refers to the official who governs the Flying Heavens, constantly gathering the qi of the eight assemblies to preserve the heavens’ and earth’s movements, supervising the officials of the long night, and delivering the souls of the dark. If one knows the sounds of heaven, the celestial demons arrange their words, the Great Ugly records the immortal ranks, and they ascend to the Forbidden Upper Heavens.

*The Kalpa Measure of Shatuo* (沙陀劫量)
*Jisi* (己巳)
The *Old Commentary* states: *Sha* refers to the Purple Tenuity’s separate palace, the Shalan Palace within the Constant Fusion Heaven. *Tuo* refers to the multitudes of Tuoqiu, numbering in the hundreds of millions, all newly delivered and attaining the Dao, their merits incomplete, dwelling scattered within the palace. *Kalpa Measure* means that with each transition of the kalpa’s movement, the multitudes of Tuoqiu have their merits and virtues assessed, ascending to the Vermilion Mound Palace to receive blessings and become immortals.

*The Radiant Brilliance of Longhan* (龙汉瑛鲜)
*Xiaoxu* (小畜)
*Gengwu* (庚午)

The *Old Commentary* states: *Longhan* is the name of the primordial kalpa. *Ying* refers to the Flying Celestial Deities of the Longhan era, who constantly deliver the souls of the departed, ascending them to the Shalan Palace. *Xian* refers to the youths of the Southern Palace. When disciples attain deliverance, the *Xian* youths refine their countenance.

*The Azure Vault and Floating Li*
*Biluo Fuli*
*Xinwei* (辛未)
*Establishing the first lunar month, the Beginning of Spring solar term.*

The *Old Commentary* states: *Bi* refers to the jade-green radiance of the *qi* perpetually born in the Jade Capital Heaven. *Luo* is the name of the Flying Celestial Deities in the void. Thrice daily, they guide the multitudes of celestial sages to ascend and pay court at the Seven Treasures Palace. *Fuli* is the inner name of the Heavenly King. When the multitudes of sages ascend to pay court, the Heavenly King proclaims his jubilation. The *Dongzhang* further states: *"Soaring triumphant, the Azure Youths ride the clouds; the Luo-net gleams upon the Supreme Mystery."* Truly, these are not merely the names of deities.

*The Treasured Song of the Void*
*Ta*
*Renshen* (壬申)

The *Old Commentary* states: *Kong* is the name of the celestial attendants who serve the dawn. *Ge* refers to the melodies of the *Dongzhang*. When the attendants of the dawn emit a single cry, the numinous winds begin to play, and the music forms the *Dongzhang*. Thus, it is called *"The Treasured Song of the Void."* When disciples comprehend the sounds of these eight characters, they ascend to the Southern Palace as guests among the Flying Celestial Deities. They preserve this kalpa without end and treasure the natural patterns of its scripture; thus, it is called *"preserving the treasure."*

*The Unranked Evil Yi*
*Pi*
*Guiyou* (癸酉)
*The Rain Water solar term, corresponding to the hexagram* Tai*, with the sun aligned in the hour of* Yin*.*

*Tai* signifies the union of Heaven and Earth, from which all things are born. By the hour of *Shen*, it is called *"half a catty of gold."* The Dragon and Tiger intertwine, yin and yang unite in kind. The ancient scripture states: *"Yin and yang intermingle; essence and fluid envelop the primordial qi. The ten thousand images arise from the void, each responding to its kind through resonance."* This is the sign of the sacred embryo’s formation.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Eyi* (also written as *Yi*) is the inner name of the Heavenly King. In the Longhan kalpa of old, all karmic conditions were exhausted. Having transcended the Three Realms, they ascended to the Pavilion of the Great Void, received the register of the Nine Immortals, and attained the title of Great Sage.

When the Kalpa of Red Clarity and Renewed Fortune dawned, the Primordial Beginning bestowed upon him the title of Brahmā-Steadfast Heavenly King.

*Wu* signifies the Supreme Non-Being Perfected One. This Perfected One, dwelling in the Heavenly King’s palace, delivers the souls of the Long Night. *Pin* denotes the weighing of the dark souls’ sins and blessings.

*"Penetrating subtlety arises from the real."*

*Fellowship*
*Jiaxu*

The *Old Commentary* states: *"Penetrating subtlety arises from the real"* means that the Supreme Non-Being Perfected One delivers the souls of the Nine Netherworlds, thoroughly discerning their past lives. All evil conditions are exhausted, and they are guided into the hall of wondrous transformation. *Zi* means *"with."* With the Flying Immortals, they merge into the real.

*"The Primordial Brahmā’s vast expanse"*
*Dahuo*
*Yihai*

The *Old Commentary* states: The *Primordial Brahmā* refers to the qi of the Primordial Beginning’s great Brahmā wind and marsh, which uplifts and clarifies the essence of the Han River. Lofty, it pervades the floating void; suspended, it never falls. *Vast expanse* means distant yet unimpeded, existent yet as if non-existent, subtle yet indescribable, wondrous yet untraceable.

Delivering beings in profound stillness.
*Humility*
*Bingzi*
*Establishing the third month, Awakening of Insects*

The *Old Commentary* states: *Profound stillness* means dark and silent, beyond hearing or seeing. Within it lies the real; within the real lies essence. In darkness, the Heavenly Ones are delivered.

The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign said: The inner sounds of the heavens, the spontaneous jade scriptures, are all formed from the qi of soaring mystery, uniting the sounds of the five directions. They arise above the Primordial Beginning and emerge within the empty vastness. Their texts are profound and intricate, difficult to trace in detail. The Heavenly Worthy, in reward and exhortation, commands their meanings to be expounded.

The Daoist regulations have their decrees, and none dare disobey the mandate. When taking up the brush, the spirit soars to the Great Empyrean, refining both essence and coarse matter to the utmost of one’s heart and thought.

Once the August Way is made manifest, the myriad heavens rejoice in celebration. Those who treasure it receive the descent of Perfected Ones; those who cultivate it attain promotion in rank. Its majestic numen is vast and boundless, defying all description.

The above sixty-four characters constitute the *True Writ of the Eight Heavens of the North*.

The Dao declares: These are the great Brahmā’s hidden words and the boundless sounds within the heavens. The hidden words are the names of the Heavenly Thearchs, concealed and not revealed. The boundless sounds are the *True Cavern Chapters*, whose natural resonance pervades all heavens.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The great Brahmā’s hidden words and boundless sounds are formed from the spontaneous coagulation of wondrous qi. All the principles of Heaven and Earth reside within them. Void and solid interpenetrate, images and numbers become visible. When guided by the nine days to deduce the Qian hexagram, no principle remains unilluminated.

That Qian begins in the north signifies yang’s birth at *zi*. *Jiazi* is paired with Qian, and *zi* corresponds to the Yellow Bell, hence *jiazi* commences at the winter solstice. The *Han Records* state: Fu Xi’s composition of the *Yijing* marked the inception of yang qi, establishing it as the standard for pitch. The day of the winter solstice is governed by the Yellow Bell, the origin of sound and qi.

The *Collected Essentials of the Imperial Dynasty* states: In antiquity, the Yellow Bell was the root of all affairs. From this perspective, the nine days guiding the Qian position mark the beginning of Brahmā qi and the inception of *jiazi*. As this qi spreads, the myriad beings are equally nourished. The four seasons and their transformations—how could they lie outside the Way of this hidden-qi language? Creation itself operates thus.

The elixir of return follows the body’s cultivation of the great Brahmā. Within its hidden words are contained the Four Symbols, Five Phases, Three Origins, Eight Trigrams, sun and moon, dragon and tiger, cinnabar and mercury, lead and silver—all culminating in the *Yin Talisman*. Fire times, gentle nurturing, extraction, and replenishment depend on the hexagrams’ qi ascending and descending, the cyclical flow of *jiazi*. Without these, one gropes in vain for a standard.

Thus, the four hexagrams Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li represent Heaven, Earth, sun, and moon, encompassing the myriad things as the crucible, vessel, medicine, and pivot of the root. The remaining sixty hexagrams correspond to the *jiazi* cycle, aligning with the seasons, shifting through cold and heat, dividing into the twenty-four qi, and subdividing into the seventy-two seasonal markers. The nodes of the twelve months are condensed into a single month; the markers of a month are embedded within the twelve hours of a day and night. One fixes the water clock, corrects the sundial, clarifies *zi* and *wu*, regulates yin and yang, harmonizes darkness and dawn, unites dragon and tiger, follows the great reckoning of Heaven and Earth, and accords with the transformative mechanism of yin and yang.

Thus, the hexagrams comprise three hundred eighty-four lines, and each line contains three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. Thereby, the myriad transformations arise from the void. Is it the void that gives birth to me, or I who give birth to the void? The principle of the great Brahmā—how vast is its Way!

The ancient script was a full *zhang* in length. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign of old inscribed its text to establish the correct pronunciation. The original hidden words, each character a *zhang* wide, bore eight-pointed rays. During the Dragon Han era, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign transcribed and annotated them.

Those who know their sounds and can fast and recite them will have the flying Heavenly Deva-Kings descend to observe their person, record their merit and diligence, and report to the heavens. The myriad spirits will pay homage, earth deities will attend at the gate, and the Great Merit Demon-Kings will sponsor their promotion. Once the Dao of the Upper Immortals is complete, they may roam the Three Realms and ascend through the Golden Gate.

This sound repels all, dispels all, delivers all, and accomplishes all—it is the natural sound of the Heavenly Perfected Ones.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This boundless sound can repel and expel all demonic spirits, dissolve and avert all calamities, deliver and liberate all from birth and death, and bring to fruition all heavenly and human endeavors. Thus, it is called the *Heavenly Perfected Numinous Writ* and the *Natural Jade Characters*.

As for the Way of the Golden Elixir, it is the great Brahmā’s spontaneous primordial essence and wondrous qi, uniting with the void and merging with non-being. Those who cultivate it are observed by the myriad heavens, silently aided by the ten thousand spirits. When merit is complete and the Dao perfected, they will surely attain immortality.

The term *elixir* denotes union with the void and merging with non-being—it is fundamentally without form or substance. Those who speak falsely claim it is as large as a pellet and red as a tangerine—how utterly mistaken! They know not what the Golden Elixir truly is.

To say it is neither existent nor non-existent is also incorrect; to say it is sometimes existent and sometimes non-existent is likewise wrong; to say it is neither existent nor non-existent is still amiss. Yet if this is so, what then is it?

The Golden Elixir lodges in things to reveal its substance yet adorns things without form.

What does it mean to *lodge in things to reveal its substance*? Thus, the *Scripture of Purity* states: The Great Dao is formless yet gives birth to Heaven and Earth—though the Dao is formless, Heaven and Earth reveal its form. The Great Dao is passionless yet moves the sun and moon—though the Dao is passionless, the sun and moon reveal its passion. The Great Dao is nameless yet nurtures the myriad things—though the Dao is nameless, the myriad things reveal its name.

What does it mean to *adorn things without form*? Inwardly observe the heart: the heart has no heart—it is unattached. Thus, outwardly observe form: form has no form—it is not possessed. Thus, distantly observe things: things have no things—they are unimpeded. Thus, when this void is seen, the elixir’s Way unites with the void and merges with non-being, leaving no residue.

All arises from the body’s natural spontaneity, not through forced action. Hence, the great Brahmā’s hidden words are called the natural sound of the Heavenly Perfected Ones. Therefore, they can repel all, dispel all, deliver all, and accomplish all.

In harmony with the *Great Change*, aligned with *jiazi*, they complete creation and unite with the Golden Elixir.

*Repels all* means eternal separation from all existence.
*Dispels all* means illumination and function are all empty.
*Delivers all* means transcending birth and death.

*Accomplishes all* means the creation of Heaven and Earth. To speak briefly of the great is sufficient, for the small may then be inferred.

Thus, when one recites it, the flying immortals descend to observe below, the Celestial Emperor sings from afar, the myriad spirits pay homage, the Three Realms attend in reverence, the host of demons bow their heads, and ghostly essences vanish of themselves. The jade tablets and golden script resound—hence "jewel-like tones." The recitation and chanting of the pivotal verses—hence "vibrant resonance." The ten directions grow solemn and pure, rivers and seas fall silent, mountains and peaks swallow the mist, the ten thousand spirits tremble in submission, and the assembly of immortals is summoned.

When this is recited, the jade groves shake with celestial music, the ten directions bask in the radiance of the Three Luminaries, rivers and seas still their winds and waves, mountains and peaks inhale the clouds and mist, the ten thousand spirits are subdued in awe, and the host of immortals gathers at one’s chamber.

Heaven is free of defiling vapors, Earth is free of demonic dust. Heaven is without the qi of defilement; Earth is without the calamity of demonic dust.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When merit is complete and conduct perfected, when the Dao is achieved and virtue established, one ascends to observe the records of merit below. The Celestial Emperor sings from afar in praise. The myriad spirits pay homage in reverence. The Three Realms attend as guardians. The host of demons bow their heads, and demonic thieves submit. Ghostly essences perish of themselves, and corpse-worms are extinguished. The jewel-like tones resound—this is spontaneous resonance. The ten directions grow solemn and pure—utterly unadulterated. Rivers and seas fall silent—nature and emotion merge in darkness. Mountains and peaks swallow the mist—spirit and breath settle into stillness. The ten thousand spirits tremble in submission—the multitude of sages stand in awe. The assembly of immortals is summoned—none but the true are gathered. Heaven is free of defiling vapors—yang is without transgression. Earth is free of demonic dust—yin is without concealment. Dark wisdom illumines the pure—vast and profoundly mysterious.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This reveals the inner sound of the heavens, the power of dark penetration and luminous insight. *Dark* means profound and unfathomable; *wisdom* means illumination without limit. Wisdom can illuminate the void—hence "dark wisdom." Lofty without end is called *illuminating*; radiant throughout the Three Clarities is called *pure*. *Illuminating* is emptiness; *pure* is stillness. Boundless and limitless is called *vast capacity*. Within this vast capacity, only true emptiness exists. Within the true lies essence; within essence lies sincerity. It can generate true sages, neither existing nor non-existing, eternally serene and subtle beyond measure. To exhaust its principle is impossible. Within the mysterious lies yet deeper mystery—hence "profoundly mysterious."

The Most High, in compassion for the lower realms, bestowed this true scripture, arranging it in mysterious statutes to open the way for beings and deliver creatures. Those who recite and chant it move the heavens above, who revere and embrace its sacred text. As their qi reaches its destination, merit is perfected and conduct fulfilled, and they ascend as ministers of the Golden Towers. Thus, through accumulated study, one penetrates the true and enters sagehood, born in Heaven or born on Earth, with limitless application. Those who know the sound of the jade script will one day ascend with flesh and bone together. Scholars of the highest learning, strive diligently.

At the beginning of the Heavenly Worthy’s discourse, creation is spoken of at the outset; at the end, the Great Brahmā is spoken of in conclusion. This is how its essence and function cycle endlessly. Fearing that learners may not awaken to the principle of constant purity and stillness, falling into the views of clinging to existence or non-existence, the scripture clearly proclaims: *Dark wisdom illumines the pure, vast and profoundly mysterious.*

*Dark* means uniting with the void and merging with non-being; *wisdom* means perfect clarity and wondrous insight; *illuminating* means penetrating without obstruction; *pure* means limpid and formless. *Vast capacity* means all-embracing and beyond measure; *profoundly mysterious* means wondrous within the wondrous, beyond conception.

Thus, when speaking of dragon and tiger, one does not stagnate in manipulating essence and spirit; when discussing nature and destiny, one does not lean toward clinging to emptiness and quiescence. The ten directions are thoroughly permeated, and all eight sides are transparent. As the scripture says: *Use its light, return to its clarity*—this is the meaning.

The Dao’s relation to humanity is no less than a loving mother’s care for her infant: it shelters and sustains, gives life and nurtures. Even to the point of dividing its body and descending into the world, it establishes the warp and weft, orders ruler and subject, rectifies high and low, provides sustenance in life and burial in death. For those who stand out from the multitude, it remains with them from beginning to end. As for those who follow the world with flowery eyes, fear death, and seek immortality, it perfects them according to their learning and merit. Not a single good deed is overlooked—this may be called the ultimate.

If people could embody the Dao, all would be like the people of Huai and Getian, without need for scriptures to emerge or teachings to be established. Yet because of their lack of benevolence, I have this scripture, and thus the teachings arise, and thus they are established. Hence, there are the retributions of Heaven and Hell—this is but a provisional means to encourage good and punish evil.

Some say that with death, all ends—what else could there be? Heaven and Hell are both unreal. Such words may be penetrating, but what can be done about them? Now, after a person dies, they may appear in dreams, be seen, speak through others, or possess objects and manifest numinosity. From this, it cannot be said that with death, all ends—what else could there be? The pure caverns of spirit, the tranquil halls of the clear, the burial of white bones, the gloom of the watery prisons—these cannot be dismissed as unrealities of Heaven and Hell.

The Heavenly Worthy says: *Before beings awaken, there are karmic conditions; once beings awaken, where are the karmic conditions? Heaven and Hell—who is not a temporary convergence? These are all created by the human mind. How can one sweepingly deny cause and effect?*

The Most High ever excels at saving, yet people do not love the Dao. Thus, the scripture admonishes the worldly, urging them not to misuse their minds, to return to their nature and darken their emotions, to abandon evil and follow good. At the highest, one may transcend the ordinary and enter sagehood; next, one may dissolve transformations and ascend to the true; next, one may withdraw and attain long life. Below, one may extend years in peace and joy, never losing human form across lifetimes, nurturing the root of nature until one also attains the immortal Dao. Compared to those afflicted by illness, bound by suffering, cut off in youth, endangered, dying unnaturally, or sinking into evil destinies—who gains and who loses? The discerning will surely choose wisely.

The Celestial Qi’s Mysterious and Vast Heavenly Treasure: The Spontaneous Eightfold Harmonies
*Lower Scroll of the Numinous Writ of Primordial Commencement*
Composed by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign

**Postface Exegesis** states:
According to careful examination, *The Wondrous Scripture of the Upper Chapters on Salvation through the Numinous Treasure* was bestowed upon Emperor Wu of Han during the Yuanfeng era by the descent of the Queen Mother of the West, marking the seventh transmission. Between transmissions, the lineage remained obscure, with only this single chapter surviving among the celestial scrolls’ vast ranks. By the Jin dynasty, the Immortal Duke of the Left Palace of the Great Ultimate in Shangyu of Kuaiji, moved by the revelation of the Perfected Xu Laile of the Great Ultimate, received *The Scripture of Salvation*, which included *The Lower Scroll of the Numinous Writ* and *The Postface of the Perfected of the Great Ultimate*. These were conferred upon the assembled immortals, gathering the texts of their final dispersal to form a complete corpus. Thereafter, due to the ravages of war and fire, Ge Hong of the *Baopuzi* received the transmission from the Perfected Zheng Siyuan, though it extended no further than the *Great Measure of the Mysterious Mysterious*. The Lower Scroll was lost, rendering it irrecoverable, and thus the world lacked the complete scripture, unattainable in its entirety.

Now, as the propitious fortune flows and celestial officials descend, the missing text is appended to the scripture’s end. Those who recite and chant it attain the wondrous model of the original scripture’s two chapters and three scrolls; those who cultivate and apply it fulfill the full merit of the ten transgressions and ten directions. Through fasting and observance, one may ascend to the Upper Clarity.

*The Scripture of the Five Teeth* states:
The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s origins in the Dao remain unknown, yet he was one who perfected the ultimate Dao through cultivation in a prior kalpa. His stature measured nine feet, his body covered in dark fur, each strand over a foot long. During the Yellow Emperor’s reign, he dwelled beneath the Absolute Yin of Mount Emei, his abode wrought of azure jade, his seat of yellow gold. Banners of patterned silk fluttered, and the fragrance of thousand-fold harmony burned. Attended by immortal youths and jade maidens, with three seated guests, all styled as Perfected Kings of the Great Clarity, the Yellow Emperor bowed twice to inquire of the Dao and was granted the texts of the *Five Teeth* and *Three Ones*.

**Eastern Eight Heavens:**
Forest-dense clouds amass, nine souls refine essence.
*Jimo* gazes through jade rings, floating plumes and pestles.
Deer benches and willow chambers, azure vines coil and return.
Pool depths bear burdens, crawling creatures retreat and advance.
*Zaozhang* transforms jade, orchid pools shatter jade.
Vast surges wild-born, utmost within Kun’s clarity.
Radiance unfolds through cavernous drought, silence without the faintest congealment.
White leans on the empty net, the august reaches the primordial numen.

**Southern Eight Heavens:**
Flaming forges in spacious halls, the Great Empyrean’s jasper corners.
Through distant tides, offerings ripple, encircling seals add diagrams.
Traversing towering paths, *gudan* and *hundu* merge.
Halberds of artemisia blaze, wells deceive with rushes.
Palms maintain constricted rites, luminous brilliance cascades.
Carved threads augment but, the subtle and minute complete thunder.
Tiny streams fill the east, crimson radiance thickens.
Jade mystery evolves lords, cypress jade attains the compass.

**Western Eight Heavens:**
Refined rectitude veers left, *Poni* slays the numinous.
Sorrow summons balanced borders, extending southward to entwine the *Kui*.
Tranquil Yi diminishes light, the Primordial Awakens to conditions.
The Dao guards distant peaks, silk’s征 knows proclamation.
The Great Numen submerges in desert, radiant harmony follows *Lusui*.
Wise capitals bloom eternally, ruins and sands harden.
Chestnut bells cast out stocks, assemblies extend to *Qiupei*.
Eminent clouds of the Azure Mansion, karma beholds *Banji*.

**Northern Eight Heavens:**
Hollow children embrace sweetness, jade eaves of nine gates.
Reeds and hooks stir ripples, dragon’s *Fen* guards the numinous pass.
Ditches and abysses dissolve demons, vast barbarians pray for passage.
Mysterious desolation’s vast breath, the unknowing indulge in clarity.
Pythons cultivate auspicious evenings, fragrant altars mark the fields.
Hot springs spread prosperity, not mediocrity but reverent aid.
Morning tranquility and sagely generosity, secret methods expand fittingly.
The Vast Emperor governs life, guards the grand inception of humanity.

**Postface Exegesis** states:
This resembles the cryptic language of the Middle Scroll, lacking the Heavenly Perfected’s inner teachings found therein. Yet the Eastern character *sen* (森) derives from wood, the Southern *yan* (炎) from fire, the Western *hao* (镐) from metal, and the Northern *wa* (洼) from water and earth. Water and earth both flourish in the North, and the character *hai* (孩) combines *hai* (亥) and *zi* (子), surely relating to the wondrous principles of Heaven and Earth’s creation. Only those who attain the Dao may thoroughly comprehend these profound words.

The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s *Celestial Qi’s Mysterious and Vast Heavenly Treasure: The Spontaneous Eightfold Harmonies* governs the governance of worldly kalpas, earthly ramparts, vast marshes, calamities, and dire adversities. Those who recite it dispel demonic misfortunes, purify the Dao’s qi, and find all tranquility. Earth officials present the writ, the hundred spirits revere and respect it, divine vermilion transcribes the text, and wearing or bearing it yields evident efficacy. Applied to the utmost study, it is not proclaimed to the vulgar below.

**The Perfected of the Great Ultimate’s Hymn** states:
Divine clouds gleam in layered voids, the Brahma-net gathers in azure skies.
Primordial Commencement’s nine dragons draw the chariot, the Sovereign reins the azure carriage.
Numinous light gathers the myriad Perfected, pearl shadows open the sun’s desolation.
Revealing the Numinous Treasure’s scroll, blessings and virtue thereby summoned.
The Cavernous Mystery conceals lofty solemnity, jade tones ripple like cloud-borne zithers.
The Immeasurable defies contemplation, the Dao’s ocean births waves and billows.
Dharma principles flow like rivulets, nurturing and cultivating fine sprouts.
Applied to relieve the destitute and hungry, the teaching flourishes to guard the central court.
The Emperor’s honor endures for myriad years, Great Peace abolishes blades of war.
Bowing heads toward the Jade Dawn, numinous blossoms scatter golden rays.

**The Perfected of the Great Ultimate** states:
The Most High Lord of the Jade Dawn and Great Dao resides above the Purple Mist in the Sevenfold Radiance of Heaven, recording the mysterious writ. Jade consorts bear the scripture, golden youths scatter incense, the Great One holds the towel, jade lads attend the banquet. Dragons chant and tigers roar, auspicious clouds shroud in mist. The ten directions’ Perfected Celestial Deities, exalted sages, Perfected of Wondrous Conduct, boundless flying heavenly kings, great demons of the three realms, elders of the nine heavens, and innumerable hosts chant the Jade Scripture, taking refuge in the Most High Numinous Treasure’s wondrous Dharma. As propitious fortune flows, it endures for kalpas uncounted.

Upon completing ten recitations of the scripture, knock the teeth thirty-six times, bow in the heart to the ten directions, rise, face south to descend the seat, and stand facing east. Bow three times in the heart and secretly intone:
Your servant has completed the scripture’s recitation. The thirty-five merit officials of the body’s emanations, the attendants of the left and right, the incense-bearing golden youths, the message-transmitting jade maidens, the five emperors’ direct talismans, and the incense officials of the appointed days—thirty-two each—are entreated to return into your servant’s body and resume their places within the palace chambers, without error or confusion.

When the subsequent summons arrives, proceed in the same manner as before. Next, concentrate the mind to ensure all spirits within the body return to their respective palaces. Knock the teeth three times, swallow saliva three times, offer incense, and secretly intone:

The sacred assembly that has gathered to hear the scripture shall now dissolve the altar and disperse. May the divine winds fall silent, mountains and seas grow solemn and clear, all myriad evils hide in submission, and the hundred spirits guard this form.

Beginning from the east, visualize the Perfected of Heaven ascending, bow three times in the heart for each direction, and knock the teeth three times to send them forth. Then draw in the three-colored cloud-qi through the nose, swallow it into the five viscera, and envision the Four Celestial Beasts returning to their original positions. Knock the teeth three times and swallow saliva three times. Only then may the scripture be gathered and one exit the chamber, speech unrestrained.

Should the recitation not follow this order, it would be better left undone, lest negligence incur fault. Some may ask why alchemical principles require such observances—it is because the Dao abides both within and without, and this cannot be otherwise. May all who know this hold it in reverence and thereby summon forth fortune and virtue.

Here ends the fifth fascicle of the *Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme Scripture of Limitless Salvation by the Primordial Beginning*.

chunks.original_text: 元始无量度人上品妙经内义 经名：元始无量度人上品妙经内义。 南宋道士萧应叟撰。 五卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞真部玉诀类。 元始无量度人上品妙经内义表 臣应叟言：谨按《灵宝度人妙经》，撰着内义成书，锓木流传者。 元始祖劫，是谓先天，灵宝本章，故曰上品。 造化独还丹可拟，范围非大梵谁能？ 已遂刊行，敢忘昭告。 臣诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首。 窃惟湛湛一真，乾坤并体； 纷纷万化，生死同根。 虽云含灵有识之殊，皆本契虚合无之妙。 夫何名利勃志，意气缪心？ 源一而流分，性近而习远。 皆缘执幻，安有知常？ 五色乱目，谁肯回光？ 万变纷葩，谁能转物？ 谓壑舟藏之已固，奈曦驭驻之不留。 与其哀夭而贪生，莫若修真而重命。 故我虚皇圣主，演妙道於空劫之前； 玉晨至尊，受真诠於黍珠之内。 度人无量，介福奚穷。 顾大道无非正中，自后世因仍踳驳，观妙至为之金锁，迷源有类於盆鱼。 谈虚无清净，溺於苦空； 论砂汞铅银，执於固有。 非明祖炁之造化，曷证大梵之幽微。 按真经以为之宗，畅玄机不泄其旨。 在昔乌焉成马，未免纠纷； 於今目无全牛，触知戒止。 挽迷车而回指南之乡，障狂澜而顺从下之流，普令下民，咸跻仁寿。 恭惟太上昊天至尊玉皇上帝玉陛下，巍巍莫量，荡荡难名，大公无私，至幽靡察，利物常善救物，度人故无弃人。 遂令蕞尔之材，辄肆菲然之作。 倘有裨於万一，愿鉴勤诚；

**The Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity**

**Scripture Title:** *The Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity*
**Author:** Xiao Yingsou, a Daoist of the Southern Song Dynasty
**Volume:** Five
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongzhen* Section, *Jade Instructions* Category

---

**Memorial on the Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Infinity for the Salvation of Humanity**

Your subject, Yingsou, respectfully states: Having examined *The Wondrous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure for the Salvation of Humanity*, I have compiled its esoteric meaning into this work, carved onto wood for transmission.

The *Primordial Kalpa* is called the *Prior Heaven*; the *Root Chapter of the Numinous Treasure* is thus named the *Supreme Scripture*. Its transformative power may be likened to the solitary return of the elixir, yet who but the Great Brahmā could encompass its vastness?

Now that its publication is complete, how dare I neglect to make this solemn declaration? With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head in prostration.

I humbly reflect: The vast and undifferentiated One Reality forms the shared body of Heaven and Earth; the myriad transformations, though diverse, share the same root in life and death. Though sentient beings differ in awareness, they all fundamentally accord with the wondrous emptiness of the formless.

Yet why do fame and profit stir the will, while emotions and desires delude the mind? Though the source is one, its streams diverge; though natures are near, habits grow distant. All this arises from clinging to illusion—how can one know the Eternal? The five colors dazzle the eyes—who will turn their gaze inward? The ten thousand changes bloom in profusion—who can reverse their course?

One may fortify the valley’s boat or store treasures in the abyss, yet how can one halt the sun’s chariot from departing? Rather than lamenting early death while clinging to life, it is better to cultivate the True and honor destiny.

Thus, our August Sovereign of the Void, the Sagely Lord, expounded the wondrous Dao before the empty kalpas; the Most High Jade Clarity, the Supreme Honored One, received the true transmission within the millet-like pearl. The salvation of beings is boundless, and the blessings bestowed are inexhaustible.

Yet the Great Dao is nothing but the true mean, and later generations, through repetition and distortion, have turned the contemplation of the wondrous into golden shackles, while their confusion of the source resembles fish trapped in a basin. Discoursing on emptiness and purity, they drown in suffering and void; debating cinnabar, mercury, lead, and silver, they cling to what is fixed and substantial. Without understanding the transformative power of the *Ancestral Qi*, how can one fathom the subtle mysteries of the Great Brahmā?

Taking the true scripture as its foundation, this work elucidates the profound mechanism without divulging its essence. In former times, crows were mistaken for horses, leading to endless confusion; today, the butcher’s eye sees no whole ox, yet his touch knows restraint. Turning the wheel of delusion to point back toward the southern homeland, damming the raging waves to follow the downward flow—may all the people below ascend to benevolence and longevity.

With utmost reverence, I contemplate the Most High August Heavenly Honored One, the Jade Emperor, Your August Jade Majesty: majestic beyond measure, vast beyond naming, impartial and selfless, penetrating even the most hidden, ever benefiting beings with goodness, ever saving beings without abandoning a single one. Thus, You have permitted even one of such modest talent as I to dare compose this humble work. If it may contribute even a ten-thousandth part, I pray You deign to regard my earnest devotion.

chunks.original_text: 若无补於毫厘，冀原狂妄。 所有内义一部，分为二卷，镂版印集，申纳都省，乞赐敷奏外，谨具表上告以闻。 冒犯天威。 臣诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首。 谨言。 宝庆二年太岁丙戌七月甲寅朔初七日庚申，上清大洞玄都三景法师臣萧应叟上表。 经旨 太上者，无极至尊也，元始之始也。 即父母未生以前，一点真阳之精，二炁相感而生两肾； 两肾既生，便生两目。 然后攒簇五脏，已圆其容，方有身也。 始曰於洞。 洞者，形骸具足，降生成人，即见其身耳。 玄者，玄一之精也。 身既存，即精守於关元； 精既守於关元，则气周流； 气周流则神全耳。 神全则百窍开关，万物感矣。 眼通光，则能视万物； 鼻开孔，则能闻香气； 耳开关，则能听音声； 口通心，则能味百物。 此四者备足，则灵矣。 所谓万物之中，惟人最灵，此之谓也。 然而人灵不悟。 夫人所以长生不老者，能以一灵不泄於外。 令眼不视於色，其魂守之於肝，固木气，不泄於外； 令鼻不闻於香，则魄守於肺，固金气，不泄於外； 令耳不听於声，则精守於肾，固水气，不泄於外； 令口不言语，则神守於心，固火气，不泄於外； 令一身端坐，四大不动，则意守於脾； 固土气，不泄於外。 五方固蒂，则神气精混合为一，返本还元，归根复命，则万神会聚，化为婴儿。 弃离幻壳，出入与造物了不相干，与道合真，即宝矣。 人得此宝於身，出入纵横，飘然自在，长春不老，与天齐休。 布真炁而能化土石，土石为宝； 布真炁而能起枯骨，枯骨成人； 布真炁而能救万病，万病自痊； 布真炁而能辟妖邪，妖邪自灭； 布真炁而能动风雷，风雷自震。 布真炁而能扶万物，万物自畅； 布真炁而能拔幽魂，幽魂自拔，此即无量度人矣。 上品者，大乘之法也。 妙者，玄奥之捷也。 经者，修真之径路也。 若能口诵其经，心悟其奥，则随念有玄应耳。 至於修真学道，济生度死，无不在此矣。 密而行之，方得成道。 《灵宝妙经》义宏理奥，非钩深索隐，通玄究微者，未易窥测。 愚曰不然。 故经有云：苟得一，万事毕。 天尊岂作艰难事，以惑人乎？ 凡人日用常行，皆此经也。 善究竟者，如富贵之观饮器，虽觥觞杯斝错落盈前，知其金也。 为何难哉！ 不善观者，随器所转，得不惑欤！ 是经也，道而已； 妙谈玄理，幽演洪名，无非梵炁分根，真空阐化。 人作境会，散漫难入。 欲明是经者，莫若以我与造化同揆，彼亦如是，我亦如是，熟观谛思，必有所契。 非特此经为然； 一大藏教皆如是也。 老泉苏公有言：天之所以与我者，岂偶然哉。 夫其所以与我者，必有以用我也。 我知之不得行之，不以告人，天固用之，我实置之，其名曰弃天。 自卑以求幸其言，自小以求用其道，天之所以，与我何如？ 而我如此也，其名曰亵天。 弃天，我之罪也； 亵天，亦我之罪也。 愚每以此为戒，自惟天幸，师友琢磨，而於灵宝之宗，窃有所睹，是亦天其与我矣。 既得之，力行之，不敢弃天也。 详言之，谨藏之，不敢亵天也。 不弃不亵，游於斯，息於斯，修於斯，藏於斯，此其愿矣。 同志或知之，俾与众共，愚惧其亵天而辞焉。 彼乃曰：子不闻李光玄之事乎？ 昔光玄精勤求道，积有年矣。 一日，於少室山遇异人，告之：尔今求道，唯当提拔世人耶？

---

**Essential Meaning of the Scripture**

The Most High is the Supreme of the Boundless, the inception of the Primordial Beginning. Prior to the existence of one’s father and mother, a single spark of true yang essence—when the two *qi* interact—gives rise to the two kidneys. Once the kidneys are formed, the two eyes emerge. Then, the five viscera gather and coalesce, shaping the countenance, and only then does the body exist. This is called *the Cavern*.

*The Cavern* refers to the fully formed physical frame, the descent into birth as a human being—here, one merely perceives the body. *The Mysterious* denotes the essence of the Mysterious Unity. Once the body exists, the essence is preserved at the *Guanyuan* (Gate of Origin). When essence is preserved at *Guanyuan*, *qi* circulates throughout; when *qi* circulates, spirit is whole. With spirit whole, the hundred apertures open, and the myriad things respond.

The eyes, permeated with light, can see all things; the nose, opened to its pores, can detect fragrances; the ears, unsealed, can hear sounds; the mouth, connected to the heart, can savor all flavors. When these four are fully developed, one becomes numinous. This is what is meant by "among the ten thousand things, humans are the most numinous."

Yet humans, though numinous, fail to awaken. The reason one may attain longevity and agelessness lies in preserving the singular numinosity, preventing its dissipation outward. Let the eyes not gaze upon forms, so that the *hun*-soul guards the liver, consolidating the wood-*qi* without leakage. Let the nose not perceive fragrances, so that the *po*-soul guards the lungs, consolidating the metal-*qi* without leakage. Let the ears not heed sounds, so that essence guards the kidneys, consolidating the water-*qi* without leakage. Let the mouth not speak, so that spirit guards the heart, consolidating the fire-*qi* without leakage. Let the entire body sit upright, the four great elements unmoving, so that intent guards the spleen, consolidating the earth-*qi* without leakage.

When the five directions are firmly rooted, spirit, *qi*, and essence merge into one, returning to the origin and reverting to the root to fulfill destiny. Then, the myriad spirits gather, transforming into an infant. Abandoning the illusory husk, one moves freely without entanglement with creation, merging with the Dao in truth—this is the treasure.

One who attains this treasure within the body moves with unrestrained freedom, drifting carefree, ever-springing and ageless, sharing the same eternal rest as Heaven. By emitting true *qi*, one can transmute earth and stone into treasures; by emitting true *qi*, one can revive withered bones into living beings; by emitting true *qi*, one can cure the ten thousand ailments, and all maladies heal of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can repel malevolent spirits, and they vanish of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can stir wind and thunder, and they resound of themselves. By emitting true *qi*, one can sustain the ten thousand things, and they flourish of themselves; by emitting true *qi*, one can deliver lost souls, and they are freed of themselves—this is the boundless salvation of beings.

The highest grade is the Great Vehicle’s method. *The Wondrous* is the swift path to the profound and obscure. *The Scripture* is the road to cultivating truth. If one can recite its words and inwardly grasp its mysteries, then with every thought, there will be a mysterious response. As for cultivating truth and learning the Dao, saving the living and delivering the dead—all is contained herein. Practice it in secrecy, and one may attain the Dao.

The meaning of the *Scripture of Wondrous Treasure* is vast and its principles profound; without delving deeply, seeking the hidden, and plumbing the mysterious to its subtleties, it is not easily fathomed. Yet I say otherwise. Thus, the Scripture states: "If one attains the One, all things are complete." Would the Heavenly Worthy create arduous matters to confuse people? In all daily actions and ordinary conduct, this Scripture is present.

Those who thoroughly investigate it are like the wealthy observing drinking vessels: though goblets, cups, and chalices lie scattered before them, they know them to be gold. What difficulty is there? Those who do not observe well are led astray by the vessels—how could they not be confused?

This Scripture is simply the Dao. Its wondrous discourse on profound principles, its subtle elucidation of grand names—all are but the branching of the *fan-qi* (Brahma-*qi*) and the revelation of true emptiness. When people engage with circumstances, they scatter and find it hard to enter. To clarify this Scripture, one should measure oneself against creation: that is as it is, and I am as it is. Observe carefully and contemplate deeply, and one will surely find resonance.

Not only is this true of this Scripture; the entire canon of teachings is thus. As the elder Su of Laoquan said: "That which Heaven bestows upon me—can it be by chance? What it bestows must have a use for me. If I know it but do not practice it, nor share it with others, though Heaven intends to use it, I cast it aside—this is called abandoning Heaven. To humble oneself in seeking fortune through its words, to belittle oneself in seeking to employ its Dao—how does Heaven bestow upon me, and how do I respond thus? This is called profaning Heaven."

Abandoning Heaven is my sin; profaning Heaven is also my sin. I have always taken this as a warning. Reflecting on Heaven’s grace, the polishing of teachers and friends, and my glimpse of the essence of the *Wondrous Treasure*—this, too, is Heaven bestowing upon me. Having received it, I strive to practice it, not daring to abandon Heaven. Explaining it in detail and guarding it carefully, I dare not profane Heaven. Neither abandoning nor profaning, I wander in it, rest in it, cultivate in it, and preserve it in it—this is my aspiration.

If like-minded individuals know of it and wish to share it with others, I fear profaning Heaven and decline. They then say: "Have you not heard of Li Guangxuan’s story? Long ago, Guangxuan diligently sought the Dao for many years. One day, on Shaoshi Mountain, he encountered an extraordinary person who asked him: 'In your quest for the Dao, should you not also uplift the people of the world?'"

chunks.translated_text: "Should you only perfect yourself? If it is solely for one’s own person, even immortals would not accept it. Have you not heard of the foolish man of Song? The foolish man grew furious and guarded it all the more stubbornly. If your words are correct, then you are of the same class as Li Guangxuan; if your reasoning is flawed, then you tread the path of the foolish man of Song. If you share it with others, those of great wisdom may correct your errors, open your obstructions, and enlighten your understanding—not only benefiting others, but also bringing profound gain to you from Heaven. Though I am dull of wit, I respectfully heed these words. Thus, I have selected the commentaries of Yan, Xue, Cheng, and Li, extracting their clearest explanations, and appended the teachings of my teachers and friends beneath each line—these are the small characters in the main scroll, to clarify the meaning of the scripture. As for the principle being revealed through the image and the image being illuminated by the principle, the essence of the scripture and the cinnabar Dao being one and without distinction, I have appended the explanations of the images and recorded them afterward. chunks.original_text: 孔子曰：知我者，其惟春秋乎。 罪我者，其惟春秋乎。 宝庆二年岁在丙戌，七月甲寅朔，观复道子萧应叟识。 太极妙化神灵混洞赤文图 混洞赤文，无无上真，此所谓无极而太极也。 元始祖劫，化生诸天，开明三景，是为天根。 上无复祖，唯道为身，此所谓太极动而生阳。 动极而静，静而生阴，静极复动； 一动一静，互为其根，分阴分阳，两仪立焉。 五文开廓，此所谓阳变阴合而生水、火、木、金、土，五炁顺布，四时行焉。 五行，一阴阳也； 阴阳，一太极也。 太极本无极也，五行之生，各一其性。 普植神灵，无文不光，无文不明，无文不立，无文不成，无文不度，无文不生。 此所谓无极之真，二五之精，妙合而凝。 乾道成男，坤道成女，二炁交感，化生万物。 万物生生而变化无穷焉。 学者当究其辞、索其意，则先天之道不谋而契，造化之妙可得而窥。 故儒者知幽明之故，周乎万物，原始反终，穷理尽性，得不怵死生之妙。 老氏则曰：深根固蒂，长生久视。 盖各有所宗也。 夫如是，何以致之？

Confucius said: "Those who understand me do so through the *Spring and Autumn Annals*; those who condemn me do so through the *Spring and Autumn Annals*."

In the second year of the Baoqing reign, cyclical year *bingxu*, on the first day of the seventh month, the *jiayin* day, recorded by Xiaoying the Daoist of Guanfu.

**Chart of the Wondrous Transformations of the Supreme Ultimate and the Numinous Chaos of the Vermilion Writ of Hun Dun**

The Vermilion Writ of *Hun Dun*—the Non-Ultimate’s Supreme Perfection—is what is called "the Non-Ultimate and yet the Supreme Ultimate." At the primordial beginning of the ancestral kalpa, it gave birth to the myriad heavens, unfolding the Three Luminaries, thus becoming the root of Heaven. With no ancestor beyond itself, its body is the Dao alone—this is what is meant by "the Supreme Ultimate moves and generates yang." When movement reaches its limit, it becomes still; stillness generates yin; when stillness reaches its limit, it moves again. One movement, one stillness, each the root of the other. Yin and yang divide, and the Two Modes are established.

The Five Scripts unfold and expand—this is what is meant by "yang transforms, yin conjoins, and water, fire, wood, metal, and earth are born." The five *qi* flow in sequence, and the four seasons proceed. The Five Phases are one yin-yang; yin-yang is one Supreme Ultimate. The Supreme Ultimate is fundamentally the Non-Ultimate. The generation of the Five Phases, each with its own nature.

Universally planting the numinous, without script there is no illumination, no clarity, no establishment, no completion, no deliverance, no generation. This is what is meant by "the true of the Non-Ultimate, the essence of the Two and Five, wondrously conjoined and congealed." The Way of Qian forms the male; the Way of Kun forms the female. The two *qi* interact and transform, giving birth to the myriad things. The myriad things, endlessly generating and transforming, are inexhaustible.

The scholar must investigate its words and seek its meaning, then the Way of Prior Heaven will unconsciously align, and the wondrous workings of creation may be glimpsed. Thus, the Confucian, knowing the causes of the hidden and the manifest, encompasses the myriad things, traces beginnings to return to endings, exhausts principle and fulfills nature, and attains the wondrous mystery beyond life and death. Laozi, however, says: "Deeply root, firmly stem, for long life and enduring vision." Each has its own tradition.

If this is so, how then is it to be achieved?
