The *Inner Meaning* states: In the midst of practicing the work, wondrous responses are indescribable—like one who drinks water, knowing its warmth or coolness for oneself. When the work is complete, the myriad spirits return to their origin, and within the state of *huanghu*, luminosity is forgotten and reflection ceases.

At this time, when heavenly beings and humans encounter the scriptural Dharma, all universally receive deliverance, preserving their allotted years without harm or injury. The *Inner Meaning* states: Examining the past and mirroring the present, the principle is not distant. The scriptural Dharma and the Dao of the elixir share a single principle without distinction. The Sixth Patriarch said: "My expounding of the Dharma is like the timely rain, universally moistening the earth. Your buddha-nature is like seeds—when they encounter this moisture, all sprout and grow." This is the principle of encountering the scriptural Dharma and universally receiving deliverance. The inner symbolic workings of the body embody this meaning.

Those who attain it know its spirit and cherish it, understand its *qi* and treasure it. Thus, they may preserve their allotted years without harm or injury. "Allotted years" means avoiding untimely death. As for the single step beyond, one should advance further. The world turns in reverence, and all cultivate a heart of goodness: refraining from killing or harming, from envy or jealousy, from licentiousness or theft, from greed or desire, from hatred or resentment; speaking without embellishment, uttering no evil words; equalizing kindness and love, transforming even strangers into kin.

The *Severing Destiny* states: Harming through killing or injury is called "harm"; resenting others for surpassing oneself is called "envy"; hating one’s peers is called "jealousy"; male and female engaging improperly is called "licentiousness"; stealing others’ possessions is called "theft"; insatiability is called "greed"; indulgence in cravings is called "desire"; disliking others is called "hatred"; suspicion is called "resentment." When the ten evils are extinguished, even strangers become kin, and when the myriad practices are mystically aligned, voices carry no strife.

The section on licentiousness refers to improper conduct between men and women, for the purpose of rectifying human relationships. For those cultivating the Way, it must be entirely abandoned. Thus, the *Supreme Mystery Numinous Writ* places licentious desire at the head of the ten defeats. Formerly, the Purple Void Primordial Lady and Lord Mao examined the gains and losses of perfected immortals under heaven—forty-seven fell in rank, while only two ascended. This was because they harbored desires for licentiousness while practicing the Way of the Supreme Perfected. Not only did they fall, but they were also subject to judgment by the Three Officials. Those seeking long life—how could they not sever such thoughts?

The section on theft does not only mean stealing others’ possessions; any acquisition not obtained by proper means is theft. The section on desire does not only mean indulgence in cravings; it refers to selfishness. The Most High said: "No sin is greater than what desire makes permissible; no fault is greater than covetousness." When the heart of desire stirs, the self arises, and from this, all the aforementioned evils follow, leading to the corruption of state governance and the loss of peace among the multitudes. Can the heart that seeks profit not be guarded against?

The *Inner Meaning* states: The human heart is inherently good, without anything inherently evil. Yet, it is obscured by material desires, dimming its original nature. Upon hearing the essentials of the Dao, all evils melt like ice, and self and others become one, with no barrier between close and distant. The matters described above are elaborated in detail in the *Treatise on Responses and Retributions*—they are the daily missteps of worldly people. The Shu scholar Li Changling’s explanation of karmic causes and conditions spans over a hundred thousand words; reading it sends a chill down the spine, so that not even the slightest selfish thought dares arise in the mind. It is of great benefit to the teachings of the world.

Carefully observing the scriptural intent, the phrase "all cultivate a heart of goodness, refraining from killing or harming, and so on" means the complete absence of evil thoughts. If even the faintest evil thought lingers in the heart, it cannot be called good. Why? Can jade with the slightest flaw still be called fine jade? Good and evil do not wait to manifest in action; the moment a thought arises, the divine records it.

Formerly, Wei Zhongda, a court academician, was summoned to the netherworld. The nether official ordered the clerks to present his records of good and evil. When they arrived, the evil record filled the courtyard, while the good record was as thin as a chopstick. The nether official changed countenance and ordered a scale to weigh them. The small scroll of good deeds outweighed the evil record, shaking the earth. The official then joyfully said: "You may depart." Wei said: "I am not yet forty—how could I have committed so many evils?" The official replied: "Not so. Any improper thought is recorded; it does not wait for a transgression." Wei asked: "Then what is recorded on the small scroll?" The official said: "The court once undertook a great construction project to repair the stone bridge of Three Mountains. You submitted a memorial to admonish and stop it—this is the draft of that memorial." Wei said: "Though I submitted it, the court did not heed it. What benefit did it bring, that it could have such power?" The official said: "Though the court did not heed it, the thought in your heart was already sufficient. Had they listened, your merit would have been far greater. You would have immediately attained liberation from the world—how could you have been summoned here? Alas, your evil thoughts were too numerous, reducing your merit by half. You can no longer hope for a high position."

Alas! Even empty thoughts diminish fortune—how much more so for actual transgressions. The retributions of good and evil are too numerous to record entirely, but observing Fan Wenzheng’s account of Dou the Remonstrator’s *Record of Hidden Virtues* suffices to know that goodness is attainable.

Some may ask: "Though I treat others with goodness, if they repay me with evil, how can I remain at peace?" Not so. If one knows the words of the Red Lord of Southern Marchmount, the *qi* will naturally be at peace. The Red Lord of Southern Marchmount said: "If others bring misfortune upon me, but I respond with fortune, then the *qi* of fortune and virtue will always arise within me, while the *qi* of harm and calamity will naturally befall them." This is the great practice of those who study the Dao. Could the Red Lord of Southern Marchmount deceive others?

chunks.original_text: 国安民丰，欣乐太平。 此乃咸行善心之所致也。 《内义》曰：按老君授干吉真人太平之道，其要曰，夫人之生也，天付之神，地付之精，中和付之炁； 人能保精爱神护炁，内则保身长生，外则致国太平。 又曰：人臣之行，当上爱其君，欲其长生。 为人子者，当念父母，畏其将死，风化其意，使之入道，常为求索奇方殊术，以奉君亲。 为人弟子者，当念录师恩。 夫人生於父母，成道德於师，得尊荣於君。 每念君、父、师，将老无以复，或行学更事，贤明求奇方异法而资益之，此乃应太古上皇最善忠臣、孝子、顺弟子也。 人皆为之，则天下太平矣。 夫有其内，必有其外，故善行着而谓之福，神性明而谓之慧。 福慧双修，内外兼济。 则国犹身也，民犹炁也，国则有君，身则有心。 君治则民安，心正则炁和。 经曰：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正，我无事而民自富，我无欲而民自朴。 治国修心，其政一也。 经始出教一国，以道预有至心，宗奉礼敬，皆得度世。 《内义》曰：经出教立，人依道行，预之为言，先也、前也。 人禀道炁而生，是心宁无有乎？ 盖由耽着幻妄，迷昧昏蒙，一遇经法，此心复明，谓如今之指出丹体，乃人人本来之物，非昔无而今有。 虽得之於闻经闻道之后，实先有於闻经闻道之前，故曰：预有至心也。 所谓宗者，祖其道也。 奉者，崇其文也。 礼者，尊其法也。 敬者，钦其德也。 故《本起经》云：夫为道者，当知道德经行之法； 道谓路，道德谓善功； 经谓径路，行谓行步，法谓有成。 道经可修而得道也，谓有成道路可随而行之也。 人能依是而行，必皆得度世矣。 道言：元始天尊说经中所言，并是诸天上帝内名隐韵之音，即天帝玉字内音是也。 亦是魔王内讳、百灵之隐名也，非世之常辞。 《内义》曰：所谓上帝内名隐韵、魔王内讳、百灵隐名者，亦如《丹经》云：日魂月魄，庚虎甲龙，水银朱砂，红铅黑锡，黄芽白雪，姹女婴儿，黄婆金公，炉灶鼎器之类。 虽名殊号异，并是先天一炁，非别阴杂之物也。 上圣已成真人，通玄究微。 《内义》曰：上圣修行妙道，已得成功。 真人洞明奥旨，识达玄微。 盖有实用，非执虚文。 如混洞赤文，元始祖劫开明三景，大行梵炁，皆知其底蕴，得其要机，则天地造化之妙、生死有无之理，都在睫前，不远身外也。 能悉其章，诵之十过， 《内义》曰：既能通玄究微，则能知其道，十过之效，功齐元始。 以丹而言，十过者，功则十月入室，理则九转。 诸天遥唱，赞其功。 万帝设礼。

When the state is secure and the people prosper, all rejoice in great peace—this is the result of universally cultivating a heart of goodness.

The *Inner Meaning* states: According to what the Most High Lord Lao conferred upon the Perfected Gan Ji as the Way of Great Peace, its essential teaching is this: when a person is born, Heaven bestows spirit upon them, Earth bestows essence, and the harmonious center bestows *qi*. If one can preserve essence, cherish spirit, and safeguard *qi*, then inwardly one preserves the body and attains long life, while outwardly one brings the state to great peace.

It further states: The conduct of a minister should be to love their ruler above all, desiring their long life. As a child, one should think of their parents, fearing their mortality, and transform their intentions through moral influence, guiding them into the Dao, constantly seeking rare formulas and extraordinary arts to offer to ruler and kin. As a disciple, one should remember the kindness of their teacher. A person is born of their parents, their virtue and power are perfected by their teacher, and they attain honor through their ruler. Ever mindful of ruler, father, and teacher—when they grow old and can no longer repay them—one may study further, seek wise counsel, and obtain rare formulas and wondrous methods to benefit them. Such is the most excellent loyal minister, filial child, and obedient disciple of the High Antiquity and August Sovereign. If all people act thus, the world will be at great peace.

What is within must manifest without: thus, virtuous conduct becomes visible as good fortune, and the clarity of the spirit-nature is called wisdom. Cultivating both fortune and wisdom, inwardly and outwardly, one achieves mutual fulfillment. The state is like the body, the people like *qi*; the state has its ruler, the body its heart. When the ruler governs well, the people are at peace; when the heart is upright, *qi* is harmonious.

The *Classic* says: "If I practice non-action, the people transform themselves; if I love stillness, the people rectify themselves; if I am without affairs, the people enrich themselves; if I am without desire, the people become simple." Governing the state and cultivating the heart share the same principle.

When the *Classic* first emerged to instruct a single state, those who approached it with utmost sincerity, revered its teachings, honored its rituals, and respected its virtue all attained deliverance from the world.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the *Classic* is revealed and teachings are established, people follow the Dao in practice. The word "approach" (*yu*) means "beforehand" or "in advance." People are born endowed with the *qi* of the Dao—how could their hearts be without it? Yet, deluded by illusory attachments, they sink into confusion and darkness. Upon encountering the *Classic* and its teachings, this heart regains clarity, like pointing out the cinnabar elixir—it is each person’s original possession, not something that was absent before and now exists. Though obtained after hearing the *Classic* and the Dao, it was already present before such hearing. Hence, it is said: "approaching with utmost sincerity."

"Revering" (*zong*) means taking the Dao as one’s ancestor. "Upholding" (*feng*) means exalting its texts. "Ritual" (*li*) means honoring its methods. "Respect" (*jing*) means venerating its virtue.

Thus, the *Sutra of Origins* states: Those who practice the Dao should know the methods of the Way, virtue, *Classic*, and conduct. The Way is the path; virtue and power are good works; the *Classic* is the direct path; conduct is the steps taken; method is completion. The Way and *Classic* can be cultivated to attain the Dao—there is a completed path to follow.

If people act accordingly, all will attain deliverance from the world.

The Dao says: What the Most High Heavenly Worthy expounds in the *Classic* consists entirely of the hidden rhymes of the inner names of the Celestial Emperors—these are the inner sounds of the Jade Characters of the Heavenly Emperor. They are also the inner taboo names of demon kings and the hidden names of the hundred spirits, not ordinary words of the world.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The so-called inner names of the Celestial Emperors, hidden rhymes, inner taboo names of demon kings, and hidden names of the hundred spirits are like what the *Elixir Classic* describes: solar soul and lunar spirit, Metal Tiger and Wood Dragon, mercury and cinnabar, red lead and black tin, yellow sprout and white snow, the maiden and the infant, the yellow woman and the golden lord, the furnace and the cauldron. Though their names and designations differ, all are the primordial unity of *qi*, not separate yin or miscellaneous things.

The highest sages who have attained perfection as Perfected Ones penetrate the profound and fathom the subtle.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The highest sages who cultivate the wondrous Dao have already achieved success. The Perfected Ones thoroughly understand the profound principles and comprehend the mysteries. Their practice is substantive, not clinging to empty texts. For example, the *Red Writ of Chaos*, the Three Luminaries revealed by the Primordial Ancestor at the dawn of kalpas, and the great circulation of Brahman *qi*—they know their depths and grasp their essential mechanisms. Thus, the wonders of Heaven and Earth’s creation, the principles of life and death, being and non-being, all lie before their eyes, not far from the body.

If one can master its chapters and recite them ten times,

The *Inner Meaning* states: Having penetrated the profound and fathomed the subtle, one can know the Dao. The effect of ten recitations equals the merit of the Primordial Ancestor. In terms of the elixir, ten recitations correspond to ten months in the chamber in practice, and nine revolutions in principle.

chunks.original_text: 尊其经。 河海静默， 周公居政，海不扬波。 真人诵经，河清海晏。 事殊理一，功异德同。 山岳藏云。 蓄云为雨，泽及万物。 日月停景，璇玑不行。 十过之效，功齐元始，此之谓也。 群魔束形，鬼精灭爽。 经谓束，送妖魔精，斩馘六鬼锋是也。 回尸起死，白骨成人。 老君起徐甲枯骨是也。 《内义》曰：诸天遥唱，万帝设礼者，《庄子》所谓澹然无极，而众美从之，天地之德，圣人之道者也。 河海静默者，爱河苦海也。 皆人之心妄幻所有，爱从情生，苦由识致。 既已德合天地，道同圣真，则爱河静息，苦海渊默。 山岳藏云者，《黄庭经》曰：五岳之云炁，彭亨即五脏云炁也。 真人者，其息深深，五脏炁盈，如山岳之蓄云也。 日月，两目也。 景，光也。 光即神也。 真人神不外驰，目虽视物而凝然之不动，故曰停景。 璇玑，斗极也。 人心象之极者，旋而不移，视而察之，似若不动。 真人者，任其自然，心虽应物而湛然常寂，故曰不行也。 群魔者，纷纭万绪，惑乱我心者也。 既任其自然，则应之若无事，是谓束形也。 鬼精者，三尸也。 三尸不去，道无由而成。 能体纯素，三尸自绝，故谓灭爽也。 回尸起死，白骨成人者，丹成之士，非特独善其身，更宜推功及物，故净明法云：吾丹既成，变化自在。 所不足者，上帝之诏未至，於是积功以期真命焉。 凡群品有善，可与延年益算。 不幸病死者，救以活之，如吴猛真君起于庆之死是也。 至学之士， 至学之士，心坚如铁石，操列於水火，天地不能逾，鬼神不能惑，行人之所不能行，太极之上，有真名者也。 又至学者，不待念起事至而后学，故能於有念无念，有事无事之间力行也。 此之真人，抑又次焉。 诵之十过，则五帝侍卫，三界稽首。 此经乃妙炁结成灵文，是为万炁之宗，在处有五行之炁，从之五炁之神，谓之帝。 故曰五帝侍卫。 季康子问五帝於孔子，孔子答：以五行佐成上帝，而称五帝。 三界者，即三界大魔也。 至学之笃行积功立，三界魔王保而敬之，故曰三界稽首也。 魔精丧眼，鬼妖灭爽。 大魔既已保敬，鬼神焉敢正视，亦束形灭爽之理也。 济度垂死，绝而得生。 《内义》曰：五帝，五脏之神也。 肝魂、肺魄、心神、肾精、脾意； 此五者，若人恬淡则神定魂清，意安魄宁，精不走失。 若人躁竞，则神疲魂浊，意乱魄散，精逐溃耗。 夫人非不欲安而寿，然而日日应酬，神稍疲倦，则三尸九虫作我蠡贼。 所以绛宫之真，为其所扰； 修炼之士，则尸虫消绝；

Revere this scripture. When rivers and seas lie in silent stillness, even as the Duke of Zhou governed the realm, the seas did not stir their waves. When the Perfected recite the scripture, the Yellow River runs clear and the seas remain serene. Though the affairs differ, the principle is one; though the merits vary, their virtue is the same.

Mountains and peaks store clouds. They gather clouds to bring forth rain, nourishing the myriad beings. Sun and moon halt their radiance; the celestial pivot ceases its turning. The effect of ten recitations equals the merit of the Primordial Ancestor—this is what is meant.

All demons bind their forms; ghostly spirits perish in clarity. The scripture speaks of binding: dispatching demonic spirits and beheading the six ghostly blades. Reviving the dead from corpses, transforming white bones into living beings—such was Lord Lao’s restoration of Xu Jia’s withered bones.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the myriad heavens sing from afar and the ten thousand emperors prepare rites, this is what *Zhuangzi* calls “tranquil and boundless, with all beauties following in its wake”—the virtue of Heaven and Earth, the Dao of the sage. The “silent stillness of rivers and seas” refers to the River of Love and the Sea of Suffering, both born of the illusory delusions of the human heart. Love arises from emotion; suffering stems from perception. Once one’s virtue harmonizes with Heaven and Earth and one’s Dao aligns with the sagely Perfected, the River of Love falls silent and the Sea of Suffering lies profoundly still.

“Mountains and peaks store clouds” refers to what the *Huangting Jing* calls “the cloud-*qi* of the Five Peaks”—here, the expansive *qi* of the five viscera. The Perfected, whose breath is deep and serene, fill their five viscera with *qi*, like mountains gathering clouds.

“Sun and moon” are the two eyes; “radiance” is their light, which is spirit. When the Perfected’s spirit does not stray outward, their eyes, though observing things, remain unmoving—hence “halting their radiance.” The “celestial pivot” is the Dipper’s handle. The human heart, mirroring this axis, turns yet does not shift; though it observes and examines, it seems motionless. The Perfected, following nature, respond to things while remaining profoundly still—hence “ceases its turning.”

“All demons” are the myriad distractions that confuse and disturb the heart. When one follows nature, responding as if to nothing, this is called “binding their forms.” “Ghostly spirits” are the Three Corpses. If the Three Corpses do not depart, the Dao cannot be achieved. By embodying purity, the Three Corpses naturally perish—hence “perishing in clarity.”

“Reviving the dead from corpses, transforming white bones into living beings”: Those who attain the elixir not only perfect themselves but must extend their merit to others. As the *Pure Brightness* method states: “Once my elixir is complete, transformation is effortless. What remains lacking is the Celestial Mandate; thus, one accumulates merit to await the true decree.” For all beings of good conduct, one may prolong their years and increase their lifespan. If misfortune strikes and they fall ill or die, one revives them—such was the case when the Perfected Lord Wu raised Yu Qing from the dead.

The most devoted scholars—those whose hearts are firm as iron and stone, whose conduct stands unshaken by water or fire, whom neither Heaven and Earth can surpass nor ghosts and spirits delude, who walk paths others cannot tread—are those whose true names reside above the Great Ultimate. Yet even more advanced are those who do not wait for thoughts to arise or affairs to arrive before practicing, but instead cultivate diligently in the spaces between thought and no-thought, action and inaction. Such Perfected are of a slightly lesser rank.

After ten recitations, the Five Emperors stand guard, and the Three Realms bow in reverence. This scripture is formed of wondrous *qi*, coalescing into numinous text—the ancestral origin of the ten thousand *qi*. Wherever the *qi* of the Five Phases resides, the spirits of the Five *Qi* follow, known as the Emperors. Thus, “the Five Emperors stand guard.” When Ji Kangzi asked Confucius about the Five Emperors, Confucius replied: “They assist the Supreme Emperor, governing as the Five Emperors.”

The “Three Realms” are the great demons of the Three Realms. When the most devoted scholars accumulate merit through steadfast practice, the demon kings of the Three Realms protect and revere them—hence “the Three Realms bow in reverence.” Demonic spirits lose their sight; ghostly beings perish in clarity. Once the great demons offer protection and reverence, how dare ghosts and spirits meet their gaze? This is the principle of binding forms and extinguishing clarity.

Saving those on the verge of death, restoring life where it has been severed.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The Five Emperors are the spirits of the five viscera—liver-soul, lung-po, heart-spirit, kidney-essence, and spleen-intent. When one is tranquil, the spirit is settled, the soul clear, the intent at peace, the po composed, and essence unlost. But when one is restless and competitive, the spirit tires, the soul grows turbid, the intent scatters, the po disperses, and essence dissipates in ruin.

Though all desire peace and longevity, daily affairs weary the spirit, allowing the Three Corpses and Nine Worms to become thieves within. Thus, the true *qi* of the Crimson Palace is disturbed. For those who cultivate the elixir, the corpse-worms vanish entirely.

chunks.original_text: 五脏之神，各安其职，故曰侍卫也。 三界，三尸也。 乃人身三部阴浊昏邪之气，以属三徒之界。 上尸彭踞居人头，中尸彭踬居人肠，下尸彭蹻居人足。 人之嗜欲贪淫，种种不善之事，皆尸鬼所使，至於庚申之日，则诣天曹，言人罪过，毫发不遗。 欲人速死，彼则欣跃。 故葛稚川曰：子能绝三彭之仇乎？ 三彭者，三尸也。 除绝之法极多，备载《道藏》庚申部。 然不若金丹为妙。 古诗曰：穷尽世间无限法，除非丹药杀三尸。 张真人曰：由来庚甲申明令，杀尽三尸道可期。 此乃铸恶成仁，化顽从善，被其制伏，故曰稽首也。 魔精鬼妖者，乃九虫六贼之类。 三尸是渠魁，虫贼是徒伴，剿其渠魁则徒伴自溃，故曰丧眼灭爽也。 若然者，故能延垂死之年，续已绝之命，则神炁壮盛，学者勉而行之，其功不言可知矣。 所以尔者，学士秽气未消，体未洞真，召制十方，威未制天政。 德可伏御地祇，束缚魔灵，但却死而已，不能更生。 《内义》曰：学者欲心未绝，性理未明，探炼虽勤，玄虚未达，只可保神啬炁，制伏阴魔，驻景延年，辟却疾病。 长生之道，未可冀矣。 轻诵此章，身则被殃。 谓不整形服，不按科仪，行立眠卧，聊耳诵念。 若夫诵而不敬，不若不诵而敬矣。 《内义》曰：轻诵此章，谓轻行是道。 夫金丹之要，全在燮调，首则动於采取，次则戒於持盈，以俟鼎器圆成，药物全备，则运符进火，添抽汞铅，时晷相符，节侯无爽。 故得阴阳炁足，离坎珠圆，神化成真，长生久视。 若乃情躁心怠，妄作谩为，纬候相差，符节不应，则隆冬大暑，盛夏严霜，姹女逃亡，赤龙奔逸。 神精既失，金液难求，气索体赢，形衰身殁矣。 供养尊礼，门户兴隆。 世世昌炽，与善因缘。 万灾不干，神明护门。 《内义》曰：若修行笃敬，外则宅合昌盛，内则身心安宁。 日新其德，动与吉会，祸患无侵，神明卫护。 斯经尊妙，独步玉京。 度人无量，为万道之宗。 巍巍大范，德难可胜。 《内义》曰：《七签经教部》云，夫三洞者，盖是一乘之妙旨，三境之玄言。 了达则上圣可登，晓悟则高真斯陟。 龙章凤篆，显至理之良诠，玉简金书，引还源之要术。 所谓斯经尊妙，独步玉京者，又为三洞之冠矣。 从古至今，仙真上圣未有不由是而修证者。 录籍具载，莫知几何。 万法千门，靡不出此。 巍巍荡荡，非可以名言思议。 道言：凡诵是经十过，诸天齐到，亿曾万祖，幽魂苦爽，皆即受度，上升朱宫。 凡诵者不限高下之格，是能依法精心诵持十过者，则诸天齐到，众圣降集於房庙，拔祖襧之幽魂，及昆宗之苦爽，下离北府，上入南宫也。 格皆九年，受化更生，得为贵人，而好学至经功满德就，皆得神仙。 飞升金阙，游宴玉京也。 格皆九年者，即九年之格，法三火之数，三三如九。 朱宫是南方属火，以火炼形，故云三火。 九年受其炼化，然后更生贵族。 生则便修此经，昔需习之仍在，万徧之功既满，三千之德复圆，遂超然升度，径得神仙，登金阙而事圣君，游玉京而谒元始。 按《三元品诫》朱陵度人之格有三等。 大福三年，中福九年，小福二十四年。 九年者，约中福之格也。 《内义》曰：此言十过者，则月之理也。 诸天齐到者，万神混归元一也。

The spirits of the five viscera each fulfill their duties, thus they are called "attendants and guardians." The Three Realms are the Three Corpses—these are the turbid, murky, and perverse *qi* of the three divisions of the human body, belonging to the realms of the three malefactors. The Upper Corpse, Peng Ju, dwells in the head; the Middle Corpse, Peng Zhi, dwells in the intestines; the Lower Corpse, Peng Qiao, dwells in the feet. All human cravings, lusts, and myriad unwholesome deeds are instigated by these corpse-demons. On the day of *gengshen*, they ascend to the Heavenly Bureau to report one’s transgressions, omitting not even the slightest fault. They delight in hastening a person’s death. Thus, Ge Zhichuan said: "Can you sever the enmity of the Three Peng?" The Three Peng are the Three Corpses. Methods to eradicate them are numerous, fully recorded in the *Daoist Canon* under the *Gengshen* section. Yet none compare to the marvel of the Golden Elixir. An ancient poem states: "Of all the boundless methods in the world, only the elixir can slay the Three Corpses." Master Zhang the Perfected said: "Since ancient times, the *geng* and *jia* days enforce the decree; slay the Three Corpses, and the Dao may be attained." This is the transformation of evil into benevolence, the subjugation of the stubborn to goodness. Thus, they are made to bow in submission. As for demonic essences and spectral apparitions—these belong to the Nine Worms and Six Thieves. The Three Corpses are their ringleaders; the worms and thieves, their followers. Destroy the ringleaders, and the followers scatter of themselves. Hence, it is said: "their eyes are extinguished, their clarity lost."

Thus, one may prolong the years of those on the verge of death and restore life where it has been severed. The spirit and *qi* grow robust and flourishing. Scholars, exert yourselves in this practice—its merit is self-evident.

The reason for this is that when a scholar’s impure *qi* has not yet dissipated and their body has not attained true transparency, their summons may command the ten directions, yet their authority does not govern the celestial administration. Their virtue may subdue earthly spirits and bind demonic spirits, but this only averts death—it does not restore life. The *Inner Meaning* states: If a scholar’s desires remain unsevered and their nature and principle are not yet illuminated, though they diligently explore and refine, they will not penetrate the mysteries of the void. They may only preserve the spirit, husband the *qi*, subdue yin demons, prolong their years, and ward off illness. The Way of long life remains beyond their hope.

To recite this chapter lightly brings misfortune upon oneself. This refers to failing to rectify one’s form and attire, neglecting the rituals and protocols, reciting casually whether standing, sitting, lying, or walking. If one recites without reverence, it would be better not to recite at all. The *Inner Meaning* states: "To recite this chapter lightly" means to treat the Dao with frivolity. The essence of the Golden Elixir lies wholly in harmonious regulation. First, one must act in gathering and refining; next, one must be vigilant in maintaining fullness, awaiting the completion of the crucible and the readiness of the medicinal ingredients. Then, one advances the talismanic fire, regulates the withdrawal and addition of mercury and lead, aligning the hours and seasons without error. Thus, the *qi* of yin and yang becomes abundant, the pearl of *Li* and *Kan* is perfected, the spirit transforms into the true, and one attains long life and enduring vision.

If, however, one is hasty in emotion and negligent in heart, acting recklessly and carelessly, the celestial cycles fall out of alignment, the talismanic nodes fail to correspond—then scorching heat arises in midwinter, bitter frost in midsummer, the Maiden of Cinnabar flees, the Crimson Dragon bolts. The spirit and essence are lost, the golden liquid is unattainable, the *qi* is exhausted, the body emaciated, the form declines, and life perishes.

Through reverent offering and solemn ritual, the household flourishes. Generation after generation prospers, bound to good causes. Myriad calamities do not encroach; divine luminaries guard the gate. The *Inner Meaning* states: If one cultivates with earnest reverence, externally, the household thrives; internally, body and mind find peace. Daily, one’s virtue is renewed, and every action meets with good fortune. Disasters do not intrude; divine luminaries provide protection.

This scripture is exalted and wondrous, unmatched in the Jade Capital. It delivers countless beings and serves as the origin of the myriad Daoist ways. Its majestic model is of virtue beyond measure. The *Inner Meaning* states: The *Seven Bamboo Slips of the Scriptural Teachings* states: "The Three Caverns are the wondrous essence of the One Vehicle, the profound words of the Three Realms. Those who comprehend them may ascend as supreme sages; those who awaken to them may rise as lofty perfected ones. Dragon scripts and phoenix seals reveal the finest explications of the supreme principle; jade tablets and golden books guide the essential techniques for returning to the source." Thus, this scripture is called "exalted and wondrous, unmatched in the Jade Capital," for it is the crown of the Three Caverns. From ancient times to the present, no immortal, perfected one, or supreme sage has not relied upon it for cultivation and realization. Records and registers abound—none can count their number. The myriad methods and thousand gates all emerge from this. Vast and boundless, it transcends naming, thought, and discussion.

The Dao states: Whoever recites this scripture ten times will have all the heavens arrive, and the suffering souls of billions of ancestors will immediately receive deliverance, ascending to the Vermilion Palace. There is no distinction of high or low in recitation. Those who, in accordance with the method, recite with a concentrated mind ten times will have all the heavens arrive, and the host of sages descend and gather in their ancestral temple. They will rescue the suffering souls of their ancestors and the afflicted spirits of their clan, lifting them from the Northern Mansion and ushering them into the Southern Palace. After nine years of refinement, they will be transformed and reborn, becoming noble persons. Those who love learning, fulfill the scripture’s merit, and perfect their virtue will all attain divine transcendence, ascending to the Golden Gates and roaming the Jade Capital.

The "nine years" refers to the nine-year refinement, following the number of the Three Fires—three times three makes nine. The Vermilion Palace belongs to the south, which pertains to fire. Refining the form with fire is thus called the Three Fires. After nine years of refinement and transformation, one is then reborn into nobility. Upon birth, one immediately cultivates this scripture. The former practice remains, and when the merit of ten thousand recitations is complete and the virtue of three thousand is restored, one transcends and ascends, directly attaining divine transcendence. They ascend to the Golden Gates to serve the Sage Lord and roam the Jade Capital to pay homage to the Primordial Beginning.

According to the *Three Primal Commandments*, the standards for deliverance in the Vermilion Numinosity include three grades: great fortune requires three years, medium fortune nine years, and lesser fortune twenty-four years. The nine years here correspond to the medium fortune standard. The *Inner Meaning* states: "Ten times" refers to the principle of the lunar month. "All the heavens arrive" means the myriad spirits merge into the primordial unity.

chunks.original_text: 亿曾万祖，乃父母假合之物； 幽魂苦爽，即有身之后，昏浊之炁，皆即受度。 上升朱宫者，乃炼化假合昏浊之气，超入灵明炳焕之域。 格皆九年受化更生。 得为贵人者，谓融炼假合昏浊之气，俱化阳神，更生真炁，万神为一神，万炁为一炁，长养圣胎也。 学士到此地位，已得神全炁足，延生长年，所谓仙者未可言也。 故曰：而好学至经，功满德就，皆得神仙，更须进修，内功成就，德行庶可以冀。 内功者，火候脱胎神化之道。 修行之法详着于后。 德行者，要在济物利人，如汉天师区别人鬼，葛仙翁普度幽魂，许真君诛剪蛟蛇是矣。 经云：学者虽守道，不作功德，亦不能得道。 昔汉天师丹成未服，谓王长真人曰：神丹成就，若服饵之，当必冲天，便为真人。 然吾未有大德，宜须为国为民、除害兴利，后可服丹轻举上升。 臣事三境则无愧矣。 如是，方能飞升金阙，游宴玉京也。 上学之士，修诵是经，皆即受度，飞升南宫。 上学者闻道勤行，见法必学，始终不替，寒暑无亏，此太清九宫以下有仙名者。 既修诵此经，使身得道而飞升仙域，受炼南宫朱陵之府。 夫魂魄升仙，则火炼鬼质； 生舟得道，则火炼垢秽，是故皆入南宫； 然后登真本位矣。 世人受诵，则延寿长年，后皆得作尸解之道，魂神暂灭，不经地狱，即得返形，游行太空。 世人即常流之人，非出群之士。 既以祖因福浅，身业功微，生前享寿遐龄，殁后解形暂灭。 然不拘三官之制，不受九府之艰，期限数登，则神归形复； 既改形容於三宫之馆，易童颜於九炼之房，故不入南上之宫，便历太空之境矣。 ○尸解有四种。 一者兵解，若嵇康寄戮於市，淮南则托形於狱。 二者文解，若次卿易质於履，长房假形於竹。 三者水火炼质，若冯夷溺於大川，封子焚於火树。 四者太阴炼质，视其已死，足不青、皮不皱、目光不毁，屈伸从人，亦尸解也。 肉皆百年不朽，更起成人。 《真诰》云：尸解仙不得御华盖，乘飞龙、登太极、游九宫，但不死而已。 《内义》曰：修诵虽殊，成功则一。 金丹之道，难遇易成。 傥宿命合真，得之者努力而行，必契经旨，无疑矣。 此经微妙，普度无穷。 一切天人，莫不受庆。 无量之福，生死蒙惠。 《内义》曰：此经隐奥，是道玄微，广济有情，普度无量。 经功满足，丹道圆成，先亡蒙解脱之恩，兆身被生成之泽。 上天所宝，不传下世。 至士斋金宝效心，盟天而传。 轻泄漏慢，殃及九祖，长役鬼官。 长役鬼官者，死魂被谪於天徒驱雷役电官，地徒担沙负石官，水徒挞汲溟波官。 《内义》曰：三洞真经列于金格，玄都所秘，万劫一开，传授效盟，经有明旨。 在昔劫数蹇屯，世运否塞，西台龟母有请玉京，由是降授，用济斯民。 玉晨道君付于玄一真人，玄一真人付太极徐真人，徐真人付葛仙公，传行於世。 法有内外，事仍两存。 以丹而言，禁戒尤重。 须严盟誓，不敢漏泄，内象之作，已露机缄，告天而行，广用提拔。 凡得此者，切勿慢轻，威神护持，灵官司察。 若违此祝，身必祸殃贻累九玄，冥责难逭。 侍经五帝、五帝巳解在前。 玉童玉女，各二十四人，营卫神文，保护受经者身。 童女都四十八人，既常营卫神经，亦兼保护诵者。
chunks.translated_text:
The billions of ancestors and forebears are but transient unions of father and mother; the suffering souls and hidden spirits, once they possess form, are all shrouded in the murky qi of ignorance—yet all may receive deliverance. Those who ascend to the Vermilion Palace undergo the refinement of this transient, murky qi, transcending into the radiant domain of luminous clarity. The standard for all is nine years of transformation and rebirth. To become a noble being means that the refining of the transient, murky qi wholly transforms it into yang spirit, rebirthing true qi, where the myriad spirits become one spirit and the myriad qi become one qi—this is the nurturing of the sacred embryo. Scholars who attain this station have already achieved the fullness of spirit and the sufficiency of qi, prolonging life and extending years; yet this is not yet what may be called immortality. Thus it is said: those who diligently study the scriptures, whose merit is complete and virtue perfected, all attain divine transcendence. Yet further cultivation is still required, for inner attainment must be realized and virtuous conduct fulfilled before one may aspire to such a state.

Inner attainment refers to the Dao of fire phases, embryo liberation, and spirit transformation—methods of practice that will be detailed later. Virtuous conduct lies in aiding others and benefiting the world, as exemplified by the Han Celestial Master discerning between humans and ghosts, Master Ge universally delivering suffering souls, and Perfected Lord Xu slaying dragons and serpents. The scripture states: though a scholar may uphold the Dao, without performing meritorious deeds, they cannot attain it. In ancient times, when the Han Celestial Master’s elixir was complete but not yet ingested, he said to Perfected Lord Wang: "The divine elixir is accomplished; if I consume it, I shall surely ascend to heaven and become a perfected one. Yet I have not yet performed great virtue. I must first serve the nation and the people, eliminating harm and promoting benefit, before I may ingest the elixir and lightly ascend. Only then will I have served the Three Realms without shame." Only thus may one ascend to the Golden Gates and roam the Jade Capital.

Scholars of the highest order who study and recite this scripture all receive deliverance and ascend to the Southern Palace. Those of the highest learning, upon hearing the Dao, practice diligently, study the teachings without fail, and persevere through cold and heat—these are the immortals recorded below the Nine Palaces of Great Clarity. Having recited this scripture, they attain the Dao in body and ascend to the immortal realm, undergoing refinement in the Southern Palace of Vermilion Numinosity. When the hun and po ascend as immortals, the ghostly substance is tempered by fire; when the living vessel attains the Dao, the filth and defilement are purged by fire—thus all enter the Southern Palace before ascending to their true original station.

Those in the world who recite this scripture extend their years and prolong their lives, later attaining the Dao of corpse liberation. Their souls temporarily dissolve, sparing them the underworld, and they swiftly regain form, roaming the vast heavens. Ordinary people—those not set apart from the multitude—though their ancestral blessings are shallow and their personal merit slight, may still enjoy long life in their years. Upon death, their forms dissolve temporarily. Unbound by the regulations of the Three Offices or the trials of the Nine Bureaus, after a set number of ascents, their spirits return and their forms are restored. Having transformed their appearance in the halls of the Three Palaces and renewed their youthful countenance in the chambers of the Nine Refinements, they do not enter the upper palaces of the South but instead traverse the celestial realms.

Corpse liberation takes four forms:
First, liberation by violence, as when Ji Kang met execution in the marketplace or the Prince of Huainan entrusted his form to prison.
Second, liberation by writing, as when Ci Qing exchanged his essence for sandals or Lord Changfang assumed the guise of bamboo.
Third, liberation through water or fire, as when Feng Yi drowned in the great river or Feng Zi was consumed by the fire tree.
Fourth, liberation through the Great Yin’s refinement, where the body appears dead—feet uncyanosed, skin unwrinkled, eyes undimmed—yet remains pliable to others, also a form of corpse liberation. The flesh remains uncorrupted for a hundred years before reviving as a complete person.

The *True Records* states: corpse-liberation immortals may not ride the floral canopy, mount flying dragons, ascend the Great Ultimate, or roam the Nine Palaces—they merely avoid death. The *Inner Meaning* says: though the methods of practice differ, their success is the same. The Dao of the golden elixir is rare to encounter yet easy to accomplish. If one’s past life aligns with the truth and they obtain it, they must strive to practice, surely aligning with the scripture’s intent without doubt. This scripture is subtle and wondrous, universally delivering boundless beings. All heavenly and mortal beings receive its blessings, and immeasurable fortune extends to the living and the dead.

The *Inner Meaning* states: this scripture is profound and recondite, the Dao’s most mysterious essence, broadly aiding sentient beings and universally delivering the innumerable. When the scripture’s merit is complete and the elixir’s Dao perfected, the departed receive liberation’s grace, and the living are endowed with life’s blessings. Treasured by heaven, it is not transmitted to the lower world. Only the most devoted scholars, offering gold and treasure with sincere hearts, may swear oaths to heaven and receive it. To lightly divulge or disdain it brings calamity upon nine generations, condemning them to eternal servitude as ghostly officials.

Such servitude entails the dead soul’s banishment to the ranks of:
- Heavenly servitors, who drive thunder and wield lightning;
- Earthly servitors, who bear sand and carry stones;
- Watery servitors, who lash the waves of the boundless deep.

The *Inner Meaning* says: the Three Caverns’ true scriptures are recorded in the golden registers, hidden in the Mystic Capital, revealed but once in ten thousand kalpas. Transmission requires oaths, as the scriptures themselves decree. In a past kalpa, when the world’s fortunes were dire and its destiny obstructed, the Tortoise Mother of the Western Terrace petitioned the Jade Capital, and thus it was bestowed to deliver the people. The Jade Dawn Dao Lord transmitted it to Perfected Lord Xuan Yi, who passed it to Perfected Lord Xu of the Great Ultimate, who then entrusted it to Master Ge, spreading it through the world. The method encompasses both inner and outer aspects, both matters preserved.

Regarding the elixir, prohibitions are especially strict. One must swear solemn vows, daring not to leak its secrets. The inner symbolism’s mechanisms have already been disclosed; one must invoke heaven in practice, broadly aiding and uplifting others. Those who receive this must never treat it lightly. Divine might protects and guards, while numinous officials oversee and observe. To violate this oath brings personal calamity and implicates nine generations, with inescapable punishment in the netherworld.

The Five Emperors who attend the scripture, along with their attendants, have already been explained. Twenty-four Jade Lads and twenty-four Jade Maidens, totaling forty-eight, safeguard the sacred text and protect the scripture’s recipients. The maidens, in particular, constantly guard the divine scripture and also protect those who recite it.

chunks.original_text: 修丹采药以寅申为起伏之候。 寅乃阳起之候，欲於申时行功，则於寅时先守，以至申时施用。 长斋者，清心也。 诵经者，摄炁也。 谓之采药。 上世亡魂，乃阴炁也。 阳炁虽曰子时发生，一阳尚在五阴之下。 至於寅时，犹阴阳相半，阴上阳下，郁而未畅，故曰逮役。 至於申时以法熏蒸，阳炁奋发上腾，入于离宫，得不谓之断地逮役，度上南宫乎？ 七月长斋，诵咏是经，身得神仙，诸天书名，黄录白简，削死上生。 七月，中元大庆之月。 中及己身，诸天上生名於白简，酆都落死籍於黑书。 身得神仙，位登天府。 黄箓白简者，以黄金为书，白玉为简也。 凡修道之法，普度九穷，通济生死。 《内义》曰：七月者，申也，乃阳伏之候。 欲於寅时行功，则於申时先守。 至寅时运汞投铅，入鼎成宝。 亦名采药，亦铸鼎器，如此则阳炁日盛，阴炁日消，所谓纯阴鬼也，纯阳仙也。 阳炁既壮，即修仙之渐，功满炁足，神化长生，故曰身得神仙。 凡得道之士，皆酆岱落名，移注仙籍，膺图受录，乃获上升，故曰诸天书名，黄箓白简； 削死上生也。 十月长斋，诵咏是经，为国王帝主、君臣父子，安镇国祚，保天长存，世世不绝。 常为人君，安镇其方，民称太平。 正月寅为鬼道，故拔先亡：七月申为人门，故度己身； 十月亥为天门，故上为帝王安镇国祚，永保太平。 《内义》曰：探药足备，铸鼎圆成。 预先十月入室，调和神炁，去冬至十五日为始，谨存神肾间，谓之筑固灵根，使根元本始神炁俱生。 国者，身也。 神为身之主，炁为神之臣。 神满炁盈，百骸俱理，丹成质蜕，久视长生，骨肉同飞，形神俱妙，一如经之谓矣。 八节之日，诵咏是经，得为九宫真人。 八节日，元始分遣天尊天君天帝神仙兵马教化人间，开度群品。 北斗南辰四司五帝亦复下降，条录罪福； 含炁之流，每至是日，各有变化，翾飞蠕动，草木飞沉，随缘感应，改故易新。 轻或更重，重或更轻。 善恶回换，炁象之运，自然而然。 上学之士，每於此日，自当存想祈谢，因变行化，习吉除凶，进善黜恶，升明弃暗，入正去邪，炼伪成真，励思登真，开度群品，生成万汇。 夫八节与八卦九宫相表里，故八节诵经，得为九官真人矣。 《内义》曰：八节八卦入室运符进火，以冬至之日、子时为首，起火神，存在肾。 阳火运行，其神随逐而进。 肾中，根也。 神室，蒂也。 自根至蒂，根带相连，结胎成果矣。 一举三时，自子至寅末住，金火逼，逐至神室。 其丹渐结，应冬至立春节，坎艮卦。 卯时沐浴，辰时进火，至巳末住。 金火逼逐至髓海，应春分立夏节，震巽卦。 阳火至极，午时运符，至申末住。 金水推运，从双关鹊桥入室，玄珠渐兆，应夏至、立秋节，离坤卦。 酉时沐浴，戌时运符，至亥末住。 真炁归元，一阳来复，应秋分、立冬节，兑乾卦。 周而复始，循环不已，盖促一年之功於一日之内，以应八节，用符八卦，凡此运用阳火阴符，皆归中宫。 长养圣胎，十月炁足，宝鼎功成，脱胎神化，是为真人。 夫八卦环列，外实中虚。 《易》曰：八卦成列，象在其中矣。 此其所以为九宫真人。 本命之日，诵咏是经，魂神澄正，万炁长存，不经苦恼，身有光明，三界侍卫，五帝司迎，万神朝礼，名书上天，功满德就，飞升上清。
chunks.translated_text:
Refining the elixir and gathering the medicine take *yin* and *shen* as the phases of ascent and descent. *Yin* marks the rise of yang; to practice the work at *shen*-hour, one must first guard at *yin*-hour, then apply it at *shen*-hour. A prolonged fast is the purification of the heart. Reciting the scripture is the gathering of *qi*—this is called gathering the medicine. The souls of past generations are *yin*-*qi*. Though yang-*qi* is said to arise at *zi*-hour, a single yang still lies beneath five *yin*. By *yin*-hour, *yin* and yang are evenly matched, *yin* above and yang below, pent up and not yet free—hence it is called ghostly servitude. When at *shen*-hour the method is applied to steam and refine, yang-*qi* surges upward and ascends into the *Li* Palace—can this not be called severing earthly servitude and delivering them to the Southern Palace?

In the seventh month, observe a prolonged fast and chant this scripture to attain immortality, have one’s name inscribed in the registers of the heavens, recorded on the Yellow Register and White Tablet, and have death erased and life bestowed. The seventh month is the great celebration of the Middle Prime. It extends to one’s own person: the heavens inscribe one’s name for ascension on the White Tablet, while Fengdu strikes one’s name from the Black Book of the dead. One attains immortality and ascends to the Heavenly Court. The Yellow Register and White Tablet are written in gold on tablets of white jade. All methods of Daoist cultivation universally deliver the nine orifices and bridge the realms of life and death.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The seventh month is *shen*, the phase of yang’s retreat. To practice the work at *yin*-hour, one must first guard at *shen*-hour. By *yin*-hour, mercury is circulated and lead is infused, entering the crucible to form the treasure—this is also called gathering the medicine or casting the crucible. Thus yang-*qi* grows daily stronger while *yin*-*qi* daily wanes. What was purely *yin* becomes a ghost; what is purely yang becomes an immortal. As yang-*qi* strengthens, the gradual refinement of immortality begins. When merit is complete and *qi* is full, the spirit transforms and one attains long life—hence it is said one attains immortality. All who achieve the Dao have their names stricken from Fengdu and transferred to the registers of immortals, receiving charts and records to ascend—thus it is said their names are inscribed in the heavens on the Yellow Register and White Tablet, and death is erased while life is bestowed.

In the tenth month, observe a prolonged fast and chant this scripture for the sake of the king, the lord, ruler and ministers, father and son, to secure the nation’s destiny, preserve the heavens’ enduring existence, and ensure the lineage continues unbroken. Always be a sovereign, secure in one’s domain, with the people proclaiming great peace. *Yin* in the first month is the ghostly path, hence it delivers the departed; *shen* in the seventh month is the human gate, hence it delivers oneself; *hai* in the tenth month is the heavenly gate, hence it secures the nation’s destiny for the emperor and ensures everlasting peace.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the medicine is fully gathered and the crucible is perfectly cast, enter the chamber in the tenth month to harmonize spirit and *qi*. Beginning fifteen days before the winter solstice, carefully guard the spirit between the kidneys—this is called fortifying the numinous root, causing the root’s original primordial spirit and *qi* to arise together. The nation is the body. The spirit is the body’s lord; *qi* is the spirit’s minister. When spirit is full and *qi* is abundant, the hundred bones are all ordered. The elixir is completed, the form is shed, and one attains long life and enduring vision. Bone and flesh ascend together, form and spirit are both wondrous—just as the scripture describes.

On the eight nodal days, chant this scripture to become a Perfected One of the Nine Palaces. On the eight nodal days, the Primordial Beginning dispatches Heavenly Worthies, Heavenly Lords, Heavenly Emperors, and immortals with their hosts to instruct and transform the world, delivering all beings. The Northern Dipper, Southern Asterism, Four Directors, and Five Emperors also descend to record merits and transgressions. All beings that partake of *qi*—on these days, each undergoes transformation: flying, crawling, plants, trees, creatures of the air and water—all respond to conditions, changing the old and renewing themselves. Light may become heavy, heavy may become light. Good and evil reverse, the movement of *qi* and images occurs naturally. Those who study the higher teachings should on these days meditate and offer prayers, adapting to change, cultivating good and eliminating evil, advancing brightness and abandoning darkness, entering rectitude and expelling perversity, refining the false into the true, striving to ascend to perfection, delivering all beings, and nurturing the myriad things.

The eight nodes correspond to the eight trigrams and nine palaces. Thus, chanting the scripture on the eight nodes allows one to become a Perfected One of the Nine Palaces.

The *Inner Meaning* states: On the eight nodes, enter the chamber, circulate the talisman, and advance the fire. Beginning on the winter solstice at *zi*-hour, invoke the Fire Spirit and guard it in the kidneys. The yang fire circulates, and the spirit follows it. The kidneys are the root; the spirit chamber is the stem. From root to stem, root and stem are connected, forming the embryo and bearing fruit. One cycle spans three hours, from *zi* to the end of *yin*. Metal and fire press forward, driving it to the spirit chamber. The elixir gradually forms, corresponding to the winter solstice and the *Li-Chun* node, the *Kan* and *Gen* trigrams. At *mao*-hour, bathe; at *chen*-hour, advance the fire until the end of *si*. Metal and fire press forward, driving it to the sea of marrow, corresponding to the spring equinox and *Li-Xia* node, the *Zhen* and *Xun* trigrams. When the yang fire reaches its peak at *wu*-hour, circulate the talisman until the end of *shen*. Metal and water propel it, entering the chamber from the Magpie Bridge at the double pass. The dark pearl gradually appears, corresponding to the summer solstice and *Li-Qiu* node, the *Li* and *Kun* trigrams. At *you*-hour, bathe; at *xu*-hour, circulate the talisman until the end of *hai*. True *qi* returns to the origin, and a single yang revives, corresponding to the autumn equinox and *Li-Dong* node, the *Dui* and *Qian* trigrams. This cycle repeats endlessly. Thus, a year’s work is compressed into a single day to correspond to the eight nodes, using the eight trigrams as talismans. All these operations of yang fire and yin talismans return to the Central Palace. Nurturing the sacred embryo for ten months, when *qi* is full, the precious crucible’s work is complete. The embryo is shed, the spirit transforms—this is the Perfected One. The eight trigrams are arrayed in a circle, solid without and empty within. The *Book of Changes* says: "The eight trigrams are arrayed, and the images are within them." This is why one becomes a Perfected One of the Nine Palaces.

On one’s natal day, chant this scripture to purify and rectify the hun-soul and spirit, preserve the myriad *qi* for eternity, avoid suffering and affliction, and radiate light from the body. The Three Realms provide attendants, the Five Emperors oversee reception, the myriad spirits pay homage, one’s name is inscribed in heaven, merit is complete and virtue perfected, and one ascends to the Upper Clarity.

chunks.original_text: 人身有三魂：一魂居直，本属宿官； 一魂居地府，一魂居形内，七魄常住而不散也。 遇本命日，魂神降体就尸，合同循环，归降不绝，则生人安稳，灾病不生。 若其日清净身心，不酒不色，着新衣服，焚香习善，更於其日眠睡少时，即魂与魄合，阴与阳并，道炁内隆，命根坚固。 若嗜酒色，昏乱形体，则魂当归时，去身三步之远，取合不能，秽恶冲射，魂复而往。 若三度昏乱，魂不合魄者，则阳衰阴旺，魄灵与阴鬼交通，致使游梦众恶，耽睡迷乱，灾病俱生，将至於死。 人能於本命斋诵，则有如上感应，功满德就，则飞升也。 既以我本命之日修诵，故能存我神炁，圣人作则，皆有由然。 以此推之，则修真之理自明矣。 《内义》曰：火候毕，行脱胎神化之道，圣胎存於髓海之中。 以周星六十日为期，本命一周以合周星之数。 忽然如霹雳之声，天门裂开，圣胎脱出，凡蜕为仙，长生不死，魔王保举，诸天奉迎，功备德隆，飞腾可待。 李昌龄曰：功者，日用之谓； 德者，日新之谓。 苟能闵闵然如农夫之望岁，汲汲然如商贾之营财，今日积德，明日又积德，今日累功，明日又累功，所谓天仙一千三百善，行之只在四年； 地仙三百善，行之只在一年。 第人不能，多至中废，不闻穿石礼树之说乎？ 紫虚元君曰：昔有傅先生者，自少好道，入焦山石室中。 积七年，忽遇太极真人，授以木钻，使之穿一磬石。 戒曰：石透，吾当度汝。 石厚五尺余，傅穿之不息，积四十七年。 石忽穿透，太极真人果来度之。 又南岳夫人曰：昔有人励志於道，然不知求道之方，唯日夕礼一枯树，求丐长生，如是不已。 积二十八年，树忽生花，有汁如蜜，其人取花并汁吞之，遂获度世。 呜呼！ 钻石、礼树，尚得度世，况持经行妙道，宁有不得者乎？ 道言：行道之日，皆当香汤沐浴，斋戒入室，东向叩齿三十二通，上闻三十二天，心拜三十二过。 诵经之日，先被服盥漱，置经於案。 然后焚香礼请，跪启修诵之意。 即东向正坐，焚香披读，注心历目，微声诵咏，若或错误，则却上三十字读，忽使匆速，苟贪徧数，翻为失功，误人不少。 调声诵咏，令神魂和畅，常令香炁不绝於室。 叩齿者，当以中齿上下两两相叩，令响，内以集神，外以彻天。 《真诰》云：叩齿以集神，咽津以和真。 次则存拜三十二天，每想天帝，存一拜之。 从东北方首始，东行左旋，止於西北。 闭目静思，身坐青黄白三色云炁之中。 玄炁青，元炁黄，始炁白。 内外蓊冥，有青龙、白虎、朱雀、玄武、狮子、白鹤，罗列左右，日月照明，洞焕室内，项生圆象，光映十方，如此分明。 青龙左，白虎右，朱雀前，玄武后； 狮子左右各两行，行有其八，对坐相望； 白鹤亦然。 日在额左，月在额右。 光明一室，项生圆象； 九色相间，青、赤、黄、白、黑、绿、红、紫、绀，照彻十方，存令分明如睹。 密咒曰：密者，口动而无声也。 贪罗郁罗，符无苏陀。 太冲太极，阴阳包和。 出有入无，出生入死。 鬼神莫测，变化自如。 元始混炁，玄中又玄。 上干有顶，下洞太渊。 诵之一徧，沉痾自痊。 炼魂浴魄，真阳自全。 斋戒礼诵，万过飞仙。 无上秘咒，万神绵绵。 心中心咒，重复宣传。

The human body possesses three *hun*-souls: one resides in the celestial bureaus, originally belonging to its destined office; one dwells in the earthly prisons, and one abides within the physical form. The seven *po*-souls remain constantly present, never dispersing. On one’s natal day, the *hun*-souls descend into the body to join the corpse, merging in an unbroken cycle of return. Thus, the living person remains at peace, free from calamity and illness. If on that day one purifies body and mind, abstains from wine and lust, dons new garments, burns incense, and cultivates goodness—and further, if one sleeps briefly—then the *hun* and *po* unite, yin and yang merge, the Dao’s *qi* flourishes within, and the root of life is firmly secured. But if one indulges in wine and lust, befuddling the body, then when the *hun* should return, it lingers three paces away, unable to rejoin. Filth and defilement assail it, and the *hun* retreats. If this befuddlement occurs thrice, and the *hun* fails to unite with the *po*, yang wanes while yin waxes, and the numinous *po* consorts with yin ghosts. This gives rise to wandering nightmares, excessive sleep, confusion, and the onset of calamity and illness, ultimately leading to death. Yet if one observes a fast and recites scriptures on one’s natal day, the aforementioned responses occur: merit is complete, virtue perfected, and one ascends in flight.

Having cultivated and recited on one’s natal day, one thereby preserves one’s spirit and *qi*. The sages established these models, all for good reason. Extending this principle, the Way of cultivating the Real becomes self-evident.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When the firing process is complete, practice the Way of shedding the embryo and transforming the spirit. The sacred embryo abides within the Sea of Marrow. Taking the sixty-day cycle of the stars as the period, one full natal cycle aligns with the stellar number. Suddenly, as if a thunderclap resounds, the Gate of Heaven splits open, the sacred embryo emerges, the mortal husk is shed for immortality, and one attains everlasting life. The Demon Kings bear witness, the hosts of heaven offer reception, merit is fulfilled, virtue exalted, and ascension awaits.

Li Changling said: Merit is the work of daily practice; virtue is the renewal of each day. If one is as earnest as a farmer awaiting the harvest, as diligent as a merchant pursuing wealth—today accumulating virtue, tomorrow again accumulating virtue; today amassing merit, tomorrow again amassing merit—then the celestial immortal’s one thousand three hundred good deeds may be accomplished in four years, and the earthly immortal’s three hundred good deeds in one year. Yet most people falter midway, failing to heed the lessons of drilling stone or bowing to trees.

The Lady of Purple Tenuity said: Long ago, there was a Master Fu who, from youth, loved the Dao. He entered a stone chamber on Mount Jiao and practiced for seven years. Suddenly, he encountered the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate, who bestowed upon him a wooden drill and instructed him to bore through a stone chime. The Perfected One warned: "When the stone is pierced, I shall deliver you." The stone was over five feet thick, yet Master Fu drilled without cease for forty-seven years. The stone was suddenly pierced, and the Perfected One of the Great Ultimate indeed came to deliver him.

The Lady of Southern Marchmount also said: Once, a man resolved to pursue the Dao but knew not the method. Day and night, he bowed to a withered tree, beseeching long life, never ceasing. After twenty-eight years, the tree suddenly bloomed, and its blossoms exuded a sap like honey. The man consumed the flowers and sap, and thus attained deliverance from the world. Alas! If drilling stone and bowing to trees can lead to deliverance, how much more so the holding of scriptures and practice of the wondrous Dao—could there be any who fail to attain it?

The Dao teaches: On days of practice, one should bathe in fragrant waters, fast, and enter the chamber. Facing east, knock the teeth thirty-two times, making it heard in the thirty-two heavens, and bow in the heart thirty-two times. On days of scripture recitation, first don proper attire, wash the hands and rinse the mouth, and place the scripture upon the desk. Then burn incense, perform the ritual invocation, kneel, and declare one’s intent to recite. Sit upright facing east, burn incense, open the scripture, focus the mind, and read in a soft voice. If an error occurs, return thirty characters and reread. Avoid haste; if one rushes to complete the count, it becomes a loss of merit and misleads many. Modulate the voice in recitation so that spirit and *hun* harmonize and flow smoothly, ensuring the incense’s fragrance never fades in the chamber.

To knock the teeth: bring the upper and lower central teeth together in pairs, making them resound. Internally, this gathers the spirit; externally, it reaches the heavens. The *Declarations of the Perfected* states: "Knock the teeth to gather the spirit; swallow the saliva to harmonize the Real."

Next, visualize bowing to the thirty-two heavens, imagining the Heavenly Emperor with each bow. Begin at the northeast, proceed eastward in a leftward circuit, and conclude at the northwest. Close the eyes and meditate, sitting amidst clouds of cyan, yellow, and white *qi*. The Mysterious *qi* is cyan, the Primordial *qi* is yellow, and the Initial *qi* is white. Within and without, all is misty and obscure. The Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, Dark Warrior, Lion, and White Crane array themselves to left and right. Sun and moon shine brightly, illuminating the chamber. A circular radiance appears above the head, its light suffusing the ten directions—all vividly clear. The Azure Dragon to the left, White Tiger to the right, Vermilion Bird before, Dark Warrior behind; lions in two rows on either side, eight in each row, seated facing one another; white cranes likewise. The sun at the left of the forehead, the moon at the right. The chamber is filled with light, a circular radiance above the head; nine colors intermingle—cyan, red, yellow, white, black, green, crimson, purple, and deep blue—illuminating the ten directions. Visualize all with perfect clarity.

chunks.original_text: 贪罗洞明，与道合真。 玉清上极，梵炁氤氲。 分灵布炁，降注臣身。 形神俱妙，变化飞升。 一如令格，统摄万灵。 急急如律令。 元上三天玄元始三炁太上道君。 玄元始三炁化生三宝君，各居一天。 三天在人额上发际。 中为清微天，天宝君治之； 左为禹余天，灵宝君治之； 右为太赤天，神宝君治之。 凡诵经，当存思三帝君。 召出臣身中三五功曹、左右官使者、侍香金童、传言玉女、五帝直符、直日香官，各三十六人出。 上、中、下三境，每境八人，三八二十四人，并三魂七魄、阴阳二君，共三十六人。 关启所言， 受法箓者，即具位。 如未受法箓，即称奉道弟子，当尽心中所欲言词。 然亦贵在简当，至诚默奏。 今日吉庆，长斋 今某日吉庆，随其日言之。 如长斋即言长斋，如不长斋即不言也。 清堂，修行至经， 若知三洞中盟之道，见行事即言修行至经，自非此人即不言修行至经。 但言清堂诵经。 无量度人。 或为一事而诵，即言为某事诵经。 若为十方普度，乃可言无量度人。 臣及甲乙，转经受生， 若常时自诵，即言臣及祖考。 若为他人，即言臣为某人。 但以意而陈述。 甲乙者，某人某人之理也。 愿所启上彻，径御无上三十二天元始上帝至尊几前。 元始上帝者，即非元始天尊，乃上帝高尊，位齐元始者。 或云元始上帝即天尊也。 毕，引炁三十二过， 引者，以鼻引而咽之。 三十二过者，东南西北方，每方八天，各一引。 东方青炁，纳於肝； 南方赤炁纳於心，西方白炁，纳於肺； 北方玄炁，纳於肾。 洞彻五内，然后诵经。 东向诵经。 东方乃长生之方，诸天所尊重。 诵经之格，初一徧从序诵起，至此存思毕，即诵后经。 第二徧，则宜从元始无量度人上品妙经起诵。 每十徧为一过，若欲禳襘济拔，须得十徧为佳，以遵十回度人之义。 或有事务暂起，亦得若经时稍久，即须依前法。 《内义》曰：如上发炉，密咒乃诵经，行持启出官将通奏斋意，以祈感格。 若夫三炁蓊冥，六神侍卫，日月洞焕，圆象照明，皆备内象之中矣。 万法皆有内外，事仍两存，有内无外，皆非大道，乃属旁门，内修秘密，外用显明。 是故太上微示内修，彰显外用，令人泝流寻源，穷末知本，使其自悟自得，兼而行之，以取仙道也。 元始无量度人上品妙经内义卷之二竟 元始无量度人上品妙经内义卷之三

The *Tanluo* Cavern shines bright, merging with the Dao in truth.
The Jade Clarity’s highest realm, Brahmanic *qi* billows and swirls.
Dividing the numinous, spreading *qi*, it descends and pours into this servant’s body.
Form and spirit both wondrous, transforming and ascending in flight.
Let it be as the ordained pattern, governing and embracing the ten thousand spirits.
Hasten! As the law commands.

The Primordial of the Three Heavens above, the Mysterious Primordial Three *Qi*, the Most High Dao Lord.
The Mysterious Primordial Three *Qi* transform and give birth to the Three Treasures Lords, each dwelling in one heaven.
The Three Heavens reside at the hairline upon the human forehead:
The center is the Qingwei Heaven, ruled by the Heavenly Treasure Lord;
The left is the Yuyu Heaven, ruled by the Numinous Treasure Lord;
The right is the Taichi Heaven, ruled by the Spirit Treasure Lord.
Whenever reciting scripture, one must visualize the Three Emperor Lords.
Summon forth from this servant’s body the Three and Five Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendant Envoys, the Incense-Bearing Golden Youths, the Message-Transmitting Jade Maidens, the Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans, and the Direct-Day Incense Officials—thirty-six of each.
In the upper, middle, and lower three realms, eight in each, three eights making twenty-four, together with the three *hun* souls, seven *po* souls, and the Yin and Yang Lords, totaling thirty-six.
Unlock and declare what is to be said.
Those who have received the register of the law shall state their rank.
If one has not received the register, they shall be called a Dao-disciple, and should devote their heart to the words they wish to speak.
Yet brevity and sincerity are most precious; present it silently and earnestly.
Today is an auspicious day, a long fast—
Today, on this auspicious day, speak according to the day.
If it is a long fast, say so; if not, do not mention it.
In the Pure Hall, cultivating the scripture to its completion—
If one knows the way of the covenant within the Three Caverns, and sees the practice being performed, say “cultivating the scripture to its completion.” If not, simply say “reciting scripture in the Pure Hall.”
Saving boundless beings.
If reciting for a single matter, say “reciting scripture for such-and-such a matter.”
If for universal salvation in the ten directions, then one may say “saving boundless beings.”
This servant and so-and-so, turning the scripture to receive rebirth—
If reciting for oneself at ordinary times, say “this servant and my ancestors.”
If for another, say “this servant for so-and-so.”
Simply state it according to one’s intent.
“So-and-so” refers to the principle of such-and-such a person.
May what is declared ascend directly to the presence of the Most High Thirty-Two Heavens’ Primordial Thearch, the August One.
The Primordial Thearch is not the Primordial Heavenly Worthy, but the Highest Thearch, whose rank is equal to the Primordial One.
Some say the Primordial Thearch is the Heavenly Worthy.
When finished, draw in *qi* thirty-two times—
“Drawing” means inhaling through the nose and swallowing.
“Thirty-two times” means in the four directions—east, south, west, and north—eight heavens in each direction, one inhalation per direction.
The green *qi* of the east is absorbed into the liver;
The red *qi* of the south is absorbed into the heart;
The white *qi* of the west is absorbed into the lungs;
The mysterious *qi* of the north is absorbed into the kidneys.
When it thoroughly permeates the five viscera, then recite the scripture.
Face east when reciting scripture.
The east is the direction of long life, revered by all heavens.
The method of reciting scripture: the first cycle begins with the preface and continues until the visualization is complete, then recite the subsequent scripture.
The second cycle should begin with *The Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial’s Boundless Salvation of Beings, Upper Chapter*.
Every ten cycles make one completion. If seeking to dispel misfortune or deliver salvation, ten cycles are best, in accordance with the principle of saving beings ten times over.
If temporarily interrupted by other matters, even if the recitation has lasted some time, one must return to the previous method.
The *Inner Meaning* states: As above, when the furnace is activated, the secret incantation is recited, the practice is performed, the officials are summoned, and the intent of the fast is communicated to seek resonance and response.
As for the three *qi* billowing in darkness, the six spirits standing guard, the sun and moon shining brilliantly, and the circular image illuminating all—all these are prepared within the inner image.
All methods have both inner and outer aspects; matters are preserved in both. If there is inner without outer, it is not the Great Dao, but belongs to side teachings. Inner cultivation is secret, outer application is manifest.
Thus, the Most High subtly reveals inner cultivation and makes outer application evident, guiding people to trace the flow back to its source, to exhaust the end and know the root, enabling them to awaken and realize for themselves, to practice both together, and thereby attain the Dao of immortality.

*Inner Meaning of the Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial’s Boundless Salvation of Beings, Upper Chapter, Scroll Two* ends.

chunks.original_text: 观复子萧应叟学 元始无量度人上品妙经 皇人曰：此乃道君标目也。 《内义》曰：玉笈琼章，分为三洞，日洞真、洞玄、洞神。 总而言之，是为一乘也。 此经属洞玄，为众经之冠，故太上道君叙经於前，题曰太上洞玄灵宝也。 此则直标元始无量度人上品妙经者，以明虚皇天尊所说。 在经，故以此名篇； 在丹，则金液还丹也。 元始洞玄，灵宝本章。 此是皇人所题内号。 元，先也，先天而生。 始，结也，元炁始结。 洞，通也，通达无穷。 玄，空也，杳然空洞。 谓元炁始结而成玉字，在空玄之中，通照乎四方，空玄为灵，入藏为宝也。 又曰：始生一，一，天也。 天从始而元，明始亦元也。 会合於元，元生之时，无天无地，无神无鬼，溟涬鸿蒙，无所分别，元始结而成玉字。 玉者，自然之精，精出而发光，以成天地，日月星辰所以化成。 元始尊神者，明其有灵也。 化生天地日月星辰者，欲以生养万物也。 天地万物生后而有号者，明元始造化也。 号元始者，示人知终始归趣也。 《内义》曰：元始者，虚无自然先天祖炁洞通也，玄妙也。 通则通贯一切，妙则妙用无穷。 灵宝者，金丹异名。 本者，根也。 章者，文也。 谓虚无自然先天祖炁，通贯一切，妙用无穷，而为金液还丹之根，宗演而为文，以显其迹也。 上品妙首，十回度人。 龙汉之年，玉字始出，日月始明，天地亦分。 众圣列位，元始出法度人，说经十徧，周回十方，度人无量。 元始因撰作十部妙经，以紫笔书着空青之林，众圣所崇，为经之祖宗，故曰上品妙首者也。 百魔隐韵，离合自然。 此四句乃皇人总明一经之宗旨。 《内义》曰：上品妙首者，金液还丹为无上妙道之冠。 十回度人者，十月之功，度世为仙。 此乃入室＋月工夫。 百魔隐韵，如丹药异名； 离合自然，犹金木间隔，复能互并，水火相克，复成既济，自然而成造化。 混洞赤文，无无上真。 混者，混沌之名； 洞者，洞阳之炁； 赤文者，赤书真文也。 齐混沌之初，在天地之先，凝化空洞之上，郁结太无之中。 太无之无，亦无其无； 既无其无，是谓无无，故日无无上真。 《内义》曰：混洞赤文，万化之本源，众生之真性。 在道，则为一炁之祖； 在人，则为万神之宗。 先天地万物，莫知其首初，故曰元始； 成天地万物，莫知其神妙，故曰灵宝； 统天地万物，莫知其广大，故曰道德； 示人达本而行，故曰妙经； 摄人返本而修，故曰还丹。 演为三乘，立为三教，无穷法门，皆此化也。 唐明皇制《混元赞》曰：大哉至道！ 元为自然，劫终劫始，先地先天，含光默默，永劫绵绵。 东训尼父，西化金仙，百王取法，万圣攸传。 大教之祖，玄之又玄。 故《道德经》云：有物混成，先天地生，不知其名，字之曰道。 《西升经》曰：虚无生自然，自然生道。 夫道者，无形无体，则先天一炁是也。 而化生万物，实天地造化之本。 修金丹者，体循造化，以虚无自然、先天纯精真一之炁，名曰空炁金胎，生金母而作丹基。 夫纯精真一之炁，父母未交之前，与混沌同体。 《道德经》曰：无名，天地之始者是也。 在经故曰混洞。 因父母媾精之始，此炁欻然感附，强名曰神，谓之阳精，喻为银矿。 是元神也，藏在坤宫。

Guanfuzi Xiao Yingsou studies *The Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial’s Boundless Salvation of Beings, Upper Chapter*. The August Personage says: This is the title bestowed by the Dao Lord.

*The Inner Meaning* states: Jade tablets and numinous chapters are divided into the Three Caverns—Cavern of Perfection, Cavern of Mystery, and Cavern of Divinity. Taken together, they form the One Vehicle. This scripture belongs to the Cavern of Mystery and stands as the crown of all scriptures. Thus, the Most High Dao Lord prefaced it, entitling it *The Most High Cavern of Mystery, Numinous Treasure*. Yet here it is directly titled *The Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial’s Boundless Salvation of Beings, Upper Chapter*, to clarify that it was spoken by the Heavenly Worthy of the Primordial Void. As scripture, it bears this name; as elixir, it is the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir.

*Primordial Cavern of Mystery, Numinous Treasure Fundamental Chapter*—this is the inner title given by the August Personage. *Primordial* means first, born before Heaven. *Beginning* means congealing, where the primordial qi first coalesces. *Cavern* means penetrating, boundless in reach. *Mystery* means emptiness, profound and void. Thus, the primordial qi first congeals to form the jade script within the empty mystery, illuminating the four directions. Emptiness becomes numinous, and concealment becomes treasure.

It is also said: The beginning gives rise to the One, and the One is Heaven. Heaven emerges from the beginning, so the beginning is also primordial. When all converges in the primordial, at the time of primordial generation, there is no Heaven, no Earth, no spirits, no ghosts—only the vast, chaotic expanse, undifferentiated and indistinct. Then the primordial congeals to form the jade script. Jade is the essence of spontaneity; its essence radiates light to form Heaven and Earth, giving rise to the sun, moon, and stars. The Primordial Venerable Deity is so named to reveal its numinosity. The generation of Heaven, Earth, sun, moon, and stars serves to nurture the myriad beings. That Heaven, Earth, and the myriad beings later receive names demonstrates the creative transformation of the Primordial Beginning. The name *Primordial Beginning* is given to show people that the end and the beginning share the same destination.

*The Inner Meaning* states: *Primordial Beginning* refers to the primordial ancestral qi of the spontaneous Void, penetrating and mysterious. *Penetrating* means pervading all; *mysterious* means wondrously inexhaustible. *Numinous Treasure* is another name for the Golden Elixir. *Fundamental* means root; *chapter* means text. It signifies that the primordial ancestral qi of the spontaneous Void, pervading all and wondrously inexhaustible, serves as the root of the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir, unfolding as text to reveal its traces.

*Upper Chapter, Wondrous Beginning, Ten Cycles of Salvation*—In the era of Dragon Han, the jade script first emerged, the sun and moon first shone, and Heaven and Earth were divided. The host of sages took their places, and the Primordial Beginning expounded the Dharma to save beings, reciting the scripture ten times, circling the ten directions, and delivering countless beings. The Primordial Beginning thus composed ten divisions of wondrous scriptures, inscribed with purple brush on the Azure Forest of Empty Green. Revered by all sages as the ancestral scripture, it is called *Upper Chapter, Wondrous Beginning*.

*Hundred Demons Conceal the Rhyme, Separation and Union Spontaneous*—These four lines summarize the essential purport of the entire scripture.

*The Inner Meaning* states: *Upper Chapter, Wondrous Beginning* refers to the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir as the crown of the supreme wondrous Dao. *Ten Cycles of Salvation* signifies the ten months’ work of elixir refinement, delivering one to immortality—this is the practice of ten months’ seclusion. *Hundred Demons Conceal the Rhyme* is like the various names of the elixir; *Separation and Union Spontaneous* resembles the alternation of metal and wood, which though distinct can merge, or water and fire, which though opposing achieve harmony—all spontaneously completing the transformation.

*Chaotic Red Script, Supreme True of the Non-None*—*Chaotic* is the name of primordial chaos; *cavern* refers to the qi of cavernous yang; *red script* is the vermilion true script. At the dawn of chaos, before Heaven and Earth, it coagulated above the empty cavern, condensing within the Great None. The *none* of the Great None is itself non-existent; since it is non-existent, it is called the *Non-None*, hence the *Supreme True of the Non-None*.

*The Inner Meaning* states: *Chaotic Red Script* is the root-source of the myriad transformations and the true nature of all beings. In the Dao, it is the ancestor of the One Qi; in humans, it is the origin of the myriad spirits. Before Heaven, Earth, and the myriad beings, none know its beginning, hence *Primordial Beginning*; in forming Heaven, Earth, and the myriad beings, none know its numinous wonder, hence *Numinous Treasure*; in governing Heaven, Earth, and the myriad beings, none know its vastness, hence *Virtue/Power*; in guiding people to return to the root and practice, it is called *Wondrous Scripture*; in gathering people to revert to the origin and cultivate, it is called *Returned Elixir*. It unfolds into the Three Vehicles, establishes the Three Teachings, and gives rise to boundless Dharma gates—all its transformations.

Tang Emperor Minghuang’s *Eulogy of the Primordial* says:
Great indeed is the Supreme Dao!
Primordial is spontaneity,
Ending and beginning kalpas,
Before Earth, before Heaven,
Enveloping light in silence,
Eternally enduring.
In the East, it instructed Confucius;
In the West, it transformed the Golden Immortal.
A hundred kings took it as model,
Myriad sages transmitted it.
Ancestor of the Great Teaching,
Mysterious beyond mystery.

Thus, the *Dao De Jing* says: There is a thing chaotically formed, born before Heaven and Earth. I know not its name, so I style it the *Dao*. The *Scripture of Western Ascent* says: The Void gives rise to spontaneity, and spontaneity gives rise to the Dao. The Dao is formless and bodiless—it is the primordial One Qi. Yet in generating the myriad beings, it is truly the root of Heaven and Earth’s creative transformation. Those who refine the Golden Elixir emulate this transformation, using the qi of the spontaneous Void—primordial, pure, true, and unified—called the *Empty Qi Golden Embryo*, to generate the Golden Mother and establish the foundation of the elixir.

This pure, true, unified qi, before the union of father and mother, was one body with chaos. The *Dao De Jing* says: The nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth—this is it. In scripture, it is thus called *chaotic*. At the moment of the parents’ union, this qi suddenly attaches, forcibly named *spirit*, called *yang essence*, likened to silver ore. This is the primordial spirit, concealed within the Palace of Earth.

chunks.original_text: 两肾间。 故谓之性，乃我本来面目。 未生之前谓之阴金，已生之后谓之阳铅，是为五金之母。 天地万汇未有不因此炁而能成立者也。 《道德经》曰：有名，万物之母。 是矣。 真一子彭真人叙《参同契》曰：径指天地之灵根，将为药祖，明示阴阳之圣母，用作丹基者，此也。 因日用妙化发生之炁运归中宫，而为丹母，故曰道生一，象乎祖炁，结而成玉字也。 在经则曰赤文，是为金火， 金者，先天自然之炁，金胎也。 火者，日用发生之阳炁也。 同出一源而为体用者矣。 此乃无上可上，至真妙道，故曰无无上真也。 元始祖劫，化生诸天。 祖，始也。 玄元始炁於祖劫之初，欻然而造化五亿诸天。 按天地一成一败，谓之一劫。 言始劫者，谓世界初生，未经成败也。 573/3 《内义》曰：周濂汉曰：大哉乾元！ 万物资始，诚之源也。 乾道变化，各正性命，诚斯立焉。 故元始祖劫者，乃大哉乾元，万物资始者也。 是真之源也。 化生诸天者，乃乾道变化，各正性命者也。 则真斯立焉。 原夫化生诸天之祖，自一炁而立三境，由三境而生九天； 三境九天各又下生三天，合三十六天； 次下四种民天，次分三界二十八天，次八梵天，以至化生五亿诸天、八圆世界，而人之生亦类是也。 父母精血相包自己本有，而成性命。 人初结胎在母腹中，精血未凝，飞潜不定，如珠似露。 凝结之后，生形三瓣，头与四肢。 男子先生左肾，次生右命门。 女则反是。 本性继种於两肾之间， 名曰坤宫，日用妙化之炁自此发生。 次则上生两瞳神水，以至化生五脏六腑。 凭母呼吸，炁足而生。 故老君曰：天地媾精，阴阳布化。 一月为胞，精血凝也； 二月为胎，形兆胚也； 三月阳神为三魂，动以生也； 四月阴灵为七魄，静镇形也； 五月五行分五脏，以安神也； 六月六律定六腑，用资灵也； 七月七精开七窍，通光明也； 八月八景神具，降真灵也； 九月宫室罗布，以定精也； 十月炁足，万象成也。 夫人虽与天地同造化，而不得并其长久者，何耶？ 盖由不能复其本也。 本者，祖炁也。 本於一心，专一炁而致柔，修一心而成道。 若能通而会之，则闭户造车，出门合辙，返本还元，形神俱妙。 故傅大士颂释迦曰：六年雪岭为何因，只为调和炁与神。 一百刻中为一息，方知大道是全身。 通而会之，此颂是也。 所以道冠、儒履、释袈裟，非徒为者也。 开明三景，是为天根。 二仪分形，三光垂曜，皆禀始炁，故为天根矣。 《内义》曰：经曰，道生一、一生二、二生三、三生万物。 故《虚无自然本起经》曰，夫道得三乃成。 故曰三合成德，道不满三，诸事不成。 《系辞》曰：易有太极，是生两仪。 由一炁而分清浊，是为三也。 《九天生神章经》云：三炁合生九炁，三炁为天地之宗，九炁为万物之根，因三成九，为物之根，谓之三生万物。 三合成德，在道，为三炁； 在物，为三才； 在天，为三光； 在人，为三元。 皆元始之祖炁，作万物之本根。 故曰开明三景，是为天根。 以内而言，假设法象，则曰铅、汞、砂也。 直指其物，则是本有之性，与夫日用妙化阴阳之二炁也。 人虽知本有之性，而莫知二界之用者，亦不免其衰谢也。 锺离真人曰：有无交入名丹本，隐显相符是水金；
chunks.translated_text:
Between the two kidneys—this is called *nature*, our original face. Before birth, it is termed *yin metal*; after birth, *yang lead*, the mother of the five metals. There is nothing in Heaven and Earth or the ten thousand transformations that does not rely on this qi for its establishment. The *Dao De Jing* says: "The named is the mother of the myriad beings"—this is it.

Master Zhenyi Peng’s preface to the *Cantong Qi* states: "Directly pointing to the numinous root of Heaven and Earth, it is taken as the ancestor of the medicine; clearly revealing the sagely mother of yin and yang, it is used as the foundation of the elixir"—this is it. As the wondrously transforming qi of daily use returns to the Central Palace to become the *Elixir Mother*, it is said: "The Dao gives birth to the One," resembling the *Ancestral Qi*, coalescing into the *Jade Letter*. In scripture, it is called *Red Script*—this is *metal and fire*. *Metal* is the spontaneous qi of the primordial, the *Golden Embryo*; *fire* is the yang qi of daily arising. Both emerge from a single source, forming substance and function.

This is the supreme, unsurpassable, most true and wondrous Dao, hence called the *Peerless True*. From the primordial beginning of the ancestral kalpa, the myriad heavens were generated. *Ancestral* means *beginning*. The mysterious primordial qi at the dawn of the ancestral kalpa suddenly gave rise to the five billion heavens. Now, Heaven and Earth undergo one completion and one destruction—this is called a *kalpa*. The *beginning kalpa* refers to the world’s initial arising, before any completion or destruction.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Zhou Lianhan said: "Great indeed is Qian’s origin! The myriad beings rely on it for their beginning—it is the source of sincerity. As the Qian Dao transforms and changes, each attains its nature and destiny, and sincerity is thereby established." Thus, the *primordial ancestral kalpa* is the greatness of Qian’s origin, on which the myriad beings rely for their beginning—this is the source of the true. The generation of the myriad heavens is the Qian Dao’s transformation and change, wherein each attains its nature and destiny—then the true is established.

Tracing the origin of the myriad heavens’ generation: from the One Qi, the Three Realms are established; from the Three Realms, the Nine Heavens arise. Each of the Three Realms and Nine Heavens further generates three heavens below, totaling thirty-six heavens. Below these are the four kinds of mortal heavens, then the division into the Three Realms and twenty-eight heavens, followed by the eight Brahma heavens, extending to the generation of five billion heavens and eight spherical worlds. Human birth follows a similar pattern: the parents’ essence and blood envelop one’s inherent nature and destiny to form them.

When a person first takes shape in the mother’s womb, essence and blood have not yet congealed, drifting and shifting like pearls or dew. After congealing, the form develops three segments: the head and four limbs. In males, the left kidney forms first, then the right *Gate of Destiny*; in females, the reverse. The original nature continues the lineage between the two kidneys, called the *Palace of Earth*, whence the wondrously transforming qi of daily use arises. Next, the divine water of the two pupils forms above, extending to the generation of the five viscera and six bowels. Relying on the mother’s breath, when qi is sufficient, birth occurs.

Thus, Laozi said: "Heaven and Earth unite their essences, and yin and yang distribute transformation. In the first month, it is the *embryo sac*, as essence and blood congeal; in the second, the *fetus*, as form begins to take shape; in the third, the yang spirit becomes the *three hun*, moving to generate life; in the fourth, the yin numen becomes the *seven po*, stillness stabilizing form; in the fifth, the five phases divide into the five viscera, to settle the spirit; in the sixth, the six pitch-standards determine the six bowels, to aid the numinous; in the seventh, the seven essences open the seven orifices, to communicate light; in the eighth, the eight luminous spirits are complete, descending true numen; in the ninth, palaces are arrayed, to secure essence; in the tenth, qi is sufficient, and the myriad images are complete."

Though humans share the same creative transformation as Heaven and Earth, they do not attain equal longevity—why? It is because they cannot return to their root. The *root* is the *Ancestral Qi*. Rooted in the One Heart, one concentrates on the One Qi to attain softness, cultivates the One Heart to accomplish the Dao. If one can penetrate and unite them, then "closing the door to build the cart" and "exiting the gate to match the tracks" are one—returning to the root and restoring the origin, with form and spirit both wondrous.

Thus, Master Fu’s eulogy for Śākyamuni says: "For what reason did he spend six years on Snow Mountain? Only to harmonize qi and spirit. In one hundred moments making one breath, one then knows the Great Dao is the complete body." To penetrate and unite them—this eulogy is it. Therefore, the Daoist crown, Confucian shoes, and Buddhist kasaya are not worn in vain.

The *Three Luminaries* revealed are called the *Heavenly Root*. As the Two Modes divide form and the Three Lights hang their radiance, all receive the *Beginning Qi*—hence it is the *Heavenly Root*. The *Inner Meaning* states: The scripture says, "The Dao gives birth to the One, the One gives birth to the Two, the Two give birth to the Three, and the Three give birth to the myriad beings." Thus, the *Scripture of the Spontaneous Origin of the Void and Natural* says: "Only when the Dao attains the Three is it complete." Hence it is said: "The Three unite to form virtue"; if the Dao does not fill the Three, nothing is accomplished.

The *Appended Sayings* states: "The *Yi* has the Supreme Ultimate, which gives birth to the Two Modes." From the One Qi, clear and turbid divide—this is the Three. The *Scripture of the Nine Heavens’ Generation of the Spirit* says: "Three qi combine to generate nine qi. The Three Qi are the ancestors of Heaven and Earth; the Nine Qi are the roots of the myriad beings. From the Three completing the Nine, they become the roots of beings—this is called 'the Three give birth to the myriad beings.' The Three unite to form virtue: in the Dao, they are the Three Qi; in beings, the Three Powers; in Heaven, the Three Lights; in humans, the Three Origins. All are the *Ancestral Qi* of the primordial beginning, the root of the myriad beings." Hence it is said: "The Three Luminaries revealed are the Heavenly Root."

With regard to the internal, borrowing metaphorical images, they are called *lead, mercury, and cinnabar*. Directly pointing to the thing itself, they are one’s inherent nature and the two qi of daily wondrous transformation—yin and yang. Though one may know the inherent nature, without understanding the function of the two realms, one still cannot avoid decline and decay.

Master Zhongli said: "The interpenetration of being and non-being is called the root of the elixir; the correspondence of concealment and revelation is *water and metal*..."
