chunks.original_text: 侍卫者，养正持盈、守雌抱一也。 送迎者，坎流於戊，离就於己也。 此乃功成而丹就也。 故《悟真篇》曰：取将次位心中实，点化离宫腹里阴。 从此变成乾健体，潜藏飞跃自由心。 如是则阳炁纯全，阴炁剥尽，离五行之数，脱八卦之机，故曰拔出地户五苦八难也。 阴炁绝於坤户，故曰七祖升迁，永离鬼官。 阳神聚於离宫，故曰魂度朱陵，受炼更生。 此乃脱胎神化、长生神仙也。 是谓无量，普度无穷，有秘上天文，诸天共所崇。 泄慢堕地狱，祸及七祖翁。 《内义》曰：大而天地，微而昆虫，此道具足，初无欠阙。 不以贵而与，不以贱而抑。 其所秘者，盖恐人之轻渎，倘能尊敬奉行，获福无量； 或有不馑，冥宪具存耳。 道言：此二章并是诸天上帝、及至灵魔王隐秘之音，皆是大梵之言，非世上常辞。 言无韵丽，曲无华宛，故谓玄奥，难可寻详。 《内义》曰； 此二章，混洞赤文、元洞玉历是也。 一明先天之道，一明后天之理。 隐秘之音，大梵之言，丹药玄微，理亦如之。 非世言辞，难以寻究，不因师旨，其可易为乎？ 上天所宝，秘於玄都紫微上宫，依玄科四万劫一传。 若有至人赍金宝质心，依旧格告盟十天，然后而付焉。 万劫如昨夜，千春如今朝。 则四万劫一传，亦非久远，此乃天真之格，非人世传受之期限也。 《内义》曰：此经此道，上天宝秘，授受有格，其可轻邪。 道言：夫天地运度，亦有否终。 否者，阳九百六之厄。 终者，三界消亡也。 日月五星，亦有亏盈。 至圣神人，亦有休否。 末学之夫，亦有疾伤。 天地圣人尚有休否，况末学之夫，宁无疾伤？ 倘有遭遇，甘之勿怨。 凡有此灾，同气皆当，齐心修斋，六时行香，十徧转经，福德立降，消诸不祥。 无量之文，普度无穷。 《内义》曰：人与天地万物，均一炁也。 故太上谓四众曰：凡彼有灾，同气皆当齐心修斋，行香诵经者，欲其一体同观也。 为人者讵宜以灵台置人我於其间？ 曾子曰：夫子之道，忠恕而已。 尽己之谓忠，推己之谓恕。 然则我之欲安，彼宁不欲安乎？ 故当己欲立而立人，己欲达而达人； 则不杀不害，不嫉不妬，不淫不盗，不贪不欲，不憎不，言无华绮，口无恶声。 齐同慈爱，异骨成亲，由此而致。 所谓欲为地仙，当立三百善； 欲为天仙，当立一千三百善，是不难也。 苟能遵行，何特成仙，太平之道毕矣。 道言：夫末学道浅，或仙品未充，运应灭度，身经太阴，临过之时，同学至人为其行香诵经十过，以度尸形如法。 魂神径上南宫，随其学功，计日而得更生。 转轮不灭，便得神仙。 《内义》曰：学力未至，数不可逃。 委蜕此形，视其已死。 然而足不青、皮不皱、目光不毁，屈伸从人。 依科作度尸之法，则神经阴炼，随其功业之浅深，准其年月之多少，时限既毕，神归返形，复得更生。 外虽终殁，经时积稔，有同时顷。 从兹已往，便得神仙，此亦得尸解之道也。 道言：夫天地运终，亦当修斋，行香诵 经。 星宿错度、日月失昏，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 四时失度，阴阳不调，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 此三者，造化不能逃乎数，假人力而助之，人力不能政其功，而道与之。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 疫毒流行、兆民死伤，亦当修斋，行香诵经。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who *escort and guard* cultivate correctness, sustain fullness, preserve the feminine, and embrace the One. Those who *send off and receive* are the flow of *kan* into *wu*, the movement of *li* toward *ji*—this is the completion of merit and the perfection of the elixir. Thus the *Wuzhen Pian* says:

*Take the solid from the next position in the heart,
Refine the yin within the Palace of Li.*
From this, it transforms into the firmness of *qian*,
A hidden, soaring, and free heart.

When yang *qi* is pure and complete, and yin *qi* is entirely stripped away, one transcends the reckoning of the Five Phases and escapes the mechanism of the Eight Trigrams—hence it is said: *delivered from the earthly realm’s Five Sufferings and Eight Difficulties.* Yin *qi* is severed at the Gate of *kun*, thus *seven generations of ancestors ascend, forever departing the ghostly officials.* The yang spirit gathers in the Palace of *li*, thus *the soul crosses the Vermilion Mound, undergoes refinement, and is reborn.* This is the divine transformation of shedding the mortal coil—*the immortal of eternal life.*

Such is the boundless, universally liberating power. It holds the secret celestial script, revered by all heavens. To leak or profane it is to fall into hell, bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Vast as heaven and earth, minute as insects, this Dao is complete, lacking nothing. It is not bestowed because of nobility, nor withheld because of lowliness. Its secrecy exists only to prevent disrespect. If one can revere and practice it, blessings are infinite; if one is negligent, dark retribution remains.

The Dao says: These two chapters are the hidden sounds of the Heavenly Emperors and the Divine Kings of Spirits—utterances of the Great Brahma, not the common speech of the world. Their words lack ornate rhythm, their melodies lack florid beauty; thus they are called profound and obscure, difficult to fathom.

The *Inner Meaning* states: These two chapters are the *Hundun Chiwen* and the *Yuandong Yuli.* One reveals the Dao of the Primordial Heaven, the other the principles of the Posterior Heaven. Their hidden sounds, the words of the Great Brahma, the mysteries of the elixir—all follow the same principle. Not being the language of the world, they are hard to investigate. Without a master’s guidance, how could they be easily understood?

This treasure of heaven is kept secret in the Purple Tenuity Palace of the Mysterious Capital. According to the celestial statutes, it is transmitted once every forty thousand kalpas. If a perfected person offers gold and treasures with a sincere heart, following the old protocol and pledging allegiance to the Ten Heavens, only then is it bestowed. Ten thousand kalpas are like last night; a thousand springs are like this morning. Thus, a transmission once every forty thousand kalpas is not truly distant—this is the celestial standard, not the timeframe of mortal transmission.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This scripture and this Dao are heavenly treasures, with strict protocols for transmission. How could they be treated lightly?

The Dao says: The revolutions of heaven and earth also have their ends. *End* refers to the calamity of the *yang* nine and hundred-six. *Termination* refers to the dissolution of the Three Realms. The sun, moon, and five planets also wax and wane. Even the most sagely and divine beings experience cycles of flourishing and decline. Lesser students also face illness and injury. If heaven, earth, and sages have their times of decline, how could lesser students avoid affliction? If one encounters such, accept it without resentment.

When such disasters arise, all of shared *qi* must act together: with unified hearts, perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times. Blessings and virtue will descend immediately, dissolving all misfortune. The boundless scripture universally liberates without end.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Humans, heaven, earth, and the myriad things are of a single *qi.* Thus the Most High addressed the four assemblies: When any among them face disaster, all of shared *qi* should unite in purification rites, burning incense and reciting scriptures—this is to view all as one body. How could one who cultivates the Dao place self and others in the chamber of the mind?

Master Zeng said: The Master’s Dao is nothing but loyalty and reciprocity. *Loyalty* is exhausting oneself; *reciprocity* is extending oneself to others. If I desire peace, how could others not desire it as well? Thus, when I wish to stand, I help others stand; when I wish to succeed, I help others succeed. Then there is no killing or harming, no jealousy or envy, no licentiousness or theft, no greed or desire, no hatred or resentment. Words are free of embellishment, speech free of malice. With unified compassion and love, even those of different bones become kin. This is how it is achieved.

It is said: To become an earthly immortal, perform three hundred good deeds; to become a heavenly immortal, perform one thousand three hundred good deeds—this is not difficult. If one can follow this, why merely become an immortal? The Dao of Great Peace will be complete.

The Dao says: If a student’s cultivation is shallow and their immortal rank incomplete, when their destined time of passing arrives and their body enters the Great Yin, at the moment of transition, fellow students and perfected ones should burn incense and recite the scripture ten times to deliver the corpse according to the method. The soul will ascend directly to the Southern Palace, and according to their merit, after a set number of days, they will be reborn. Escaping the wheel of rebirth, they will attain immortality.

The *Inner Meaning* states: If one’s practice is insufficient, fate cannot be escaped. Though this form is shed and appears dead, the feet do not turn green, the skin does not wrinkle, the eyes do not dim, and the limbs remain pliable. Following the protocol for delivering the corpse, the spirit undergoes refinement in the Yin realm. According to the depth of their merit and the length of their practice, after the allotted time, the spirit returns to the body, and they are reborn. Though outwardly deceased, after years or even decades, it is but a moment in time. From then on, they attain immortality—this is also the Dao of corpse liberation.

The Dao says: When the revolutions of heaven and earth end, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their regularity, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. These three cannot escape the reckoning of fate, but human effort can assist them. Human effort cannot alter their outcome, yet the Dao grants it.

When the ruler of a state faces disaster and warfare erupts on all sides, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When plague and pestilence spread, causing the death of the people, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures.

chunks.original_text: 师友命过，亦当修齐，行香诵经。 此三者，天不能神其用； 人成之，人不能极其挚，亦道与之也。 夫斋戒诵经，功德甚重，上消天灾，保镇帝王，下禳毒害，以度兆民。 生死受赖，其福难胜。 故曰无量，普度天人。 《内义》曰：人肖天之貌 ，身处阴阳之间，未离范围，宁免屯否。 造化潜运，寒暑密移，倘不以时消息，忽罹沴疫，岂无疾患乎？ 以内而言，所谓天地运终者，则数之尽也。 星宿错度，日月失昏者，乃神气浊乱，心目眩悸也。 四时失度、阴阳不调者，则燥湿寒温失宜、二炁乖理也。 所谓修斋行、香、诵、经者，即虚心炼炁，颐神葆真也。 可以济世垂死，弭患蠲疾矣。 其或国主有灾，兵革四兴，疫毒流行，兆民死伤，师友命过，当奋发忠诚，慈悲恻隐，禳禬消度，拯救济技，以资善果，积着阴功。 故曰斋戒诵经，功德甚重。 夫斋者，斋其心也。 颜子不饮酒，不茹荤，孔子谓祭祀之斋，非心斋也。 心斋者，虚其心也。 《道藏纪算录》云：清斋一旬，增算一纪； 清斋一日，增算十旬。 清斋即心斋是矣。 戒者，老君曰：夫学上道，不奉大戒而诵经行咒、佩符析神、合丹服药、隐处山林、求升仙之举，恐未可希也。 若能全戒於内，和光於外，乃庶几於灵标之崖矣。 非修行难，奉戒难耳。 子能全戒，念及十方，太上将保尔登仙矣。 戒全而诵宝经，佩大符而行事，若复不仙，则天下无有不死之道矣。 我所慨世，求其人难得耳。 夫有经而无戒，犹涉海而无舟楫，犹有口而无舌，何缘度兆身也。 夫道要在行合真科、积善内足，然后始涉大道之境界。 弗能耳者，皆为徒劳於风尘，无益於生命之修短也。 故戒有别文，略具其目：老君五戒，授尹真人一百八十戒，授干真人天师七十二戒，太清二十四戒，修斋行道十二戒，修真十戒，九真妙戒，灵宝九戒，正一五戒，其他具载经忏，不可尽名。 无非检心律己，止恶防非。 约而言之，思无邪、毋不敬而已。 所最急者，淫欲为先。 故曰淫欲为十败之首，杀又次之。 其他行妨於道事，碍於理，皆应去之。 经曰：损之又损，以至於无为。 凡行戒者，须当精详修习，或有不解，或有遗忌，或有谬误，或冒禁故，皆招愆罪，悉名破戒。 即应忏悔首谢。 西王母曰：夫好道慕仙者，精诚志念，斋戒思愆，辄除过一百，克己反善，奉敬真神，存真守一。 行此一月，辄除过一千。 如是则过者化、存者神、济世福国，其以美利利天下，阴阳和静，鬼神不扰，群生遂性，万物不伤。 外应如是，内应可知。 得不谓上消天灾，保镇帝王，下禳毒害，以度兆民，生死受赖，其福难胜？ 故曰无量普度天人乎。 元始无量度人上品妙经内义卷之四竟 元始无量度人上品妙经内义卷之五 观复子萧应叟学 道言：凡有是经，能为天地帝主兆民行是功德，有灾之日，发心修斋，烧香诵经十过，皆诸天记名，万神侍卫，右别至人，克得为圣君金阙之臣。 《内义》曰：前云天地运度否终、日月五星亏盈、至圣休否、末学疾伤，皆当修斋诵经。 又云：斋戒诵经，可消天灾、保帝王、禳毒害、度兆民，行是功德，皆诸天记名，万神侍卫，右别至人，得为圣君金阙之臣。 是则功归於我也。 故前辈谓善之一字，最能成就一切行。
chunks.translated_text:
When masters or friends face the end of their allotted span, one should likewise perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. In these three matters, Heaven cannot manifest its efficacy unaided; human effort brings them to fruition, yet human effort cannot exhaust their utmost sincerity—this, too, is granted by the Dao.

Now, purification rites and scripture recitation carry profound merit: above, they dissolve celestial calamities and safeguard the emperor; below, they dispel poisonous harms and deliver the multitudes. In life and death, all depend upon them, their blessings beyond measure. Thus it is said: boundless, they universally ferry across heaven and humanity.

The *Inner Meaning* states: Humans, bearing the form of Heaven, dwell between yin and yang, never departing the bounds of their mold—how could they escape hardship and adversity? The workings of creation move in secret; cold and heat shift imperceptibly. If one does not adjust in accord with the seasons, suddenly afflicted by pestilence, how could illness be avoided? Speaking inwardly, when "the movements of Heaven and Earth reach their end," this is the exhaustion of fate. When "the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their regularity," this is the turbidity and chaos of spirit and qi, the dizziness and palpitations of heart and eyes. When "the four seasons lose their order and yin and yang fall out of harmony," this is the imbalance of dryness and dampness, cold and warmth, the discord of the two qi. As for "performing purification rites, burning incense, and reciting scriptures," this is to empty the heart and refine qi, to nurture the spirit and preserve the true. It can succor the world and revive the dying, avert misfortune and dispel illness.

If the ruler of a state faces disaster, warfare erupts on all sides, plague and pestilence spread, causing the death of the people, or masters and friends face the end of their span, one should rouse loyalty and sincerity, compassion and pity, dispel calamities and rescue the afflicted, employing arts of salvation to accumulate good karma and amass hidden merit. Thus it is said: purification rites and scripture recitation carry profound merit.

Now, purification is the purification of the heart. When Yanzi abstained from wine and meat, Confucius called it the purification for sacrifice, not the purification of the heart. The purification of the heart is to empty the heart. The *Daoist Canon’s Record of Calculations* states: "A ten-day purification fast adds a twelve-year cycle to one’s lifespan; a one-day purification fast adds a hundred days." This purification is none other than the purification of the heart.

As for precepts, Lord Laozi said: "Those who study the supreme Dao yet do not uphold the great precepts—reciting scriptures, chanting incantations, wearing talismans, praying to spirits, compounding elixirs, ingesting medicines, or retiring to the mountains to seek ascent as immortals—may hardly hope for success. If one can fully uphold the precepts inwardly while harmonizing one’s light outwardly, one may approach the threshold of the numinous. It is not cultivation that is difficult, but upholding the precepts. If you can fully uphold the precepts, extending your thoughts to the ten directions, the Most High will ensure your ascent as an immortal. If one upholds the precepts fully, recites the precious scriptures, wears the great talismans, and performs the rites, yet still does not ascend as an immortal, then there is no path to deathlessness under Heaven. What I lament about the world is the rarity of such people."

To have scriptures without precepts is like crossing the sea without a boat or oars, like having a mouth without a tongue—how could one ferry across the multitudes? The essence of the Dao lies in aligning one’s conduct with the true regulations and accumulating goodness within; only then may one enter the realm of the great Dao. Those who cannot do so labor in vain amidst the dust, gaining nothing for the length of their lives.

Thus, precepts have distinct texts, their outlines briefly set forth: the Five Precepts of Lord Laozi, the One Hundred Eighty Precepts conferred upon Master Yin, the Seventy-Two Precepts conferred upon the Perfected Master Gan, the Twenty-Four Precepts of the Great Clarity, the Twelve Precepts for Purification Rites and Daoist Practices, the Ten Precepts for Cultivating the True, the Nine Wondrous Precepts of the Nine Perfected, the Nine Precepts of the Numinous Treasure, the Five Precepts of the Orthodox Unity—others are fully recorded in the scriptures and repentance texts, too numerous to name. Without exception, they serve to examine the heart and restrain the self, to cease evil and prevent wrongdoing. In short: think no deviance, respect all things. What is most urgent is to place lust first. Thus it is said: lust is the foremost of the ten defeats, killing comes next. Other actions that hinder Daoist practice or obstruct principle should all be abandoned. The scriptures say: "Diminish and diminish again, until reaching non-action."

All who uphold the precepts must meticulously study and practice them. If there is anything not understood, omitted, violated, or mistakenly transgressed, all incur transgressions and sins, collectively called "breaking the precepts." One should then repent and confess. The Queen Mother of the West said: "Those who yearn for the Dao and aspire to immortality must concentrate their sincerity and will, purify themselves and reflect on transgressions, thereby eliminating a hundred faults. Restraining the self and returning to goodness, revering the true spirits, preserving the true and guarding the One—practicing this for a month eliminates a thousand faults. Thus, faults are transformed, the preserved becomes numinous, the world is succored, the state is blessed, and all under Heaven enjoy its great benefits. Yin and yang harmonize and settle, ghosts and spirits do not disturb, all beings fulfill their natures, and the myriad things remain unharmed. Outwardly, this is the response; inwardly, the result may be known. How could it not 'dissolve celestial calamities above, safeguard the emperor, dispel poisonous harms below, and deliver the multitudes'? How could its blessings not be 'beyond measure, universally ferrying across heaven and humanity'?"

Here ends *Volume Four of the Inner Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Boundless Salvation of Humanity*.

*Volume Five of the Inner Meaning of the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Boundless Salvation of Humanity*

Observing Reversion said: Master Xiao Ying studied the Dao.

The Dao states: Whoever possesses this scripture and performs these meritorious deeds for Heaven and Earth, the emperor, and the multitudes—on days of disaster, rousing the heart to perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scriptures ten times—all the heavens record their names, the myriad spirits attend and protect them, and the distinguished Perfected Ones of the right distinguish them, enabling them to become ministers of the Golden Gates of the Sage Lord.

The *Inner Meaning* states: As previously said, when "the movements of Heaven and Earth reach their end, the sun, moon, and five planets wane and wax, the sagely flourish or decline, and the unlearned suffer illness or harm," one should perform purification rites and recite scriptures. It is also said: "Purification rites and scripture recitation can dissolve celestial calamities, safeguard the emperor, dispel poisonous harms, and deliver the multitudes. Performing these meritorious deeds, all the heavens record their names, the myriad spirits attend and protect them, the distinguished Perfected Ones of the right distinguish them, enabling them to become ministers of the Golden Gates of the Sage Lord." Thus, merit returns to oneself. Therefore, the ancients said: "The word 'goodness' is most capable of accomplishing all practices."

chunks.original_text: 愿人发善愿，天上闻之，声如爆竹，上真诸圣无不主持，心契故也。 经曰：既以为人己愈有，既以与人己愈多。 观经之旨，岂欺我哉！ 诸天记人功过，毫分无失。 天中魔王，亦保举尔身得道者，乃当洞明至言也。 旧注曰：修行是道，功德积着，诸天录善，魔王保举，自然玄解体真、通达经旨。 诸天中大梵隐语无量音 《内义》曰：大梵者，元始大梵之炁，离合以成音。 梵之言泛，六合无处不同。 隐语者，谓隐秘天中，世人不解。 无量音者，殊方异类，普闻妙义，无有限极。 凡二百五十六字，分置三十二天，各八字。 又书玄都宫阙及诸天楼观。 若能服其字，则随人所习，乘炁各归其处也。 按《内音经》云：元始天尊於赤明世界栢陵舍座，是时，云雾郁勃，三日三夜，玄阴不解。 五老上白天尊曰：今日侍座，所未曾见。 天尊演教，则河海静默，山岳藏云。 今白日昼阴，天人惶惧，不审何故？ 天尊曰：今日诸天发瑞，灵应自然，玉字焕斓，障蔽天光。 咸令四座暝目伏听。 俄顷，天炁顿启，冥暗豁消，五色光明洞照十方。 忽有灵书字方一丈，见於空玄之上，文彩焕烂，八角垂芒，精光夺目，不可得看。 天尊普告曰：此灵书八会，字无正形，其趣宛奥，难可寻详，可注解之。 於是天真皇人受天尊明命，注解其音，以付道君，使教诸天应得道成真、有仙名者也。 元始灵书中篇　　道君撰 《内义》曰：灵书所标白字，乃卦炁法象、节候时晷，先真谓此灵书合於大易六十四卦。 此经在天地之先，在有卦之前。 西王母以九日导乾坤毋东覆两卦显之，故乾坤二卦始於此，继以屯蒙，终於既未，为造化之纲维也。 次列六十甲子於下者，明炁数始终循环也。 次系月建节候十二卦者，以表一年阴阳伐谢、寒暑推迁也。 复别朔望盈亏者，以明一月也。 又标十二时辰者，以准一日火候，水符进退也。 盖以一年之节，陷於一月，两日半准一月。 复以十二卦，以应十二时者，又促一月归於一日也。 一时准两日半。 故上下卦象所用皆殊，甲子节候，其义亦别。 综而言之，上卦甲子，经也； 下卦节候时晷，纬也。 志士但观动静起伏、消息盈虚，自然得意忘言，幽微之理尽在是矣。 仍依天真皇人内音训释，或删繁取要，或加字益文以注之，盖欲使人皆晓意义耳。 亶娄阿苍，豫 丁丑 旧注曰：亶者，坦然旷远貌。 娄者，玉京山下长楼，上承玄都宫。 阿者，玄都宫阿那之神名也。 掌楼上之监，主大梵之炁，炁数交周，则阿那鸣楼都之鼓，集众真、朝元始，日三周而一鸣，以为常节。 苍者，帝君游台之名，苍郁华秀也。 无和观音。 随 戊寅　春分节应大壮卦，日应卯时。 旧注曰：无者，太无也。 言太无之中，自然能生真圣。 和者，日月门户名。 观，觉也，是天中帝君之讳。 音乃八字之音，能诵则真人乘金轮以开冥，玉女扬华凡旛以披钮。 观觉主长夜之录，四冥拔九幽之府，七祖披朗，朽骸还生。 此八字，乃黄曾天内音也。 须延明首，蛊 己卯 旧注曰：须延者，玉完西北阙名。 大劫数交，须延而开，玉真上圣於是而回。 明首者，元始之都侯也。 元始开运，则都候启道梵行，诸炁倏忽自朗。 法揽笠口昙。 临 庚辰
chunks.translated_text:
May one’s good intentions be voiced, and the heavens above shall hear them—resounding like the crack of firecrackers—whereupon the Perfected Ones and all the sages above will surely uphold them, for their hearts are in accord. As the scripture says: “Having acted for others, one finds oneself all the more enriched; having given to others, one finds oneself all the more abundant.” How could the purport of the *Contemplation Scripture* deceive us? The heavens record each person’s merits and transgressions, not missing even the slightest fraction. Even the demon-kings of the celestial realms will safeguard and commend those who attain the Way, for this is the luminous truth of the most profound teachings.

The old commentary states: In cultivating the Dao, as merit and virtue accumulate and become manifest, the heavens record one’s goodness, and the demon-kings protect and commend one, naturally leading to profound understanding, embodiment of the real, and penetration of the scriptures’ purport.

Within the heavens, the Great Brahma’s hidden language resounds with boundless tones. The *Inner Meaning* says: The Great Brahma is the primordial qi of the Original Beginning, which coalesces and disperses to form sound. *Fan* (梵) means “pervasive,” for it is the same throughout the six directions. “Hidden language” refers to the secrets of the celestial realms, which worldly people cannot comprehend. “Boundless tones” means that beings of all regions and kinds universally hear the wondrous meaning, without limit or end. Altogether, there are two hundred fifty-six characters, distributed among the thirty-two heavens, eight characters to each. They are also inscribed upon the palaces and towers of the Mysterious Capital and the various heavens. If one can ingest these characters, then according to one’s practice, one rides the qi and returns to one’s proper place.

According to the *Scripture of Inner Sounds*: Once, the Most High Lord of the Original Beginning was seated in the Cypress Mound Lodge of the Vermilion Brightness World. At that time, clouds and mist surged for three days and nights, and the dark yin did not disperse. The Five Elders addressed the Heavenly Worthy, saying: “Today, as we attend your seat, we witness what we have never seen before. When the Heavenly Worthy expounds the teachings, rivers and seas fall silent, and mountains and peaks conceal their clouds. Yet now, in broad daylight, darkness prevails, and the heavenly and human realms are filled with dread. We do not know the reason.” The Heavenly Worthy replied: “Today, the heavens have emitted auspicious signs, and numinous responses arise spontaneously. Jade characters gleam resplendently, obscuring the light of heaven. Let all in the four directions close their eyes and listen reverently.” In an instant, the celestial qi suddenly parted, the gloom vanished, and five-colored radiance illuminated the ten directions. Suddenly, a divine scripture appeared in the empty mystery above, its characters a full *zhang* in size, its patterns and hues dazzling, its eight corners trailing rays of light. The brilliance was so intense that none could gaze upon it directly. The Heavenly Worthy proclaimed to all: “This is the *Numinous Scripture of the Eight Assemblies*. Its characters have no fixed form; their import is subtle and profound, difficult to fathom. They must be annotated.” Thereupon, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign received the Heavenly Worthy’s luminous command and annotated its sounds, transmitting them to the Dao Lord, who taught them to all in the heavens who were destined to attain the Way, achieve Perfection, and gain immortal names.

---

**The Middle Section of the Numinous Scripture of the Original Beginning**
*Composed by the Dao Lord*

The *Inner Meaning* says: The white characters marked in the *Numinous Scripture* correspond to the symbolic forms of the hexagrams’ qi, the seasonal nodes, and the times of day. The ancient Perfected Ones declared that this *Numinous Scripture* accords with the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Great Change*. This scripture existed before heaven and earth, before the hexagrams came into being. The Queen Mother of the West, over nine days, guided the *Qian* and *Kun* hexagrams to manifest the *Mu* and *Dong* trigrams, so that *Qian* and *Kun* began with these, followed by *Zhun* and *Meng*, and concluding with *Ji Ji*, forming the warp and woof of creation. The sixty *jiazi* cycles listed below clarify the beginning and end of the qi’s numerical circulation. The twelve hexagrams of the monthly nodes and seasons that follow illustrate the waxing and waning of yin and yang, the advance and retreat of cold and heat over the year. The separate notations for the waxing and waning of the new and full moons clarify a single month. The twelve two-hour periods further mark the fire phases and the advance and retreat of the water tally within a single day. Thus, the nodes of a year are compressed into a month, and two and a half days correspond to a month. The twelve hexagrams that follow, matching the twelve two-hour periods, further condense a month into a single day. One two-hour period corresponds to two and a half days. Therefore, the upper and lower hexagrams differ in their applications, and the *jiazi* cycles and seasonal nodes also vary in meaning. In sum, the upper hexagrams’ *jiazi* are the warp, while the lower hexagrams’ seasonal nodes and times of day are the weft. The cultivated person need only observe the movements and stillness, the rises and falls, the waxings and wanings, and naturally will grasp the meaning beyond words, for the subtlest principles are all contained herein. Following the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s annotations of the inner sounds, some passages have been abridged to retain essentials, while others have been expanded with additional characters to elucidate the text, all to ensure that people may understand its meaning.

**Dǎnlóu Ācāng, Yù**
*Dīngchǒu*

The old commentary says: *Dǎn* describes a vast and boundless appearance. *Lóu* refers to the long tower beneath the Jade Capital Mountain, which supports the Mysterious Capital Palace. *Ā* is the name of the spirit of the palace’s eaves, who oversees the tower’s surveillance and governs the qi of the Great Brahma. When the qi’s cycles complete their circuit, *Ānà* sounds the drum of the tower capital, assembling the multitude of Perfected Ones to pay homage to the Original Beginning. This occurs three times daily, with one drumbeat, as the regular observance. *Cāng* is the name of the terrace where the Imperial Lord roams, lush with verdant splendor. *Wúhé Guānyīn*.

**Suí**
*Wùyín*   The Spring Equinox node corresponds to the *Great Strength* hexagram, and the sun corresponds to the *mǎo* hour.

The old commentary says: *Wú* is the Great Void. Within the Great Void, the true sages naturally arise. *Hé* is the name of the gate of the sun and moon. *Guān* means “awakening,” and is the taboo name of the Heavenly Emperor. The sound is that of the eight characters; reciting them enables the Perfected to ride the golden wheel and open the darkness, while the Jade Maidens wave flowered banners to unfasten the gates. The *Awakening* oversees the records of the long night, delivers the four dark realms, and rescues the nine nether palaces. The seven generations of ancestors are illuminated, and decayed bones revive. These eight characters are the inner sounds of the Yellow and Primeval Heavens.

**Xūyán Míngshǒu, Gǔ**
*Jǐmǎo*

The old commentary says: *Xūyán* is the name of the northwest gate of the Jade Perfection. When the great kalpas intersect, it opens at *Xūyán*, and the Jade Perfected and Upper Sages return. *Míngshǒu* is the title of the capital’s warden under the Original Beginning. When the Original Beginning initiates the kalpa, the warden opens the Dao and begins the Brahma practices, and the various qi suddenly become radiant. *Fǎlǎn Lìkǒu Tán*.

**Lín**
*Gēngchén*

chunks.original_text: 忽诃流吟。 噬嗑 壬午 旧注曰：忽，觉也，飞天神名也。 诃，诃摩也，天中呼元始天尊为诃摩。 流吟者，流布歌吟。 劫运既终，诃摩开化教法，普度天人，将来劫坏，真经隐藏，天尊已知，预为歌吟也。 人能常诵洞章，则主图先生削罪录於长夜，注生名於南宫也。 华都曲丽，贲 癸未　谷雨节，应夬卦，日应辰时。 旧注曰：华都者，天中太极宫青华门别令。 曲者，天中有梵天神人飞行太极之上，爽灵风之炁，歌洞章之曲。 丽是太和玉女之名也。 鲜菩育臻。 剥 甲申 旧注曰：鲜者，鲜云，即庆云也。 菩者，菩楼，即天中楼名也。 育者，帝君隐名。 臻，至也。 育帝常乘八景之轮，游观八极之外，至於鬼神之家，回十绝之旛以召天魔，举度天人也。 人能常诵洞章，则飞天遥唱，三界司迎，七祖出离长夜，上升南宫。 答落大梵，复 乙酉 旧注曰：答者，天中玉阙名。 落，落然也。 大者，大宥也。 天尊开运之初，皆放大赦，谓之大宥。 梵者，梵行之炁，开龙汉之劫，运赤明之辰矣。 散烟庆云，无妄 丙戌　　建巳月立夏节。 旧注曰：散烟者，真人散香於玉阙。 庆云者，五色备也。 庆云接乎紫馆，飞天舞乎空轮。 飞洒玉都，大畜 丁亥 旧注曰：飞者，飞天神人之号。 天地改运，沦於延康，冥冥无开，飞天启光，於是散晖，诸天受炁也。 洒者，龙汉一会，倏欻而回。 玉者，玉真主开长夜之圣号。 都者，九幽之酆都。 人有善功，则玉真开长夜之户，酆都度八难之场。 七祖还生，幽魂扬光也。 明魔上门。

**Hūhē Liúyín.**
*Shìkè*
*Rénwǔ*
The Ritual of the Chen Month’s End, Grain Rain Festival.

The old commentary says: *Hū* means "awakening" and is the name of a Flying Heavenly Spirit. *Hē* is *hēmó*, the title by which the Heavenly Worthies invoke the Primordial Heavenly Worthy. *Liúyín* means "flowing chants." When the kalpic destiny reaches its end, *hēmó* reveals the teachings to transform and universally deliver heaven-dwellers and humans. Before the kalpic dissolution arrives, the Heavenly Worthy, already foreseeing the concealment of the true scriptures, preemptively chants these verses. Those who constantly recite the cavernous chapters will have the Heavenly Master of Diagrams erase their transgressions from the records of eternal night and inscribe their names in the Southern Palace.

**Huādū Qūlì, Bì**
*Guǐwèi*
Grain Rain Festival, corresponding to the *Guài* hexagram, with the sun aligned at the *chén* hour.

The old commentary says: *Huādū* is a special commission of the Great Ultimate Palace’s Azure Flower Gate in the heavens. *Qū* refers to the Brahmanic divine beings who soar above the Great Ultimate, singing the melodies of cavernous chapters upon the invigorating winds of the *shuǎnglíng* qi. *Lì* is the name of a Jade Maiden of Supreme Harmony.

**Xiānpú Yùzhēn.**
*Bō*
*Jiǎshēn*

The old commentary says: *Xiān* refers to *xiānyún*, the auspicious clouds. *Pú* is *púlóu*, the name of a heavenly tower. *Yù* is the hidden name of an Imperial Lord. *Zhēn* means "to arrive." The Imperial Lord of *Yù* perpetually rides the wheel of the Eight Radiances, roaming beyond the Eight Poles to the abodes of ghosts and spirits. There, he unfurls the banners of the Ten Absolutes to summon heavenly demons and universally deliver heaven-dwellers and humans. Those who constantly recite the cavernous chapters will have Flying Heavenly Spirits chant from afar, the Three Realms’ administrators welcome them, and their seven ancestors emerge from eternal night to ascend to the Southern Palace.

**Dāluò Dàfàn, Fù**
*Yǐyǒu*

The old commentary says: *Dā* is the name of a jade tower in the heavens. *Luò* means "falling open." *Dà* refers to the Great Amnesty. At the inception of the Heavenly Worthy’s kalpic revolution, universal pardons are granted, known as the Great Amnesty. *Fàn* is the qi of Brahmanic conduct, inaugurating the Dragon Han kalpa and setting in motion the era of Red Clarity.

**Sànyān Qìngyún, Wúwàng**
*Bǐngxū*
The Ritual of Establishing the Fourth Month, Beginning of Summer Festival.

The old commentary says: *Sànyān* refers to the Realized Ones dispersing incense in the jade towers. *Qìngyún* are the five-colored auspicious clouds. As the auspicious clouds ascend to the Purple Mansion, Flying Heavenly Spirits dance in the celestial wheel.

**Fēisǎ Yùdū, Dàxù**
*Dīnghài*

The old commentary says: *Fēi* is the title of the Flying Heavenly Spirits. When heaven and earth undergo kalpic transformation and sink into the *Yánkāng* era, plunging into boundless darkness, the Flying Heavenly Spirits illuminate the light, dispersing radiance so that all heavens receive the qi. *Sǎ* refers to the swift revolutions of the Dragon Han kalpa. *Yù* is the sacred title of the Jade Perfected Lord who opens the gates of eternal night. *Dū* is *Fēngdū*, the nether capital of the Nine Dark Realms. Those who accumulate meritorious deeds will have the Jade Perfected Lord open the gates of eternal night and *Fēngdū* deliver them from the Eight Tribulations. Their seven ancestors will be reborn, and the souls of the departed will shine forth. The Demon Lords ascend to the gates of enlightenment.

chunks.original_text: 颐 戊子　　小满节应乾卦，日应巳时。 旧注曰：明者，解八字之义。 魔者，魔王。 上者，上帝也。 门者，门下也。 人能明识八字之义，则魔王敬服，上帝育养於始生之神门。 门下有韩君司命司录、度算於南宫，庆流九族，生死蒙恩也。 无行上首，大过 己丑 旧注曰：无者，上道也。 言元始之炁，开明元上之道。 行者，天元之纲纪，维罗八极，梵炁弥布，流行不息也。 上首者，北斗之罪宫也。 回蹶流玄。 坎 坎者，水也。 玄，龟也。 化，机也。 阴内含阳象，铅中有真银，阴无阳不能自莹其魄，故名雄金； 属北方，谓之坎男。 旧注曰：回，转也。 跖，履也。 劫运之初，元始则履空而轮转，布化於十方。 流者，流晨之光，照长夜之府。 玄者，空也。 越衡天上玄都之景，有空峰之山，万圣之所游，生死之所归，道未足备，身应灭度，魂升空峰，受炼而度南宫也。 阿陀龙罗，离 离者，火也，朱雀也，化机也。 阳内含阴，象砂中有真汞。 阳无阴不能自耀其魂，故名雌火，属南方，谓之离女。 旧注曰：阿者，天中有九折之山，连阿相属。 陀者，山上之楼，上通玉清之炁，以望三界之乡。 帝君常游阿丘之岭，下监万生之罪。 龙者，龙山与阿陀相去九亿万里。 罗者，日月之名。 上清九天真人呼日为濯。 罗，言山势相交，日月明於峰上。 四象吁员。 咸 庚寅

At *Yí* (戊子), the *Lesser Fullness* solar term aligns with the *Qian* hexagram, and the day corresponds to the *Si* hour.

The old commentary says: *Míng* means to elucidate the meaning of the Eight Characters. *Mó* refers to the Demon Lords. *Shàng* is the Supreme Emperor. *Mén* is the gate below. If one can clearly comprehend the meaning of the Eight Characters, the Demon Lords will revere and submit, and the Supreme Emperor will nurture and sustain the spirit-gate of one’s initial birth. Beneath the gate, Han Jun, the Controller of Destiny and Registrar of Records, calculates and measures in the Southern Palace, bestowing blessings upon the nine clans, so that both the living and the dead receive grace.

*Wúxíng Shàngshǒu* (无行上首), *Dàguò* (己丑)

The old commentary says: *Wú* is the supreme Dao. It speaks of the primordial qi of the Origin Beginning, which opens the luminous Dao of the primordial origin above. *Xíng* is the guiding principle of the Celestial Origin, weaving through the eight directions, with Brahmanic qi pervading and circulating without cease. *Shàngshǒu* is the Sin-Palace of the Northern Dipper. It revolves and stumbles, flowing into the mysterious.

*Kǎn*
*Kǎn* is water. *Xuán* is the tortoise. *Huà* is the mechanism. The yin within contains the yang symbol; within lead lies true silver. Yin without yang cannot refine its own essence, hence it is called "masculine metal." Belonging to the north, it is called the *Kǎn* male.

The old commentary says: *Huí* means to revolve. *Zhí* means to tread. At the inception of the kalpic revolution, the Origin Beginning treads the void and wheels in revolution, disseminating transformation throughout the ten directions. *Liú* is the flowing light of dawn, illuminating the palace of eternal night. *Xuán* is emptiness. Beyond the celestial balance of the *Xuándū* in the heavens above, there is the *Kōngfēng* Mountain, where myriad sages wander, where the living and the dead return. When the Dao is not yet fully attained and the body is destined for extinction, the soul ascends to *Kōngfēng*, undergoes refinement, and is measured in the Southern Palace.

*Ātuó Lóngluó*, *Lí*
*Lí* is fire, the Vermilion Bird, the mechanism of transformation. The yang within contains yin; within cinnabar lies true mercury. Yang without yin cannot radiate its own spirit, hence it is called "feminine fire." Belonging to the south, it is called the *Lí* female.

The old commentary says: *Ā* refers to the nine-fold mountains in the heavens, connected in continuous ridges. *Tuó* is the tower upon the mountain, which ascends to the qi of the Jade Purity and gazes upon the realms of the Three Worlds. The Lord Emperor often roams the peaks of *Āqiū*, overseeing the transgressions of all beings. *Lóng* is Dragon Mountain, separated from *Ātuó* by nine hundred million miles. *Luó* are the names of the sun and moon. The Perfected of the Nine Heavens of Highest Purity call the sun *Zhuó*. *Luó* describes how the mountain’s form intertwines, with the sun and moon shining above its peaks.

The Four Symbols exhale and inhale in harmony.

*Xián* (庚寅)

chunks.original_text: 咸，感也。 乃中宫交会之所。 四象吁员，合此卦者可见经旨符契，真精元炁。 至於中宫龙虎交缔，阴阳得类，金水停均，坎离既济，甘露降、黄芽生、是为还丹之质。 咸之为卦，艮下兑上，经曰地藏发泄，金玉露形，兹足明矣。 旧注曰：四者，四极之宫。 谓东华、南极、西灵、北真也。 四极真人主生死命籍。 象者，象轮之车，真人常乘象辇，游行三界，校人生死罪录，开度学道之人。 吁，育也，是天帝讳，为南宫度命君主，炼度朽魂也。 员者，童也。 是日中生童，主灌津於天人也。 人能诵咏洞章，则玉名入於帝箓，生死度於南宫，四极给自然之羽车，七祖欢游於福堂也。 已上六十四字系东方八天真文。 南爓洞浮，恒 辛卯　　建午月、芒种节。 旧注曰：南爓者，南方有流火之庭，广七万里，飞焰焕乎八方。 洞浮者，洞阳之宫，流火之炁，炎而浮流也。 玉眸诜诜。 遁 壬辰
chunks.translated_text:
"Xián" means "resonance." It is the place of union in the Central Palace. When the Four Symbols exhale and inhale in harmony, those who align with this hexagram may perceive the essential concord of the scriptures, the true essence, and the primordial qi. As for the intertwining of Dragon and Tiger in the Central Palace, yin and yang unite in kind, Metal and Water achieve balance, Kan and Li attain completion—sweet dew descends, the yellow sprout arises, and this is the substance of the Returned Elixir.

The hexagram *Xián* consists of *Gèn* below and *Duì* above. The scripture states: "The earth’s treasury releases its secrets; gold and jade reveal their forms." This is sufficiently clear.

The old commentary says: The "Four" refers to the palaces of the Four Poles—namely, the Eastern Flower, Southern Pole, Western Numinous, and Northern Perfected. The Perfected of the Four Poles govern the registers of life and death. "Symbol" refers to the chariot of the symbolic wheel; the Perfected constantly ride these symbolic carriages, roaming the Three Realms to audit the records of beings’ lives and deaths, and to initiate those who cultivate the Dao.

"Xū" means "nurturing." It is the taboo name of the Heavenly Emperor, who presides as the Lord of Life-Measurement in the Southern Palace, refining and delivering decayed souls. "Yuán" means "youth." It is the Youth Born at Midday, who pours divine fluid upon the heavenly and earthly beings. If one recites and chants the cavernous scriptures, their jade name enters the Emperor’s register, their life and death are delivered in the Southern Palace, the Four Poles bestow natural feathered chariots, and their seven ancestors rejoice in the Hall of Blessings.

The above sixty-four characters constitute the True Writ of the Eight Heavens of the East.

The Cavernous Floating of the Southern Crimson—*Héng* (恒), *Xīn-Mǎo* (辛卯), established in the month of *Wǔ*, during the Grain in Ear solar term.

The old commentary says: The "Southern Crimson" refers to the Flowing Fire Courtyard in the south, seventy thousand miles in breadth, its flying flames blazing across the eight directions. "Cavernous Floating" refers to the Cavernous Yang Palace, where the qi of flowing fire burns and floats. The jade pupils gleam brilliantly.

*Dùn* (遁), *Rén-Chén* (壬辰).

chunks.original_text: 旧注曰：玉眸者，流火之膏，炼身体、生玉光、明如眸子。 南极真人理於宫内，诸学人始得道者，皆诣流火之庭。 南极真人以火膏洗炼，荡除尘垢，即与真人为侣。 诜诜者，众多也。 梵形落空，壮 癸巳　　月望。 旧注曰：梵形者，元始天尊在龙汉时号也。 赤明世号无名君，上皇开运号元始丈人。 梵炁随劫化生，以一神而见，不受胎生。 落空者，谓元始自空而生也。 九灵推前。 晋 甲午　　夏至节，应媾卦，月亏日，应午时。 一阴始生，乃砂中抽汞。 《龙虎经》曰：正阴发离午，赤水流为汞者也。 真阴下降，如月之象，复还中宫，阴归阳室，汞来投铅矣。 旧注曰：九灵者，南宫九华真人也。 王九幽宿对死魂。 推前者，真人主命录推算死魂前生功德， 译落菩台，明夷 乙未　　泽音托，落亦作@、音壑。 旧注曰：泽者，天中山窟。 其山上有众龙之窟，黄房之室。 落者，真晨道君之内名。 理於黄房，混大劫而不终，经龙汉而更明。 菩者，飞天真人之隐号，有无数之众。 台者，玉台也，处凙山之阳。 绿罗大千。 家人 丙申　　建未月、小暑节。 旧注曰：绿罗者，月中天人，字罗英理，在日月之宫，上乘大罗之天，梵行之炁，运度之关，以应天地之数，终於大劫。 既受交於日月，则会於玉台之上。 大千者，世界之数。 陆先生云：以千数至千，即千千为小千，小千数至千，为中千，中千数至千，为大千也。 人能诵咏洞章，则得驾羽轮之车，升黄房之室，游玉台之上，览大千之境也。 眇莽九丑，睽 丁酉 旧注曰：眇者，玉字翳而不彰，眇眇然也。
chunks.translated_text:
The old commentary states: The "jade pupils" are the essence of flowing fire, which refines the body, generates jade radiance, and shines as brilliantly as the eyes. The Perfected of the Southern Culmen govern within the palace, and all those who first attain the Dao proceed to the Courtyard of Flowing Fire. The Perfected of the Southern Culmen washes and refines them with the fire’s essence, purging the dust and filth, whereupon they become companions to the Perfected. *Shēnshēn* (诜诜) means "multitudinous."

The Dharma-body descends from emptiness,
*Zhuàng* (壮), *Guǐ-Sì* (癸巳), at the full moon.

The old commentary states: The "Dharma-body" was the title of the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginning during the Dragon Han kalpa. In the Crimson Clarity kalpa, he was called the Nameless Lord; in the Highest Sovereign’s kalpa, he was called the Primordial Venerable. The Dharma-qi transforms and manifests through kalpas, appearing as a single spirit without undergoing womb-birth. "Descends from emptiness" means the Primordial Beginning arises from emptiness.

The Nine Numinous Ones advance forward,
*Jìn* (晋), *Jiǎ-Wǔ* (甲午), at the Summer Solstice, corresponding to the *Gòu* hexagram, on a waning-moon day, at the hour of *wǔ*.

As the first yin arises, cinnabar draws forth mercury. The *Scripture of Dragon and Tiger* says: "When true yin stirs at *lí-wǔ*, the Red Water flows as mercury." True yin descends like the moon’s image, returning to the Central Palace; yin returns to the yang chamber, and mercury comes to merge with lead.

The old commentary states: The "Nine Numinous Ones" are the Nine Radiant Perfected of the Southern Palace. King Nine governs the dark lodges of the dead. "Advance forward" means the Perfected oversee the ledgers of destiny, calculating the merits of the dead from past lives.

Transcribed in the Terrace of Transcendence,
*Míngyí* (明夷), *Yǐ-Wèi* (乙未). *Zé* (泽) is pronounced *tuō*; *luò* (落) is also written as *@*, pronounced *hè*.

The old commentary states: *Zé* refers to the grottoes of the Heavenly Center Mountain, where dragons gather in yellow chambers. *Luò* is the inner name of the Perfected of the Dawn Dao Lord, who governs within the Yellow Chamber, enduring through the great kalpa without end and growing ever brighter through the Dragon Han kalpa. *Pú* (菩) is the hidden title of the Flying Celestial Perfected, numbering beyond count. *Tái* (台) is the Jade Terrace, located on the southern slope of Mount É.

The Verdant Net spans the great chiliocosm,
*Jiārén* (家人), *Bǐng-Shēn* (丙申), in the month of *wèi*, at the Lesser Heat solar term.

The old commentary states: The "Verdant Net" is the celestial being of the moon, named Luó Yīnglǐ, who resides in the palace of the sun and moon, ascending to the Great Net Heaven. The Dharma-conduct qi governs the pivot of kalpic transformation, aligning with the numerology of heaven and earth and enduring until the great kalpa. Having received the union of sun and moon, one meets upon the Jade Terrace. "Great chiliocosm" refers to the enumeration of worlds. Master Lù says: Counting a thousand to a thousand makes a small chiliocosm; counting a thousand small chiliocosms makes a medium chiliocosm; counting a thousand medium chiliocosms makes a great chiliocosm. Those who recite and chant the Cavernous Writ shall ride the feathered-wheel chariot, ascend to the Yellow Chamber, wander above the Jade Terrace, and behold the realm of the great chiliocosm.

The Nine Uglies are obscure and vast,
*Kuí* (睽), *Dīng-Yǒu* (丁酉).

The old commentary states: *Miǎo* (眇) means the jade script is veiled and not manifest, appearing faint and distant.

chunks.original_text: 莽者，其文复明，莽莽然也。 遇真道，男女并皆寿三万六千岁； 其运之极，又经一劫，九炁各生一兽，以害恶民。 其劫既开，而九兽号九丑之鬼，北帝上真主生死图录，故立九丑以辅三官。 数极九九八十一万，度天炁之交，九丑当得辅，号为九都使者。 韶谣缘邅。 赛 戊戌　　大暑节、应遁卦，日应未时。 旧注曰：韶者，皇笳天神霄王内名。 神霄王是魔王之神，主常试学道之人正与不正，作谣歌以乱人心。 心固者，王即保举，升上皇笳天也。 缘邅者，南北二斗君之内讳。 人有善功则列言於南斗，南斗即度三界之难，技九幽之苦，告下魔王，不敢害败之也。 人有恶则三官列罪於北斗，北斗即告下魔王，灭魂付九幽之下，充长夜之役，万劫无期矣。 云上九都，解 己亥 旧注曰：云上者，飞天神王之内讳。 开龙汉劫，启赤明运，敷自然之书，立天地之根也。 九都者，三象既分，而有九层之台，处乎玉京之山，焕乎玄空之上，飞天神人常散百合之香，流五云之华以观飞天真人。 台上有太真玉郎，一日三回十绝之旛，回旛一周，则诸天上帝三朝玄台，绕台三匝，诵咏洞章。 飞生自骞。 损 庚子
chunks.translated_text:
"Mǎng" (莽) signifies that its script shines again, vast and boundless.

When one encounters the true Dao, both men and women shall live for thirty-six thousand years. At the culmination of this cycle, after enduring one kalpa, the nine qi each give birth to a beast to harm the wicked. Once the kalpa unfolds, these nine beasts are called the Nine Uglies of ghosts. The Northern Emperor and the Perfected of the Upper Realm preside over the Register of Life and Death, thus establishing the Nine Uglies to assist the Three Officials. When the count reaches eighty-one myriad, at the convergence of heavenly qi, the Nine Uglies are fit to serve as aids, known as the Envoys of the Nine Capitals.

The *Sháo* hymns follow the *Yuán-Zhān* cycle.
*Saì* (赛), *Wù-Xū* — at the Great Heat solar term, corresponding to the *Dùn* hexagram, the day aligns with the *Wèi* hour.

The old commentary states: *Sháo* is the inner name of the Celestial Sovereign of the *Huáng-Jiā* Heaven. The Celestial Sovereign of *Shén-Xiāo* is the spirit of the Demon King, who constantly tests those who study the Dao to discern whether they are upright or not, composing songs to disturb the human mind. Those with steadfast hearts are protected and recommended by the Sovereign, ascending to the *Huáng-Jiā* Heaven. *Yuán-Zhān* is the inner taboo name of the Northern and Southern Dipper Lords. When one accumulates good deeds, they are recorded by the Southern Dipper, which then delivers them from the tribulations of the Three Realms and the sufferings of the Nine Darks, notifying the Demon King below to refrain from harming or corrupting them. If one commits evil, the Three Officials list their sins before the Northern Dipper, which then instructs the Demon King below to extinguish their souls and consign them to the depths of the Nine Darks, where they toil in eternal night for ten thousand kalpas without end.

Above the Nine Capitals, *Jiě* (解), *Jǐ-Hài*.
The old commentary states: "Above the Clouds" is the inner taboo name of the Flying Celestial Divine King. At the dawn of the *Lóng-Hàn* kalpa, the *Chì-Míng* cycle was inaugurated, the spontaneous scriptures were bestowed, and the roots of heaven and earth were established. The Nine Capitals refer to the nine-tiered terrace that arose after the Three Images were divided, situated upon the Jade Capital Mountain, resplendent above the Mysterious Void. Flying celestial beings constantly scatter the fragrance of a hundred lotuses and strew the blossoms of the five clouds to behold the Flying Perfected. Upon the terrace stands the Jade Lad of the Great Perfected, who thrice daily waves the Ten Absolute Banners. With each revolution of the banners, the Divine Emperors of all heavens thrice circumambulate the Mysterious Terrace, chanting the Cavernous Writ in procession.

The flying ones ascend of their own accord.
*Sun* (损), *Gēng-Zǐ*.

chunks.original_text: 旧注曰：景者，景黄也，是四极上真人也。 蔚者，蔚秀也，景霄仙人也。 并理玉京台，常历校长夜之中开度善根之魂。 萧，仞也。 是白素元君之宫。 嵎者，萧仞之嵎，对宾之所。 人能常诵洞章，乃得驾九色之云，而上升景黄之台矣。 易邈无寂，归妹 癸丑　　霜降节、应剥卦，日应戌时。 旧注曰：易邈者，孝芒天王之号也。 无寂者，虚无寂寂之庭也。 言天王从龙汉而来，至赤明而出，居乎虚无之内寂寂之庭。 宛首少都。 丰 甲寅 旧注曰：宛首者，太上道君内号也。 道君常开元始玄奥，演大法以度人。 少都者，日中灵童之名，常散日精以灌真流，飞华以拂尘。 学人知八字之音，则天王飞景云之舆，降三素之耕，度身三界之上，进入寂寂之庭也。 阿褴郁竺，旅 乙卯 旧注曰：阿褴者，天王隐名也。 常乘景霄之轮，游九层之台，处玉楼之上，唱洞章以伏魔王。 郁者，默郁是天中魔王隐名。 竺，欲也。 是魔王都伯常在砍界之上，咏空谣之歌。 华漠延由。 巽 丙辰　　建亥月、立冬节。 巽者，风也。 凡物之生，赖其吹嘘而．得长养华实。 阴非风不凝，阳非风不融。 《易》曰：随风，巽。 君子以申命行事，服夫申命行事，亦阴阳施用之理也。 旧注曰：华者，言色界光华也。 漠者，言欲界渺漠不可寻也。 延是束鬼之庭，由是禁鬼之房。 天王登云楼之上，咏无量之章，则天魔应响而束身，群鬼诣由而伏形。 奉之者九祖开泰，修之者灰骸更生也。 九开自辩，兑 丁巳 兑者，金虎也。 金者，水之化机。 间隔幽微之理，已释于前矣。 旧注曰：九开自辩者，大演之初，天地未封，轮转三炁，开为九分。 九度既明，九位乃列，阴阳万品於是可而生，自然明辩也。 阿那品首。 涣 戊午　　小雪节，应坤卦，日应亥时。 旧注曰：阿者，阿丘天王内名也。 常驾龙軿，登龙山之岭，游观九玄之中。 那者，那邪飞天神人隐名也。 飞行三界，历校长夜，技度善人之魂，有知八字之音，则天王品度兆身，首化枯骨，成童子之颜矣。 无量扶盖，节 己未 旧注曰：无量者，无量大圣之始神也。 总统飞天之神人，皆受其品量而得升迁也。 扶者，更生真人内名。 常校幽夜之录，简善恶之根。 盖者，玄中福堂之号也。 浮罗合神。 中孚 庚申 旧注曰：浮者，幽魂受真人开度，谓之浮也。 罗者，大罗也。 开大千之界，召更生之宾，诣大罗之天，定籍削死。 合者，合庆也。 神者，神公也。 是大罗丞相，人能知八字之音，与神公合庆，度为更生之宾，勿故曰合神。 玉诞长桑，小过 辛酉　　建子月、大雪节。 旧注曰：玉诞者，昙誓天中玉都名也。 长桑者，天中骞林亦名桑林也。 栢空度仙。 既济 壬戌

chunks.original_text: 受胎之后，神藏肾中，是谓坤宫。 谓之性，曰铅； 化机运归中官； 化机乃日用发生之阳炁。 而为丹基药祖，谓之元精； 收摄砂汞，而为丹质。 夫造化者，从元生有，故坤因乾而立，乾因坤而成。 乾坤相互而生成，初无先后。 伊川曰：造化无端，阴阳无始。 譬若铅因银而生，银因铅而成之理。 按，道经曰：此两者同出而异名。 如是先真上圣推物理而明造化，强以铅、银、砂、汞而喻丹旨者何也？ 盖欲后世易以明矣。 旧注曰：坤母者，太阴都候九灵母也。 理东海扶桑旸谷之渊，常总地机，转轮元炁，上应天关； 天关转、地机动，周天一度，水则涌溢三千三百度。 天地炁交，九海冥一，水则弥天。 东者，东海。 受会制期河源也。 覆者，水神理於昆仑山，填固巨海，遏断东井，则地机不泄，保劫长存。 形摄上玄。 屯 甲子　　冬至节，应复卦，月朔，日应子时。 一阳来复，妙用之炁，自坤宫而发生。 古经曰：阳炁黑发坤，日晷南极，五星连珠，日月合璧。 又曰：金精一化，青龙受符，阳爻是池。 真阳上升，如日之象。 至於中宫，金母收摄，是为砂也。 砂者，木也。 木者，龙也。 此青龙受符也。 旧注曰：形摄者，灾交之时，坤母形出东河之上，摄召鸟母，以凤车迎学仙之人，上昆仑之墟。 鸟母，乃水之候神。 上者，坤母上诣帝君，申劫会之期，度学仙之人，言名於玄都也。 陀罗育邈，蒙 乙丑 旧注曰：陀者，天帝内名，与妙成天俱生在云阿之岭。 罗是月始生之名，陀在云岭之上，抱月而明。 育是神王名，总统十方，飞天之神。 邈是天中羽林监神名。 神王常使匡御三 界，简人生死之籍，令魔王保度得道之人也。 眇炁合云。 需 丙寅　　建丑月、小寒节。 旧注曰：眇炁者，人得保度，诣羽林监受符升天，眇眇行云炁也。 合者，合景也。 既入羽林，结云炁成衣，遂与诸天合景上飞也。 飞天大丑，讼 丁卯 旧注曰：飞天者，飞玄之炁，结成洞空之经。 飞天神王常诵之，以接学者。 大者，三界都录，主生死图籍。 丑，伯也。 是三界大魔，受事於大丑。 学士识八字之音，则魔王保真而身腾三清矣。 总监上天。 师 戊辰　　大寒节、应临卦、日应丑时。 旧注曰：总是飞天都统之官，常摄八会之炁以保天地之运，监领长夜之官，开度幽魂。 人知天中之音，则天魔列言，大丑勒录仙部，上升禁上天也。 沙陀劫量，比 己巳 旧注曰：沙者，常融天内紫微别馆沙兰之宫。 陀者，陀丘之众，有巨亿万人，并是新得道受度者，功德未备，停散宫中。 劫量者，每至劫运一交，此陀丘之众计功量德，升朱陵之宫，受福而仙也。 龙汉瑛鲜。 小畜 庚午

After the adept receives the embryo, the spirit conceals itself within the kidneys—this is called the *Kun* Palace. It is termed *nature*, and called *lead*; the mechanism of transformation returns to the Central Palace. This mechanism is the yang qi of daily arising and generation. As the foundation of the elixir and the ancestor of medicine, it is called *primordial essence*; gathering and refining cinnabar and mercury, it forms the substance of the elixir.

Now, in the workings of creation, existence arises from the primordial, and so *Kun* is established through *Qian*, while *Qian* is completed through *Kun*. *Qian* and *Kun* mutually generate and complete one another, with no before or after. As Yi Chuan said: "Creation has no beginning; yin and yang have no origin." It is like the principle by which lead arises from silver, and silver is completed by lead.

According to the *Daoist Scriptures*: "These two emerge as one with different names." Why then do the ancient perfected and supreme sages, in elucidating the principles of things and clarifying the workings of creation, forcibly employ lead, silver, cinnabar, and mercury as metaphors for the elixir’s mysteries? It is simply to make it easier for later generations to understand.

The *Old Commentary* states: The *Kun* Mother is the Great Yin’s capital, the Ninefold Spirit Mother. She governs the abyss of the Eastern Sea’s Fusang and Yang Valley, ever controlling the earth’s mechanism, turning the wheel of primordial qi, and corresponding above to the Celestial Pass. When the Celestial Pass turns and the earth’s mechanism moves, the heavens complete one revolution, and the waters surge forth in thirty-three hundred degrees. When the qi of heaven and earth intermingle, the nine seas merge into one, and the waters fill the sky.

The *east* refers to the Eastern Sea, the meeting point and controlling source of the river’s origin. *Covering* means the Water Spirit governs Kunlun Mountain, filling and securing the vast sea, blocking the Eastern Well—thus the earth’s mechanism does not leak, and the kalpa’s long preservation is ensured. It also says: "When the metal essence undergoes its first transformation, the Azure Dragon receives the talisman, and the yang line is the pool." True yang ascends like the image of the sun. Upon reaching the Central Palace, the Metal Mother gathers and refines it—this is called *cinnabar*. *Cinnabar* is wood; wood is the dragon. This is the Azure Dragon receiving the talisman.

The *Old Commentary* states: *Gathering form* refers to the time of calamitous conjunction, when the *Kun* Mother’s form emerges above the Eastern River, summoning the Bird Mother with a phoenix chariot to welcome the adept ascending to the wastes of Kunlun. The Divine King constantly commands the guardians of the Three Realms, reviewing the registers of human life and death, and ordering the demon kings to protect and deliver those who attain the Dao.

Once entering the Feathered Forest, they weave cloud qi into garments and then ascend together with the heavens, merging with the luminous essence.

chunks.original_text: 夫玄科有制，不敢违命，按笔之日，神冲太霄，精之与粗，极乎心虑。 皇道既明，诸天称庆； 宝之者真降，修之者表迁，威灵恢廓，难可名焉。 已上六十四字，系北方八天真文也。 道言：此诸天中大梵隐语无量之音， 隐语是天帝之名，隐而不显。 无量之音者，真洞章，自然响彻诸天也。 《内义》曰：大梵隐语，无量之音，乃自然妙炁结而成文。 凡天地之道，皆在其中。 虚实相通，象数可见，以九日导乾推之，理无遗矣。 夫乾始於北者，即阳生於子也。 甲子配乾，子为黄锺，故甲子始於冬至。 《汉志》曰：伏牺之作《易》者，纪阳炁之初，以为律法，建日冬至而声以黄锺为官，此声炁之元也。 《国朝会要》曰：古者，黄锺为万事根本，由是观之，九日导乾位，即梵炁之始，甲子之首也。 一炁所播，万汇均被，四时生成，岂外是炁隐语之道，造化亦然。 还丹者，循体大梵而修尔。 四象五行、三元八卦、日月龙虎、砂汞铅银隐语之中，俱备至於阴符。 火候温养，抽添非依卦炁升降，甲子循环，茫然无凭，何以取则。 故乾、坤、坎、离四卦而象天、地、日、月，包囊万物，为鼎器药物枢纽根宗。 余六十卦以应甲子之数，准则春秋，推移寒暑，分二十四炁，擘七十二候，以一年十二月之节，归於一月之内； 以一月之候陷于一昼夜十二时中，定刻漏、正时晷、明子午、按阴阳、通晦朔、合龙虎，依天地之大数，叶阴阳之化机。 故卦有三百八十四爻，爻有三百八十四铢，由是万化凭虚而生。 不知虚之生我欤，我之生虚欤？ 大梵之理，其道大矣。 旧文字皆广长一丈，天真皇人昔书其文，以为正音。 隐语旧来本文，字广一丈，八角垂芒。 天真皇人於龙汉中书写，仍训释之。 有知其音，能斋而诵之者，诸天皆遣飞天神王下观其身，书其功勤，上奏诸天、万神朝礼，地祇侍门。 大勋魔王保举，上仙道备，克得游行三界，升入金门。 此音无所不辟，无所不禳，无所不度，无所不成，天真自然之音也。 《内义》曰：此无量之音，能辟逐一切精邪，能消禳一切灾害，能度脱一切生死，能成就一切天人。 故谓之天真灵书、自然玉字。 至若金丹之道，乃大梵自然元精妙气，契虚合无。 修之者，诸天鉴观，万神默佑，功圆道备，必证神仙。 所谓丹者，既曰契虚合无，固非有形有质。 妄者云：大若弹丸，色同朱橘，何谬之甚！ 是不识金丹为何物也。 若云无亦非也，有亦非也； 或有或无，亦非也； 非有非无，亦非也。 然虽如是，毕竟若何？ 盖金丹者，寓物见质，丽物无形。 何谓寓物见质？ 故《清静经》云：大道无形，生育天地，道虽无形，天地可见其形也。 大道无情，运行日月，道虽无情，日月可察其情也。 大道无名，长养万物，道虽无名，万物可识其名也。 何谓丽物无形？ 内观其心，心无其心，不着也。 故虚外观其形，形无其形，不有也。 故无远观其物，物无其物，不碍也。 故空此见丹道契虚合无，无余蕴矣。 皆由体自然而然，不强为而为，所以大梵隐语谓天真自然之音。 故能无所不辟，无所不禳，无所不度，无所不成。 合大易，准甲子，成造化，契金丹。 无所不辟者，永离无有也。 无所不禳者，照用皆空也。 无所不度者，超越生死也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Daoist regulations have their decrees, and none dare disobey the mandate. When taking up the brush, the spirit soars to the Great Empyrean, refining both essence and coarse matter to the utmost of one’s heart and thought.

Once the August Way is made manifest, the myriad heavens rejoice in celebration. Those who treasure it receive the descent of Perfected Ones; those who cultivate it attain promotion in rank. Its majestic numen is vast and boundless, defying all description.

The above sixty-four characters constitute the *True Writ of the Eight Heavens of the North*.

The Dao declares: These are the great Brahmā’s hidden words and the boundless sounds within the heavens. The hidden words are the names of the Heavenly Thearchs, concealed and not revealed. The boundless sounds are the *True Cavern Chapters*, whose natural resonance pervades all heavens.

The *Inner Meaning* states: The great Brahmā’s hidden words and boundless sounds are formed from the spontaneous coagulation of wondrous qi. All the principles of Heaven and Earth reside within them. Void and solid interpenetrate, images and numbers become visible. When guided by the nine days to deduce the Qian hexagram, no principle remains unilluminated.

That Qian begins in the north signifies yang’s birth at *zi*. *Jiazi* is paired with Qian, and *zi* corresponds to the Yellow Bell, hence *jiazi* commences at the winter solstice. The *Han Records* state: Fu Xi’s composition of the *Yijing* marked the inception of yang qi, establishing it as the standard for pitch. The day of the winter solstice is governed by the Yellow Bell, the origin of sound and qi.

The *Collected Essentials of the Imperial Dynasty* states: In antiquity, the Yellow Bell was the root of all affairs. From this perspective, the nine days guiding the Qian position mark the beginning of Brahmā qi and the inception of *jiazi*. As this qi spreads, the myriad beings are equally nourished. The four seasons and their transformations—how could they lie outside the Way of this hidden-qi language? Creation itself operates thus.

The elixir of return follows the body’s cultivation of the great Brahmā. Within its hidden words are contained the Four Symbols, Five Phases, Three Origins, Eight Trigrams, sun and moon, dragon and tiger, cinnabar and mercury, lead and silver—all culminating in the *Yin Talisman*. Fire times, gentle nurturing, extraction, and replenishment depend on the hexagrams’ qi ascending and descending, the cyclical flow of *jiazi*. Without these, one gropes in vain for a standard.

Thus, the four hexagrams Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li represent Heaven, Earth, sun, and moon, encompassing the myriad things as the crucible, vessel, medicine, and pivot of the root. The remaining sixty hexagrams correspond to the *jiazi* cycle, aligning with the seasons, shifting through cold and heat, dividing into the twenty-four qi, and subdividing into the seventy-two seasonal markers. The nodes of the twelve months are condensed into a single month; the markers of a month are embedded within the twelve hours of a day and night. One fixes the water clock, corrects the sundial, clarifies *zi* and *wu*, regulates yin and yang, harmonizes darkness and dawn, unites dragon and tiger, follows the great reckoning of Heaven and Earth, and accords with the transformative mechanism of yin and yang.

Thus, the hexagrams comprise three hundred eighty-four lines, and each line contains three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. Thereby, the myriad transformations arise from the void. Is it the void that gives birth to me, or I who give birth to the void? The principle of the great Brahmā—how vast is its Way!

The ancient script was a full *zhang* in length. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign of old inscribed its text to establish the correct pronunciation. The original hidden words, each character a *zhang* wide, bore eight-pointed rays. During the Dragon Han era, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign transcribed and annotated them.

Those who know their sounds and can fast and recite them will have the flying Heavenly Deva-Kings descend to observe their person, record their merit and diligence, and report to the heavens. The myriad spirits will pay homage, earth deities will attend at the gate, and the Great Merit Demon-Kings will sponsor their promotion. Once the Dao of the Upper Immortals is complete, they may roam the Three Realms and ascend through the Golden Gate.

This sound repels all, dispels all, delivers all, and accomplishes all—it is the natural sound of the Heavenly Perfected Ones.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This boundless sound can repel and expel all demonic spirits, dissolve and avert all calamities, deliver and liberate all from birth and death, and bring to fruition all heavenly and human endeavors. Thus, it is called the *Heavenly Perfected Numinous Writ* and the *Natural Jade Characters*.

As for the Way of the Golden Elixir, it is the great Brahmā’s spontaneous primordial essence and wondrous qi, uniting with the void and merging with non-being. Those who cultivate it are observed by the myriad heavens, silently aided by the ten thousand spirits. When merit is complete and the Dao perfected, they will surely attain immortality.

The term *elixir* denotes union with the void and merging with non-being—it is fundamentally without form or substance. Those who speak falsely claim it is as large as a pellet and red as a tangerine—how utterly mistaken! They know not what the Golden Elixir truly is.

To say it is neither existent nor non-existent is also incorrect; to say it is sometimes existent and sometimes non-existent is likewise wrong; to say it is neither existent nor non-existent is still amiss. Yet if this is so, what then is it?

The Golden Elixir lodges in things to reveal its substance yet adorns things without form.

What does it mean to *lodge in things to reveal its substance*? Thus, the *Scripture of Purity* states: The Great Dao is formless yet gives birth to Heaven and Earth—though the Dao is formless, Heaven and Earth reveal its form. The Great Dao is passionless yet moves the sun and moon—though the Dao is passionless, the sun and moon reveal its passion. The Great Dao is nameless yet nurtures the myriad things—though the Dao is nameless, the myriad things reveal its name.

What does it mean to *adorn things without form*? Inwardly observe the heart: the heart has no heart—it is unattached. Thus, outwardly observe form: form has no form—it is not possessed. Thus, distantly observe things: things have no things—they are unimpeded. Thus, when this void is seen, the elixir’s Way unites with the void and merges with non-being, leaving no residue.

All arises from the body’s natural spontaneity, not through forced action. Hence, the great Brahmā’s hidden words are called the natural sound of the Heavenly Perfected Ones. Therefore, they can repel all, dispel all, deliver all, and accomplish all.

In harmony with the *Great Change*, aligned with *jiazi*, they complete creation and unite with the Golden Elixir.

*Repels all* means eternal separation from all existence.
*Dispels all* means illumination and function are all empty.
*Delivers all* means transcending birth and death.

chunks.original_text: 无所不成者，造化天地也。 略言其大，则小者可知矣。 故诵之，致飞天下观，上帝遥唱，万神朝礼，三界侍轩，群祆束首，鬼精自亡，琳琅振响。 金书玉字，故曰琳琅也。 诵咏枢吟，故曰振响也。 十方肃清，河海静默，山岳吞烟，万灵振伏，招集群仙。 诵此则琼林振天籁之响，十方晏三景之明，河海风浪而澄静，山岳吞纳乎云烟，伏万灵而震慑，招群仙而诣室也。 天无氛秽，地无祆尘。 天无氛秽之气，地无祆尘之灾也。 《内义》曰：功满行圆，道成德就者，飞天下观书功也。 上帝遥唱，称赞也。 万神朝礼，敬仰也。 三界侍轩，翼卫也。 群妖束首，魔贼伏也。 鬼精自亡，尸虫灭也。 琳琅振响，自然感应也。 十方肃清，纯素无杂也。 河海静默，性情冥也。 山岳吞烟，神息定也。 万灵振伏，众圣钦也。 招集群仙，无非真也。 天无氛秽，阳无愆也。 地无祆尘，阴无伏也。 冥慧洞清，大量玄玄也。 《内义》曰：此明诸天内音，冥通慧照之力也。 冥者，幽深不测； 慧者，通照无穷。 慧能照空，故曰冥慧。 高而不极谓之洞，焕耀三清谓之清。 洞，空也。 清，静也。 无边无际，谓之大量。 大量之内，唯有真空。 真中有精，其中有信，能生真圣，非有非无，常住湛然，微妙莫测，究竟其理，不可寻详。 玄中更玄，故曰玄玄也。 上圣慈怜下界，降此真经，列以玄科，开人度物。 诵咏之者，上感诸天，佩服灵文，即随炁所至，功圆行满，升为金阙之臣。 是如积学通真入圣，生天生地，应用无穷； 能知玉字之音，骨肉同飞有日矣。 上学之士，勤而勉之。 ○天尊叙经首，言造化於始，末言大梵於终。 此其所以体用循环而无穷也。 恐学者不悟，常清常静之理，堕於执有执无之见。 故明诏之曰：冥慧洞清，大量玄玄。 夫冥则契虚合无，慧则圆明妙智，洞则通达无碍，清则澄莹无形。 大量则无所不容，难以测度； 玄玄则妙中更妙，不可思议。 若然者，言龙虎不滞於弄精魂，谈性命不偏於执空寂，十方通彻，八面玲珑。 经曰：用其光，复归其明； 此之谓也。 夫道之於人，不啻慈母之爱赤子，覆之载之，生之育之，至於分身降世，陈纲立纪，礼君臣、正上下，生有所养，死有所藏。 其或出类拔萃者，则与相为终始； 若乃华目以随世，畏死而希仙者，因其学功而成就之。 片善不遗，可谓至矣。 人能体道，皆无怀葛天氏之民； 经不必出，教不必立可也。 惟其不仁，则我有己经，由是出教，由是立焉。 故有天堂、地狱之报，是亦为劝善惩恶之权耳。 或者谓一死则已，更有何物？ 天堂地狱皆无是事。 斯言也，达则达矣，其奈若何！ 今夫人死之后，或梦之，或见之，或附人而言，或凭物而灵； 由是观之，固不得谓一死则已、更有何物也。 神清之洞，清燕之堂，白骨埋形，水狱阴惨，又不可谓天堂地狱，皆无是事也。 天尊曰：众生未悟，故有摄因； 众生既悟，摄因何在？ 地狱天堂，孰非假合？ 此皆人心自造，岂得一切拨为无因果乎。 太上常善救，人故不爱道。 诱谕世俗，勿错用心，使其返性冥情，舍恶从善，上可超凡入圣，次可解化登真，又其次隐遁长生； 下则延年安乐，生生世世不失人身，熏习性根，亦证仙道。 比之疾病婴缠、夭伤危厄、非命横亡、沉沦恶趣者，孰得孰失，达士必能详择焉。
chunks.translated_text:
*Accomplishes all* means the creation of Heaven and Earth. To speak briefly of the great is sufficient, for the small may then be inferred.

Thus, when one recites it, the flying immortals descend to observe below, the Celestial Emperor sings from afar, the myriad spirits pay homage, the Three Realms attend in reverence, the host of demons bow their heads, and ghostly essences vanish of themselves. The jade tablets and golden script resound—hence "jewel-like tones." The recitation and chanting of the pivotal verses—hence "vibrant resonance." The ten directions grow solemn and pure, rivers and seas fall silent, mountains and peaks swallow the mist, the ten thousand spirits tremble in submission, and the assembly of immortals is summoned.

When this is recited, the jade groves shake with celestial music, the ten directions bask in the radiance of the Three Luminaries, rivers and seas still their winds and waves, mountains and peaks inhale the clouds and mist, the ten thousand spirits are subdued in awe, and the host of immortals gathers at one’s chamber.

Heaven is free of defiling vapors, Earth is free of demonic dust. Heaven is without the qi of defilement; Earth is without the calamity of demonic dust.

The *Inner Meaning* states: When merit is complete and conduct perfected, when the Dao is achieved and virtue established, one ascends to observe the records of merit below. The Celestial Emperor sings from afar in praise. The myriad spirits pay homage in reverence. The Three Realms attend as guardians. The host of demons bow their heads, and demonic thieves submit. Ghostly essences perish of themselves, and corpse-worms are extinguished. The jewel-like tones resound—this is spontaneous resonance. The ten directions grow solemn and pure—utterly unadulterated. Rivers and seas fall silent—nature and emotion merge in darkness. Mountains and peaks swallow the mist—spirit and breath settle into stillness. The ten thousand spirits tremble in submission—the multitude of sages stand in awe. The assembly of immortals is summoned—none but the true are gathered. Heaven is free of defiling vapors—yang is without transgression. Earth is free of demonic dust—yin is without concealment. Dark wisdom illumines the pure—vast and profoundly mysterious.

The *Inner Meaning* states: This reveals the inner sound of the heavens, the power of dark penetration and luminous insight. *Dark* means profound and unfathomable; *wisdom* means illumination without limit. Wisdom can illuminate the void—hence "dark wisdom." Lofty without end is called *illuminating*; radiant throughout the Three Clarities is called *pure*. *Illuminating* is emptiness; *pure* is stillness. Boundless and limitless is called *vast capacity*. Within this vast capacity, only true emptiness exists. Within the true lies essence; within essence lies sincerity. It can generate true sages, neither existing nor non-existing, eternally serene and subtle beyond measure. To exhaust its principle is impossible. Within the mysterious lies yet deeper mystery—hence "profoundly mysterious."

The Most High, in compassion for the lower realms, bestowed this true scripture, arranging it in mysterious statutes to open the way for beings and deliver creatures. Those who recite and chant it move the heavens above, who revere and embrace its sacred text. As their qi reaches its destination, merit is perfected and conduct fulfilled, and they ascend as ministers of the Golden Towers. Thus, through accumulated study, one penetrates the true and enters sagehood, born in Heaven or born on Earth, with limitless application. Those who know the sound of the jade script will one day ascend with flesh and bone together. Scholars of the highest learning, strive diligently.

At the beginning of the Heavenly Worthy’s discourse, creation is spoken of at the outset; at the end, the Great Brahmā is spoken of in conclusion. This is how its essence and function cycle endlessly. Fearing that learners may not awaken to the principle of constant purity and stillness, falling into the views of clinging to existence or non-existence, the scripture clearly proclaims: *Dark wisdom illumines the pure, vast and profoundly mysterious.*

*Dark* means uniting with the void and merging with non-being; *wisdom* means perfect clarity and wondrous insight; *illuminating* means penetrating without obstruction; *pure* means limpid and formless. *Vast capacity* means all-embracing and beyond measure; *profoundly mysterious* means wondrous within the wondrous, beyond conception.

Thus, when speaking of dragon and tiger, one does not stagnate in manipulating essence and spirit; when discussing nature and destiny, one does not lean toward clinging to emptiness and quiescence. The ten directions are thoroughly permeated, and all eight sides are transparent. As the scripture says: *Use its light, return to its clarity*—this is the meaning.

The Dao’s relation to humanity is no less than a loving mother’s care for her infant: it shelters and sustains, gives life and nurtures. Even to the point of dividing its body and descending into the world, it establishes the warp and weft, orders ruler and subject, rectifies high and low, provides sustenance in life and burial in death. For those who stand out from the multitude, it remains with them from beginning to end. As for those who follow the world with flowery eyes, fear death, and seek immortality, it perfects them according to their learning and merit. Not a single good deed is overlooked—this may be called the ultimate.

If people could embody the Dao, all would be like the people of Huai and Getian, without need for scriptures to emerge or teachings to be established. Yet because of their lack of benevolence, I have this scripture, and thus the teachings arise, and thus they are established. Hence, there are the retributions of Heaven and Hell—this is but a provisional means to encourage good and punish evil.

Some say that with death, all ends—what else could there be? Heaven and Hell are both unreal. Such words may be penetrating, but what can be done about them? Now, after a person dies, they may appear in dreams, be seen, speak through others, or possess objects and manifest numinosity. From this, it cannot be said that with death, all ends—what else could there be? The pure caverns of spirit, the tranquil halls of the clear, the burial of white bones, the gloom of the watery prisons—these cannot be dismissed as unrealities of Heaven and Hell.

The Heavenly Worthy says: *Before beings awaken, there are karmic conditions; once beings awaken, where are the karmic conditions? Heaven and Hell—who is not a temporary convergence? These are all created by the human mind. How can one sweepingly deny cause and effect?*

The Most High ever excels at saving, yet people do not love the Dao. Thus, the scripture admonishes the worldly, urging them not to misuse their minds, to return to their nature and darken their emotions, to abandon evil and follow good. At the highest, one may transcend the ordinary and enter sagehood; next, one may dissolve transformations and ascend to the true; next, one may withdraw and attain long life. Below, one may extend years in peace and joy, never losing human form across lifetimes, nurturing the root of nature until one also attains the immortal Dao. Compared to those afflicted by illness, bound by suffering, cut off in youth, endangered, dying unnaturally, or sinking into evil destinies—who gains and who loses? The discerning will surely choose wisely.

chunks.original_text: 梵炁玄辽天宝自然八合之音 元始灵书下篇　　天真皇人撰 《后释》曰：谨按，《灵宝度人上品妙经》，汉元封中，西王母下降，授武帝，已为第七授。 中间传授，经传不显，其在天卷秩繁多，此才一品。 至晋，太极左宫仙公，於会稽上虞，上感太极真人徐来勒所受《度人经》，即有《灵书下篇》，及《太极真人后序》，授经众真，聚集终散之文，方成全篇。 自后以兵火之变，抱朴子葛洪於郑真人思远所受，其后止於大量玄玄也。 其下篇遗失，不可考复，故世无全经，莫可而得。 今昌运流行，天吏下降，以其阙文续于经末。 诵咏之者，得本经二章三篇之妙范； 修用之者，备全品十过十方之殊功，斋戒遵行，则上清可跻矣。 《五牙经》曰：天真皇人者，不知其得道之始，然是前劫修真极道之人也。 身长九尺，玄毛被体，皆长尺余。 黄帝时在峨眉山绝阴之下，苍玉为屋，黄金为座，张华罗旛，然千和之香，侍者仙童玉女，座宾三人，皆称太清仙王。 黄帝再拜问道，授以五牙三一之文。 东方八天 森□储云，九魂炼精。 枳默窥玦，浮枚臼。 鹿几杨房，碧提酇回。 池滇党负，蚑逭谒携。 澡章变瑜，兰泮璧坏。 亢滂野生，极中昆清。 曜展洞涸，寂无眇凝。 素倚虚罗，皇达元灵。 南方八天 炎镀绰堂，太霄瑶隅。 历遐荐漪，周扃加图。 披峣蹊臄，觚亶浑都。 戟芸荼炫，井欺持蒲。 掌维迮仪，奕洸琅璀。 扁缕益但，幽微毕雷。 涓湟实东，赤曜丛稽。 玉玄演侯，栢璖至规。 西方八天 镐正左适，婆泥杀灵。 悲招均疆，洎南缠魁。 静夷损光，混元觉缘。 道守岑遥，绵征知宣。 太灵湮漠，炳和卢随。 哲京常华，墟咸坚沙。 栗铎黜株，会衍球裴。 卓云青府，业睹般基。 北方八天 洼孩蒙甘，翠宇九阑。 萧钩涟兴，龙汾神关。 沟沦泬魔，豁蛮祈通。 玄寥亢息，无知肆明。 蟒修吉夕，馥坛时畎。 汤长敷昌，匪庸谨济。 朝康圣宽，秘法侈宜。 广帝理生，卫肇宏人。 《后释》曰：此与中篇隐语为相类，非如中篇有皇人内训可考。 然东方森字从木，南方炎字从火，西方镐字从金，北方洼字从水、土。 水、土俱旺於北，而孩字从亥从子，必关涉天地造化之妙理。 得道者乃当洞明至言也。 天真皇人梵炁玄辽天宝自然八合之音，主治世会地垒洪泽、灾变厄难。 诵咏之者，禳辟祆殃，清静道炁，无不宁也。 地官奉书，百灵畏敬，神朱写文，服佩明验。 施之於至学，不宣於下俗也。 太极真人颂曰 神云焕层虚，梵罗屯碧霄。 元始九龙驾，皇人按青轺。 灵光集万真，珠影闿阳寥。 出示灵宝篇，福德由是招。 洞玄隐高严，玉音泛云璈。 无量匪得思，道海生波涛。 法义同涓流，滋植成嘉苗。 用以账穷饥，教兴卫中朝。 帝尊寿亿年，太平灭兵刀。 稽首望玉晨，灵华散金毫。 太极真人曰： 太上玉晨大道君居紫霞之上七映之天，纪录玄文，玉妃捧经，金童散香，太一执巾，玉郎侍筵。 龙吟虎嗥，庆云蒙霭。 十方天真大神、上圣高尊、妙行真人、无极飞天神王、三界大魔、九天丈人、无鞅数众，吟咏玉经，归依太上灵宝妙法。 昌运流行，亿劫长存。 诵经十徧毕，叩齿三十六通，心拜十方而起，南面下座，东向立。 心礼三拜，密咒曰： 臣诵经已竟，向来所出身中三五功曹、左右官使者、侍香金童、传言玉女、五帝直符、宜日香官，各三十二人，请还入臣身中，复於宫室，毋令差互。
chunks.translated_text:
The Celestial Qi’s Mysterious and Vast Heavenly Treasure: The Spontaneous Eightfold Harmonies
*Lower Scroll of the Numinous Writ of Primordial Commencement*
Composed by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign

**Postface Exegesis** states:
According to careful examination, *The Wondrous Scripture of the Upper Chapters on Salvation through the Numinous Treasure* was bestowed upon Emperor Wu of Han during the Yuanfeng era by the descent of the Queen Mother of the West, marking the seventh transmission. Between transmissions, the lineage remained obscure, with only this single chapter surviving among the celestial scrolls’ vast ranks. By the Jin dynasty, the Immortal Duke of the Left Palace of the Great Ultimate in Shangyu of Kuaiji, moved by the revelation of the Perfected Xu Laile of the Great Ultimate, received *The Scripture of Salvation*, which included *The Lower Scroll of the Numinous Writ* and *The Postface of the Perfected of the Great Ultimate*. These were conferred upon the assembled immortals, gathering the texts of their final dispersal to form a complete corpus. Thereafter, due to the ravages of war and fire, Ge Hong of the *Baopuzi* received the transmission from the Perfected Zheng Siyuan, though it extended no further than the *Great Measure of the Mysterious Mysterious*. The Lower Scroll was lost, rendering it irrecoverable, and thus the world lacked the complete scripture, unattainable in its entirety.

Now, as the propitious fortune flows and celestial officials descend, the missing text is appended to the scripture’s end. Those who recite and chant it attain the wondrous model of the original scripture’s two chapters and three scrolls; those who cultivate and apply it fulfill the full merit of the ten transgressions and ten directions. Through fasting and observance, one may ascend to the Upper Clarity.

*The Scripture of the Five Teeth* states:
The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s origins in the Dao remain unknown, yet he was one who perfected the ultimate Dao through cultivation in a prior kalpa. His stature measured nine feet, his body covered in dark fur, each strand over a foot long. During the Yellow Emperor’s reign, he dwelled beneath the Absolute Yin of Mount Emei, his abode wrought of azure jade, his seat of yellow gold. Banners of patterned silk fluttered, and the fragrance of thousand-fold harmony burned. Attended by immortal youths and jade maidens, with three seated guests, all styled as Perfected Kings of the Great Clarity, the Yellow Emperor bowed twice to inquire of the Dao and was granted the texts of the *Five Teeth* and *Three Ones*.

**Eastern Eight Heavens:**
Forest-dense clouds amass, nine souls refine essence.
*Jimo* gazes through jade rings, floating plumes and pestles.
Deer benches and willow chambers, azure vines coil and return.
Pool depths bear burdens, crawling creatures retreat and advance.
*Zaozhang* transforms jade, orchid pools shatter jade.
Vast surges wild-born, utmost within Kun’s clarity.
Radiance unfolds through cavernous drought, silence without the faintest congealment.
White leans on the empty net, the august reaches the primordial numen.

**Southern Eight Heavens:**
Flaming forges in spacious halls, the Great Empyrean’s jasper corners.
Through distant tides, offerings ripple, encircling seals add diagrams.
Traversing towering paths, *gudan* and *hundu* merge.
Halberds of artemisia blaze, wells deceive with rushes.
Palms maintain constricted rites, luminous brilliance cascades.
Carved threads augment but, the subtle and minute complete thunder.
Tiny streams fill the east, crimson radiance thickens.
Jade mystery evolves lords, cypress jade attains the compass.

**Western Eight Heavens:**
Refined rectitude veers left, *Poni* slays the numinous.
Sorrow summons balanced borders, extending southward to entwine the *Kui*.
Tranquil Yi diminishes light, the Primordial Awakens to conditions.
The Dao guards distant peaks, silk’s征 knows proclamation.
The Great Numen submerges in desert, radiant harmony follows *Lusui*.
Wise capitals bloom eternally, ruins and sands harden.
Chestnut bells cast out stocks, assemblies extend to *Qiupei*.
Eminent clouds of the Azure Mansion, karma beholds *Banji*.

**Northern Eight Heavens:**
Hollow children embrace sweetness, jade eaves of nine gates.
Reeds and hooks stir ripples, dragon’s *Fen* guards the numinous pass.
Ditches and abysses dissolve demons, vast barbarians pray for passage.
Mysterious desolation’s vast breath, the unknowing indulge in clarity.
Pythons cultivate auspicious evenings, fragrant altars mark the fields.
Hot springs spread prosperity, not mediocrity but reverent aid.
Morning tranquility and sagely generosity, secret methods expand fittingly.
The Vast Emperor governs life, guards the grand inception of humanity.

**Postface Exegesis** states:
This resembles the cryptic language of the Middle Scroll, lacking the Heavenly Perfected’s inner teachings found therein. Yet the Eastern character *sen* (森) derives from wood, the Southern *yan* (炎) from fire, the Western *hao* (镐) from metal, and the Northern *wa* (洼) from water and earth. Water and earth both flourish in the North, and the character *hai* (孩) combines *hai* (亥) and *zi* (子), surely relating to the wondrous principles of Heaven and Earth’s creation. Only those who attain the Dao may thoroughly comprehend these profound words.

The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign’s *Celestial Qi’s Mysterious and Vast Heavenly Treasure: The Spontaneous Eightfold Harmonies* governs the governance of worldly kalpas, earthly ramparts, vast marshes, calamities, and dire adversities. Those who recite it dispel demonic misfortunes, purify the Dao’s qi, and find all tranquility. Earth officials present the writ, the hundred spirits revere and respect it, divine vermilion transcribes the text, and wearing or bearing it yields evident efficacy. Applied to the utmost study, it is not proclaimed to the vulgar below.

**The Perfected of the Great Ultimate’s Hymn** states:
Divine clouds gleam in layered voids, the Brahma-net gathers in azure skies.
Primordial Commencement’s nine dragons draw the chariot, the Sovereign reins the azure carriage.
Numinous light gathers the myriad Perfected, pearl shadows open the sun’s desolation.
Revealing the Numinous Treasure’s scroll, blessings and virtue thereby summoned.
The Cavernous Mystery conceals lofty solemnity, jade tones ripple like cloud-borne zithers.
The Immeasurable defies contemplation, the Dao’s ocean births waves and billows.
Dharma principles flow like rivulets, nurturing and cultivating fine sprouts.
Applied to relieve the destitute and hungry, the teaching flourishes to guard the central court.
The Emperor’s honor endures for myriad years, Great Peace abolishes blades of war.
Bowing heads toward the Jade Dawn, numinous blossoms scatter golden rays.

**The Perfected of the Great Ultimate** states:
The Most High Lord of the Jade Dawn and Great Dao resides above the Purple Mist in the Sevenfold Radiance of Heaven, recording the mysterious writ. Jade consorts bear the scripture, golden youths scatter incense, the Great One holds the towel, jade lads attend the banquet. Dragons chant and tigers roar, auspicious clouds shroud in mist. The ten directions’ Perfected Celestial Deities, exalted sages, Perfected of Wondrous Conduct, boundless flying heavenly kings, great demons of the three realms, elders of the nine heavens, and innumerable hosts chant the Jade Scripture, taking refuge in the Most High Numinous Treasure’s wondrous Dharma. As propitious fortune flows, it endures for kalpas uncounted.

Upon completing ten recitations of the scripture, knock the teeth thirty-six times, bow in the heart to the ten directions, rise, face south to descend the seat, and stand facing east. Bow three times in the heart and secretly intone:
Your servant has completed the scripture’s recitation. The thirty-five merit officials of the body’s emanations, the attendants of the left and right, the incense-bearing golden youths, the message-transmitting jade maidens, the five emperors’ direct talismans, and the incense officials of the appointed days—thirty-two each—are entreated to return into your servant’s body and resume their places within the palace chambers, without error or confusion.

chunks.original_text: 后召复到，一如故事。 次精思身中诸神各还宫讫，叩齿三通，咽液三过，上香密咒曰： 向来听经圣众，解坛散席，各复所司。 神风静默，山海肃清，千邪伏匿，百灵 护形。 次自东为始，存天真上升，每方心拜三拜，三叩齿送之。 次鼻引三色云炁，咽入五脏，想四兽复本位，叩齿三通，咽液三过。 然后收经出室，语言无碍。 诵经如不依此，不若不诵，而免怠慢之愆。 或谓丹旨何须载此，盖道存内外，不得不然。 庶几人知崇重，各招福德也。 元始无量度人上品妙经内义卷之五竟
chunks.translated_text:
When the subsequent summons arrives, proceed in the same manner as before. Next, concentrate the mind to ensure all spirits within the body return to their respective palaces. Knock the teeth three times, swallow saliva three times, offer incense, and secretly intone:

The sacred assembly that has gathered to hear the scripture shall now dissolve the altar and disperse. May the divine winds fall silent, mountains and seas grow solemn and clear, all myriad evils hide in submission, and the hundred spirits guard this form.

Beginning from the east, visualize the Perfected of Heaven ascending, bow three times in the heart for each direction, and knock the teeth three times to send them forth. Then draw in the three-colored cloud-qi through the nose, swallow it into the five viscera, and envision the Four Celestial Beasts returning to their original positions. Knock the teeth three times and swallow saliva three times. Only then may the scripture be gathered and one exit the chamber, speech unrestrained.

Should the recitation not follow this order, it would be better left undone, lest negligence incur fault. Some may ask why alchemical principles require such observances—it is because the Dao abides both within and without, and this cannot be otherwise. May all who know this hold it in reverence and thereby summon forth fortune and virtue.

Here ends the fifth fascicle of the *Esoteric Meaning of the Supreme Scripture of Limitless Salvation by the Primordial Beginning*.
